author: Michael Starr
summary: It's not only showing all 156 episodes of Rod Serling's classic CBS series, in chronological order - "TZ" aired from 1959 to '64 - but it's airing them in HD. (That probably won't make much of a difference for a black-and-white series from this era, but still . . .) This parable of life and death, decided in a seedy pool room (city unknown), features two actors with terrific chops and even better chemistry: Jack Klugman as Jesse Cardiff, the self-proclaimed best pool player on Randolph Street, and Jonathan Winters as the dead pool legend James Howard "Fats" Brown ("The best who ever was"). Fats materializes from pool-player heaven and challenges Jesse to a game. The stakes? If Jesse wins, he lives. If he loses, he dies. The banter between Klugman and Winters (stepping outside his comic comfort zone) is priceless. (And the timing was perfect: The episode aired shortly after the big-screen premiere of "The Hustler," co-starring Jackie Gleason as pool legend Minnesota Fats.) This one still creeps me out. Evil youngster Anthony Fremont (Billy Mumy, later to star in "Lost in Space") holds his family and small Ohio town hostage by killing anyone who doesn't think good thoughts about him (or anything else) - turning them into something hideous before "wishing" them to a nearby cornfield. One of Anthony's neighbors gets drunk at a birthday party and mouths off about the young lad. Bad move. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Boy, I'm Scared! The 10 best 'Twilight Zone' episodes on Syfy

author: Bart Hubbuch
summary: "What I want to do is win a game on Sunday - that's the bottom line for this group right now," [Tom Coughlin] added. "I always have the competitive spirit, [but] sometimes it takes me a day or two to figure it all out when it's over. Right now, let's stick with the game and let's go win a football game." "[I] love him, there's no doubt," [Rashad Jennings] said. "I love Coach Coughlin. The very first thing that I noticed from him the very first day I got here [was] something he said that kind of reiterates who he is: 'Faces may change, but expectations never do.' I've always seen him lead in that way, too. He's an awesome coach." "I'm focused on the game, I don't go that way [of thinking about what the emotions will be when Sunday's game is over]," Coughlin said. "I'm not thinking about any of that stuff." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Kevin Kernan
summary: Tom Coughlin did not meet the challenge this season. As the new year begins, here is a closer look at some of Coughlin's best qualities and the key coaching mistakes that caused his downfall. When The Post asked Coughlin on Thursday what the biggest thing he learned from this 6-9 season was, Coughlin offered a little laugh and said, "Win the close games. Find a way to win the close ones." Said running back Rashad Jennings: "I love Coach Coughlin. The very first thing that I noticed from him the very first day I got here [was] something he said that kind of reiterates who he is: 'Faces may change, but expectations never do.' I've always seen him lead in that way, too. He's an awesome coach." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Plenty of lessons in this lost season

author: Brian Costello
summary: "It's a reality check in the sense where you start out fast as a team and then you fall to a .500 record," wide receiver Eric Decker said of the midseason adjustment. "You can go both ways. I've seen it go both ways. The fact that everyone rallied around one another and started to win one game after another, confidence built. I think we've played enough together to have the experience of what the systems are. ... It felt like we started having fun and started playing football instead of overthinking things and overdoing things." "I just wasn't pleased with the majority of my performance," [Ryan Fitzpatrick] said. "That was just something I tried to evaluate after that game and work on the next few weeks and try to get better at and I think we've seen some progress and I just want to make sure I'm going out there and making the right decisions and making the right throw to the guys." "I think in order for us to progress to move forward, we had to incorporate more guys in the offense, because you can shut down two guys," [Todd Bowles] said. "With [Bilal Powell] being back there along with [Kenbrell Thompkins] and Quincy, we've progressed quite a bit. I'm happy about that." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Steve Serby
summary: "We've discussed it, we talked about it after practice, we understand we can't let one night ruin what you're going into this weekend ... you can't babysit them all," [Todd Bowles] said. "They can run out to New York City and have fun and do everything you need to do, but understand what you have ahead of you and what you're coming into tomorrow." "It was mind-blowing, it was very mind-blowing to sit there ... the previous years you're sitting at home and watching everybody play," [Darrelle Revis] said. "And you have these team goals before the season to sit here and say, 'Hey, we want to win the Super Bowl.' And, you get your dreams crushed when you don't make the playoffs the previous years. So, to actually finally get there, and be like, 'Wow, we're here,' but now we have to make some noise, we have to advance week-to-week to get where we want to go." "It's almost like divine intervention," he said at the time. "I don't think it's coincidence. I hope God's a Jets fan." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Howie Kussoy
summary: "I knew from the get-go," [Watson] said following Clemson's 37-17 win over Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl. "I knew if we put the work in and the grind, we'd be at this point, and now we're here." The Sooners spent the days before the Orange Bowl believing they had seen Watson's type of athleticism before, believing they understood what 13 teams hadn't figured out. That confidence was soon shattered, broken with the realization of how misleading film can be. "He's the best player in the country," Clemson coach Dabo Swinney said. "It's just that simple. ... There ain't a better one than No. 4. This guy is special in every regard." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: For confident Watson, it was all elementary

author: Howie Kussoy
summary: "It's amazing to me that, I told them, 'You ain't favored to win the damn game, but we ain't no underdog,' " said Clemson coach Dabo Swinney, whose 14-0 Tigers will face No. 2 Alabama in the National Championship Game. "Everybody out there, nobody believes in this team except these guys and they just got a great heart and showed it." "We shocked them, didn't we?" Swinney joked about the fake punt. "Ain't nobody covering that big ol' guy. ... I just felt like that it was the right time. ... It was a great play and I thought a spark we needed. I felt like we were a little stagnant right there, a little tight and I wanted to send a message to the guys, 'Listen, we're here to play and let's cut it loose.' " "At this point, this championship drive, talent doesn't win the game. It's the will," Oklahoma linebacker Eric Striker said. "They just seemed to have that edge and that will about them in the second half and we didn't." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Zach Braziller
summary: The offense truly began to hits its stride two weeks later, when [Calvin Ridley], who had eight catches for 138 yards on Thursday, made his first start. He immediately became Alabama's No. 1 wide receiver that evening against Georgia, ranked eighth in the nation at the time, hauling in five catches for 120 yards and a touchdowns. He would have two more 100-yard receiving games, against Arkansas and Florida, during the regular season. And then came Thursday night, Ridley turning AT&T Stadium into his personal playground.  The cards were stacked against Ridley to make an impact this year. He played just three high-school games as a senior, because of Florida's age limits, which don't allow anyone over the age of 19 and nine months to be eligible to play. He didn't enroll at Alabama until the fall semester, late for most top football prospects. And he suffered a rib injury in the season opener against Wisconsin, an injury he still feels.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Believe it or not Tide turned after frosh WR Ridley's emergence

author: Zach Braziller
summary: "The focus they had for this game was completely different than we ever had before, and I think it paid off for them," [Nick Saban] said after Alabama rebounded from last year's playoff loss to Ohio State. "And we're looking forward to try to do the same thing for the next game."  "Tonight he had to make the plays because they were there, and [[Jake Coker]] certainly made them," Saban said. "But I think in each game that we've asked him to do that, he's come through for us very nicely."  The story, however, was the ferocious Alabama defense, which turned the physical Michigan State offensive attack meek, living up to its prodigious regular-season stats as the nation's leader in sacks and run defense. The front seven owned the line of scrimmage, living in the Spartans' backfield and sacking Connor Cook four times. The secondary, the third-ranked unit's supposed Achilles' heel, was strong in coverage, highlighted by [Cyrus Jones]' interception in the end zone to close the first half. At one point, a frustrated Cook could be seen on the scoreboard, saying to nobody in particular: "They're f---ing everywhere."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Fred Kerber
summary: "We got a chance to go see him, go talk to him, he's in good spirits," Carmelo Anthony said of the Wednesday nighttime visits by teammates to Early's Manhattan hospital room. "That kind of gave us some of our good spirits in here today. Came in here, got a good practice in. I don't want to say put that behind us, but we were able to focus on basketball today." "Couple of guys went in pairs, threes, but most of the guys went to go see him [Wednesday] night," Anthony said. "He's good, relatively speaking. But he's in good spirits. It was good to see everybody come through. That definitely put a smile on his face. He'll be back soon." "Basketball - people don't understand, sport period - is very therapeutic," Anthony said. "You can't control what happens off the court, but when you come into this gym, it's all about basketball. It's therapy. You get a chance to compete. ...Whether it's here, a football field, baseball stadium, a clubhouse, you can go to these places and feel like you're getting that release." author: Ryan Lazo
summary: "Just take a look at the timeline of the Jets from the preseason until now," [Damien Woody] said. "It started with the IK Enemkpali situation with Geno [Smith], Sheldon Richardson being suspended ... starting off 4-1 and then losing four of five, and then you go on a five-game winning streak. As a head coach, it's your job to keep everyone even-keeled and that's where you have to give [Todd Bowles] some credit. "It's not the first time [Rex Ryan] is in this type of situation," Woody said. "A few years ago, he had a chance to get the Jets to the playoffs with a win over the Dolphins, but couldn't get it done. Now he's on the other sideline and I'm sure it's going to be huge for Rex to try to get this victory and sweep the team he used to coach." It's something Bowles and his coaches have proven adept at. Bowles' confidence and steady hand have elevated his team's play over the season's final month, but it means nothing if the Jets can't get a win in Buffalo. author: Haley Goldberg
summary: It's a new year, and a new chance to get your finances in order. Here, 34-year-old Patrice Washington, an Atlanta-based personal-finance expert and author of three books, including the upcoming "Real Money Answers for Every Woman: How To Win the Money Game With or Without a Man" (Jan. 19, HarperCollins), tells Haley Goldberg her own story of hitting financial rock bottom - twice - and how she strategized her way out. "If you keep stressing out about the mortgage industry, you're not going to leave here with a baby," my doctor warned me. A maintenance worker had to drill the TV off of the wall to keep me from turning the news back on. After two years of pinching pennies, we still weren't making a dent in our debt. "This is not the $18,000 credit card debt that you had as a kid," a mentor finally told me. "You're in the big leagues now, and you can't nickel-and-dime your way out of $2 million." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: I WAS $2M IN DEBT - NOW I'M A SUCCESS! Patrice Washington owed millions after the recession - and now she teaches others how to manage their money

author: hALEY gOLDBERG
summary: If you can only settle your debt by filing for bankruptcy, know the cons: a dive in your credit score and a lack of trust from future creditors. "Bankruptcy was truly not our first choice," Washington says of her own decision to file for Chapter 7.Figure out your financial goal. Is it to raise your credit score? Get out of debt? "Breaking big goals into smaller steps [lets you] complete tasks on a daily, weekly or monthly basis," Washington says. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: GET YOUR FINANCES IN SHAPE

summary: [Stephen Colbert] is doing a little better in the traditional ratings, although he's been slipping a bit there as well. "The Late Show" is averaging around 3.1 million viewers, second to NBC's "The Tonight Show Starring [Jimmy Fallon]," with 3.9 million viewers. Colbert's show will get a coveted promotional slot after CBS airs the Super Bowl in February. Normally, the move might help narrow the digital divide - if Fallon's lead weren't growing even faster. Fallon's digital engagements in the fourth quarter were up 45 percent year over year, according to ListenFirst.  "The Colbert numbers aren't too surprising," Jason Klein, ListenFirst CEO, told The Post. "Generally, if you look at programming on CBS, it's just not a network where we see high engagement on digital and social. It's not just Colbert."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "It's always been in the back of my head," [Amukamara] said. "I mean, normal questions are if I'm going to stay here or if I'm going to go elsewhere. My main focus is to finish this season. I'd be lying if I said it's never come up in my head or someone has never brought it up to me." "Honestly, I don't think anybody could have come back from this injury like I did," said [Jason Pierre-Paul], who has an ankle issue and is listed as questionable to play in the season finale, against the Eagles. "I don't have fear of anything. I'm happy with what I did this year, I didn't sit out a season. This is my sixth year and hopefully the next five years or six years are going to be better." "I'm not going to disagree with my head coach, but my opinions would just be ups and downs," Amukamara said. "Are you talking about getting scored on against the Jets and getting scored on in Miami? I would say those are definitely two or three plays that stand out, but I felt like overall I was myself, maybe a little rusty because I hadn't played in five or six weeks, but I mean, I don't credit anything to that." author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "Hey, age catches up with everybody, in many areas, mentally and physically," [Charley Casserly] said. "You got to see where he is, does he still have the energy to do this? That's crucial. That's hard to judge because you're judging next year, you're not judging today, so that's a guess." "There isn't exactly Bill Parcells sitting there ready to walk in," Casserly said. "It's not, you can sit there and go to the grocery store and buy one. There's a gamble in whoever you bring in, and I think the Giants are well aware of that because [Tom Coughlin]'s an exceptional coach, and they know that. So you're going to have a little bit of a gamble going in if you make a change, you're going to be in the tournament like everybody else. That doesn't mean you can't get a good coach, but it's not surefire. "Clearly what's happened is they've had some bad drafts a couple of years ago, they've drafted a little better the last two years," Casserly said. "I think they got to take a good, hard look at what they're doing in scouting, why they have struggled at certain times and figure out: Is there something they need to evaluate there and change there? I know I had to go through that myself and change things internally. We didn't fire anybody, we changed some things internally in philosophy on how we were doing it and it was fine, we got better." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Hold your fire NFL sage Casserly: Talent void, energetic Giants complicate Coughlin decision

"I knew he knew [that I could beat him] when he started wanting to be on my team when we would have two-on-two games," she said. summary: "He doesn't really have an ego. At the same time he doesn't care if people like him or not, he's gonna treat everybody the same, and he expects you to win and get the job done," [Calvin Pryor] said. "He holds you accountable to your actions, on and off the field." [Todd Bowles] hasn't tried to be Bill Parcells. He hasn't tried to be Bruce Arians. He hasn't tried to be Joe Gibbs, and he sure hasn't tried to be Ryan. "We come in Wednesday - 'OK guys, this is what we need to do.We need to do A, B and C to win this game,' " [Darrelle Revis] said. " 'If we don't do A, B and C, then we'll lose.' He paints a very simple picture, man." Bowles wasn't any different this week than he has been any week. No Jet turbulence from week-to-week anymore. "Coach has been the same since he walked in the door, and that's not going to change," Pryor said with a smile. "People try to expect him to act different, but that's just not who he is. You got to love it because you never know what he's thinking, you never know what's on his mind. You expect the same from him week in and week out, and that's to prepare us as best as he can so we can go out there and play good football on Sunday." author: Brian Costello
summary: "We're playing pretty well right now, especially to win five in a row," cornerback Darrelle Revis said. "That's definitely difficult to do late in the season, but we're still up to the challenge and we have one more challenge this upcoming Sunday. Guys have been very responsive to how we made adjustments in the middle of the season and what we need to really focus on." On paper, this game is a mismatch in the Jets' favor. The Bills have nothing left to play for and Ryan's first year has been a mess filled with players ripping him, unreal expectations and plenty of injuries. "We do the same things we've been doing. You take it a game at a time," [Todd Bowles] said. "It's just the last game, so it's a more important game, but if you don't win the other five, you don't get yourself in this situation. You start doing things that you want to do that you haven't done in the last five weeks, then we're going down the wrong path. So from that standpoint, there's no pressure." author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: So look: If this is really it for Tom Coughlin, if Sunday's game with the Eagles at MetLife Stadium - two old rivals playing out the string of two lost seasons - is really the final game he will coach the Giants, there will be some melancholy attached to it, and some sadness, regardless of whether the ultimate separation is termed a "firing" or a "retirement," because in the upside-down reality of the profession, that's about as positive an ending as a coach can ask for: a melancholy one. "You'd like to think you have all the answers, and when you're successful you can delude yourself into believing that you do," [Davey Johnson] said five years after the Mets fired him. "But what you realize is this: Every coach and manager in every sport in the world is hired to be fired. It's an old clich. But every clich is based in a measure of truth, right?"  HARD GOODBYE: Tom Coughlin and the Giants are almost assuredly about to part ways. Whether it's the coach's or the team's choice, the breakup is never easy with great coaches, as the departures of (from top) [Joe Torre], [Pat Riley], [Mike Keenan] and [Bill Parcells] illustrate. (Getty Images)Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: BREAKING UP IS HARD TO DO Coughlin's likely finale a reminder coaching tenures very rarely end well

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "My responsibility will be fulfilled completely, there will be no distraction," [Tom Coughlin] said. "We're going to game plan and we're going to mentally be ready, we're going to get our players ready to play. We're going to do everything in our power. Then the season ends and that's what football is all about-what's next?" What's next is likely a day or so for ownership to set in motion Coughlin's removal as head coach, with the hope of making this a dignified retirement even though he has one year remaining on his contract.A decision for status quo would be shocking. "He wants us to go out there and just worry about playing football, worry about having our mind on our assignments, our job, our practice, and getting ready to play this football game," said Eli Manning, Coughlin's quarterback fo ra dozen years. "I don't think it helps to wonder. I think just follow his lead and listen to what he says, and just worry about going to play football and doing our job." "I think it's good," [Odell Beckham Jr.] said. "I think things like this help you grow and they help you mature. You learn from it and you move on. In life you're taught so many lessons, good or bad, and you learn from it and grow."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: "He's too good," Saints offensive tackle Zach Strief told New Orleans reporters last week. "There's like five [truly great quarterbacks] on the whole planet, really. When you have one, you don't get rid of him." [Stephen Gostkowski] also is perfect on extra points (51-for-51) despite the league moving the distance back this year. That's actually par for the course for Gostkowski, who hasn't missed a PAT since his 2006 rookie season. [Reggie Nelson] needs two interceptions Sunday to tie Deltha O'Neal's 2005 franchise record of 10. O'Neal, incidentally, was also considered a bust as a cornerback in Denver before rejuvenating his career in Cincinnati. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Richard Witt
summary: BROWNS (+10 1/2) over Steelers: Don't sneeze at Cleveland quarterback Austin Davis, who participated in Rams headbutts of the Buccaneers, 49ers and Seahawks last season. The Steelers earn their placement on playoff road with a win and a Jets loss, but won't endorse the concept of laying double-digits in this divisional visit. 49ERS (+3 1/2) over Rams: It's tough to buck St. Louis' revival behind Case Keenum, but the Rams' history attempting divisional sweeps as chalk has been sordid since the last two Mike Martz playoff seasons of more than a decade ago. The Niners figure to be competitive, unless they're angling for draft position. Rams' RB Todd Gurley (foot) is listed as doubtful. PACKERS (-3 1/2) over Vikings: We're no fans of Mike McCarthy's primitive passing strategies. It takes [Aaron Rodgers]' talent to make it better - but still want the Packers at Lambeau against the Vikings, who need to show they can beat real teams. If the Seahawks win, the Vikings off a loss can loiter around Green Bay for instant replay! Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: STEVE SERBY
summary: A: I think it's been definitely a journey. A journey where I've had the ability to kind of see some mountaintops. I've traveled through some valleys, because there's been times where we've really been successful as an organization ... and times where we just haven't. I've had different guidance along the way, at all levels, at all stages. And I think I've developed during that journey personally. Because as I traveled I learned some things through my experiences. So all in all, I'm pleased I have the opportunity to continue down this path, and I'm excited to see where it takes me. A: Personally, from an individual standpoint, when you get voted to the Pro Bowl ... I think as a team, the fact that we were able to beat some very good opponents in our playoff run. As far as some of the valleys, there's been some years, especially early on, where I don't feel maybe people had confidence in what I could do. So that's hard when you feel like you're traveling an uphill journey. And I think, as a team, there's been some real tough years where we've had some negative seasons, where we just couldn't figure out how to get out of the rut. It wasn't for a lack of effort. It wasn't for a lack of want-to. It was just what it was at that time, and I think that could be really challenging, because you don't exactly know what you're doing wrong. A: I don't know if it was any one person, but it could be just the lack of confidence. ... I don't know if I was held in the highest light as far as what I could do. Maybe there were many expectations coming in as a top pick. ... Maybe not having that immediate success, it felt like I was fighting an uphill battle, but when I was able to reach that mountaintop experience. ... During that time when I went to the Pro Bowl, we'd faced a lot of top opponents that I had to battle. The one thing about this game or this position is when you're on that field, there's nowhere to run, there's nowhere to go. You're going to play that game, you're going to finish that game, good, bad or indifferent. So it's kind of like a fight. It's almost like, you watch those UFC fights: Once that gate's closed, you're not getting out! So you have to decide whether you want to be the victor. How bad do you want it? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: It's hard to forget Rex Ryan's first team, after all, which famously received a gift from the Colts in Week 16 in 2009 but got just as much of a helping hand from the Bengals a week later, Cincinnati laying down in Week 17 and the Jets finishing off a most improbable playoff push (and then paying the Bengals back for that maneuver by beating them in Cincinnati the very next week). There also was a thrilling Week 17 win in Herman Edwards' first season, John Hall nailing a playoff-clinching field goal at the final gun in Oakland (and setting up a return trip there a week later that didn't have such a feel-good tinge to it). The Giants? One of the most painful of all Big Blue losses was the one that closed out the 1988 season, the 7-7-1 Jets beating them in the final minute on a Ken O'Brien-to-Al Toon touchdown pass, and because the Giants were good enough in those years to harbor Super Bowl aspirations every year, that one especially stings. But there was an equally thrilling finale in 2002, the Giants qualifying by beating the detested Eagles in overtime on the final day, Tiki Barber's one-man opera of a day (three fumbles, but also 203 yards rushing and 76 more receiving in a 10-7 win. author: Joel Sherman
summary: It is possible this might just whet appetites for Jan. 6 rather than diminish interest. For example, Ken Griffey Jr. had been named on all 128 ballots, so it will be fascinating if he tops Tom Seaver's record percentage of 98.84. Based on the public ballots, Mike Piazza, Jeff Bagwell and Tim Raines were all over the 75 percent threshold for election, but still needed a significant majority of what was unknown to gain election. Now my hypocrisy alert: The revealed ballots fascinate me. Actually, what they could be indicating fascinates me. Because if they are really predictive then large percentage leaps are coming for Bagwell, Piazza, Raines, Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens, Edgar Martinez, Mike Mussina, Curt Schilling and Alan Trammell. The Trammell bounce probably has much to do with something akin to a sympathy vote since this is his final year on the writers' ballot. The Internet megaphone is essentially owned by those who favor the advanced stats and care a lot less about PED use. The voting membership appears to be trending that way, as well. Also, that megaphone can tend to be vicious against those who do not vote to their liking, and I do wonder if more voters are checking boxes to avoid the online torment. I even wonder if some of those early released ballots are about getting praise on the Internet for "enlightened" ballots. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Fred Kerber
summary: "Quite frankly, we've been horrendous on the defensive end in the last six games as well," coach Derek Fisher said after his 15-19 Knicks had a long prep for Sunday's home meeting with Atlanta. "The focus has always been on the offense. We only scored eight points [in the fourth quarter], but we've been last in the league the last six games on defense. And that has a lot to do with this as well." "[Against Chicago], in terms of defensive efficiency, points per possession, was like 120. That won't get it done," Fisher said. "It's more interesting to talk about offense and what guys are shooting and who didn't get what shot. We often overlook the dirty work that needs to be done on the defensive end in order to win. If we can get back to that, the offense can come around." "It's more popular to talk about the other stuff, the offense," Fisher said. "Not saying our guys aren't trying to do those [dirty-work] things, we're just not getting it done as consistently as we should." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Lewis
summary: "It wasn't the cleanest way we'd like to finish things up, but we got the 'W' - that's the ultimate objective," said [Jarrett Jack], who left the locker room on crutches and will have an MRI exam on Sunday. "At least it wasn't insult to injury." Within 3:22 left Boston tied it up at 83-all, but [Brook Lopez]'s gave the Nets the lead again with a three-point play, and his putback made it 90-85 with 6:34 to play. The lead was still five on Lopez's dunk with 26.9 seconds left, but a Shane Larkin turnover followed by Turner's putback cut it to three, and Marcus Smart's interception of a Thaddeus Young pass gave the Celtics one last shot. "No, we were fortunate. I chalk it up to we were fortunate" [Lionel Hollins] said. "Because either one of those 3s could've gone in. They very easily could've gone in. We're fortunate and we'll take it and we have to get better." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: Instead it's here, after a New Year's Day practice in the quiet visitors' locker room at BB&T Center, when [Chris Kreider] says exactly what he's thinking. What's clear is the Rangers' 24-year-old former wunderkind spends a lot of time in his own head, thinking about hockey and his own game. And though the performance hasn't quite been there this season - the start of which he recently called "as bad as it can be" - there was some budding confidence taken from a good stretch heading into Saturday night's game against the red-hot Panthers. "There's no doubt that he's trying extremely hard," coach Alain Vigneault said. "I just look at the last game, and for a good portion of that day we didn't expect him to play. Still wanted to play, went out and I thought he was extremely physical when he had the opportunity to finish. He's trying hard. He's trying to put his game together, a lot like our team. Hopefully when he does, it's going to be real good." "We need everyone to fill their role. Do their job - that's the Patriots' motto, do your job," Kreider said. "You're not going to win games in this league if you don't have guys firing on all cylinders most nights." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: ZACH BRAZILLER
summary: Can Watson create issues for Alabama? The Crimson Tide haven't faced anyone quite like him. The closest comparison is Mississippi State quarterback Dak Prescott. The Tide held him to 14 yards on 26 carries; however, Prescott isn't surrounded by anywhere close to the talent that surrounds [Deshaun Watson], up front or at the skill positions, and he isn't quite as good, either. What makes this so fascinating is how different these two coaches are, from the buttoned-up approach of [Nick Saban] to the carefree personality of Swinney. If Clemson wins, you will get to see one of [Dabo Swinney]'s great dance routines. If Alabama prevails, Saban already will be planning recruiting visits. He might not even smile. The Spartans dared [Jake Coker] to beat them, stacking the box against [Derrick Henry], and Coker obliged, with the best performance of his career. It's hard not to feel good for Coker, a selfless leader his teammates swear by who has waited until his fifth year of college to finally get this opportunity, three years as a backup at Florida State and one at Alabama. He's certainly making the most of it. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: The Giants traded up six spots in the fourth round of the 2013 NFL Draft to select [Ryan Nassib], a quarterback out of Syracuse. At the time, general manager Jerry Reese stated he hoped Nassib never played, not wanting the need to arise for Nassib to replace Eli Manning. Well, Reese got his wish. Nassib has taken the field five times in his career, only in mop-up duty. He has completed nine of his 10 passes for 128 yards. Last week, with the Giants trailing 49-10 to the Vikings in Minneapolis, Nassib relieved Manning and completed all five of his passes, including a 25-yard touchdown to rookie Myles White. It was the first touchdown for both players. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: No Backup plan Future still unclear for Giants' No. 2 QB Nassib

author: BIlLY HELLER
summary: Sakamoto tells the true story of Japanese-American siblings Frank, Pierce and Harry Fukuhara, who found themselves on opposite sides of the Pacific Ocean as the US entered World War II. Living in their mother's ancestral home in Hiroshima, younger brothers Frank and Pierce became soldiers in the Japanese Imperial Army. Back in the US, eldest brother Harry was sent to an internment camp after Japan attacked Pearl Harbor but was released to become a bilingual interpreter for the US Army. US-Japanese wartime relations as you've never seen them before. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Maureen Callahan
summary: "I was an extremely pious child," he writes. "I liked to enforce the rules of Islam. 'The wrath of Allah will be upon you,' I used to say to my aunties. 'Go and cover your head.' " "With hindsight, I can see what barbarity this was," Passarlay writes. "But it has to be put into context . . . My grandfather called life under the Taliban 'The best of times we are living in.' " By June 2007, Passarlay had been on the run for six months, bouncing among Turkey, Iran and Bulgaria. The attempted sea crossing, the one that nearly killed him, brought him his wish: Passarlay and the others were rescued by Greece's coast guard. They were rounded up and put in a holding cell, but Passarlay was struck by the kindness of the Greek guards, who let the Muslim prisoners observe Ramadan. "I was greatly touched by this," he writes. "Greece isn't a Muslim country." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

None of the three hybrid vehicle models that are currently approved by the TLC is wheelchair accessible." Of the city's 13,587 yellow cabs, only 581 are now wheelchair accessible. Not good enough, says Jim Weisman, the president of the United Spinal Association: "The city made a deal and we expect them to live up to it and enforce the rule." author: Michael Gray
summary: That's why NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell is trying to squeeze out every penny of profit now. While football has always wrung fans with things like "personal seat licenses" and television networks with sky-high licensing fees, pairing with gambling companies like instant fantasy football is the first initiative that takes the league into a gray area that can hurt the game. And that's facing a court battle as well. While ratings remain high, there have been some trouble signs. Look at Disney's stock. The company releases the biggest movie ever in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," yet all analysts and investors are focused on is ESPN losing subscribers who don't want to pay extra to view games. Madison Ave.: You are already seeing advertisers moving away from using pro athletes in their campaigns. As Peyton Manning moves quickly to retirement, who will be the face of the NFL for national advertisers? Not Tom Brady or Drew Brees. Yes, you have a handful of companies that are in love with pro football and as of now the league still delivers a desirable demographic, but where are today's "heroes" to build a future that Madison Avenue can invest in so it's not so easy for them to walk away should the public begin to turn away? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: END OF THE NFL It seems impossible - but professional football faces a dire future

author: Kyle Smith
summary: "I think we've said we've got to get our message out better," Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, [David Dinkins]' chief political aide, said at the time. "The vehicles we've used haven't gotten the message out clearly, so we're going to the people."  Since de [De Blasio] arrived, though, #We'reAlarmedEnough. The effect of some of his videos is not what is intended. In the clip called "ThriveNYC: NYC's Mental Health Roadmap" (4,400 views), cartoon characters say things like, "I'm not able to sleep at night," "I'm anxious all the time" and "Drinking is the only way I can feel good these days." They may be intended to sound like mental-health patients but they sound more like the New Yorkers pollsters are calling to ask them how they feel about living in the city these days. The feeling is widespread that de Blasio, in the first significant office he has ever held, doesn't get it. He is heading for his own "DAVE, DO SOMETHING" moment (to quote the front page headline addressed to Mayor Dinkins in the Sept. 7, 1990, Post). As one observer wrote of those days, "There was a sense of doom on the streets . . . The cops on the beat wanted to do their jobs, but the brass didn't trust them to do it . . . The feeling behind many desks was that it was better for cops to stay away from criminals and steer clear of temptation than to chase them down and put them away." The person who wrote those words is Bill Bratton, de Blasio's police chief, in his memoir, "Turnaround." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Isabel Vincent,Melissa Klein
summary: For seven years, the NRA also skipped a key question on its tax form - whether or not it engaged in lobbying. Asked to answer "yes" or "no," it simply left the space blank. It also answered "yes" in 2014 filings to whether it conducted political activity - something the NRA denied in its previous six IRS filings. Such activity is potentially subject to tax. The NRA reported paying $1.6 million in taxes last year on its political activity. "The NRA is a sophisticated entity that only filed its tax returns after multiple layers of internal and external review, making it difficult to believe a clerical error is responsible for the NRA's failure to report its political expenditures for at least six years," wrote Noah Bookbinder of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington in a June 2015 letter to the IRS. You may also recognize him as Adele's love interest in the music video "Hello" - and his resume promises to grow with talks of "The Breaks" possibly turning into a five-part series. "We're both from Staten Island so I have known him since I was a kid," he says of Method Man. "My father owns a barber shop so he would cut all of Wu-Tang's hair. So it was cool and hilarious to have [Method Man] play my dad - a man who was so strict and just wanted me to go to school and get a job - versus the real Method Man, who told me to follow my dreams and go for what I want." The ball fluttered in the air and Manny Lawson intercepted it. The Jets got the ball back one last time with under a minute left. So, yes: the ball that Leodis McKelvin picked off in the end zone with 10:48 left in the game might have been the one that caused you to double over in misery, and the two that followed probably made you reach for a couple of bonus Alka-Seltzers. author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: "The first one, it was more emotional, there's no question - first time going against the Jets or whether it was [because] it was there," Ryan went on, referring to the Nov. 12 Thursday night game that Buffalo won 22-17 at MetLife Stadium. "I know it was real emotional for me then." Ryan's defense did a masterful job of thwarting the inside screen passing game the Jets love to use. The Jets had been killing opponents on those screens during their five-game winning streak entering the game, and Ryan took those away. "It's not the same team over there, trust me," Ryan said, referring to the talent the new regime brought in after firing him. "You got [receiver] Brandon Marshall on that football team. I would have liked to have him when I was there. They got [Darrelle] Revis and [Antonio] Cromartie [who were both re-signed in the offseason]. I'm not taking anything away from those guys [on the Jets last year], but I don't believe they were over there last year, either." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Rexact revenge Ryan's Super Bowl more a relief than a celebration

author: Brian Costello
summary: "You just can't keep everybody on this defensive line," [Sheldon Richardson] said. "It's just not realistic. Guys are going to play out their contracts. I'm gonna miss 'em." "We grew up together, pretty much in the league," Richardson said. "They helped me through a hard time in my life. It's going to be tough." "They were costly," Jets coach Todd Bowles said. 'There are mistakes that can't happen that we had happen in this game that we were pretty good at all year." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Howie Kussoy
summary: "He still has the same command when he walks in the room. He is still Coach [Tom Coughlin] to me," [Hakeem Nicks] said following Sunday's 35-30 loss to the Eagles, having returned to the Giants in November after leaving before the 2014 season. "He is going to get on you when he needs to get on you and he is going to let you know when you do things right, as well, so it has been a pleasure playing for him. "He believed in me before I believed in myself," said [Tye], an undrafted free agent out of Stony Brook, who had 67 yards and a touchdown Sunday. "He has that old-school feel you don't like, but you know you need. He does the right things and you know he knows what he's doing. You know he knows best." "I say it all the time, my two years of playing under Coach Coughlin, one of the things that stuck out about him when he was speaking to us as a whole entire team, he said one thing and I wrote it down and it is kind of a staple of how I perceive him," [Rashad Jennings] said. "He said that, 'Faces may change, but expectations never will.' " Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Jints standing behind Tom

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "The season just ended, there will be time for that," he said. "We will get into that discussion. I'm going to give myself a little bit of time. I'm sure we'll talk with ownership and then we'll go from there." Prior to the game, [Tom Coughlin] had his entire family on the Giants' sideline, including his wife, children and 11 of his grandchildren, wearing "Coughlin Crew" shirts. It had the look and feel of a closing act. "I love him," Justin Pugh said. "I know one day I'm going to look back and say I played for Tom Coughlin and learned a lot of great things from him." And he tells me. You have that chemistry and you just build on that. ... It's not about me but I am thankful I got the opportunity." "I'm excited because I'm just now getting in my prime late in my career," Jennings said. "I'm gonna be right here training every day, making sure I'm ready [for next season]. "I'm trying to be more aggressive, draw more fouls, drive to the basket," [Porzingis] said. "This shows my versatility, not only a shooter from the outside, but I can get to the basket, that's what I'm focusing on a little more. That opens up options for my teammates, that's what I'm trying to do. "The hardest thing is to play at this level every night," Porzingis said. "For a team like us, it's not easy yet because we are still learning. We are getting there. We have to bring the energy and the intensity that we had tonight." summary: He's known as "AA," but Knicks shooting guard Arron Affalo may just be the Knicks' X-factor. "I felt it [this zone] a couple of times but not in the last week and a half. Once I was feeling the shot going, I have to commend my teammates. They started looking for me and kept finding me. I've been in that situation a few times where you feel you have a great rhythm, your mind is clear." author: Brian Lewis
summary: "When u get an update on your phone and the update is about you haha that kind of made me laugh in the midst of everything else," [Jarrett Jack] wrote on Instagram on Sunday, as he shared a picture of an alert announcing his injury. "Sh-- sucks but I'm ready for the grind to get back already." Jack is making $6.3 million this season and the Nets have a team option on his $6.3 million salary next year, with only $500,000 guaranteed. But the Nets are in rebuild mode, Jack is 32 and has been picked by the annual NBA GM survey as one of the five players who would make the best coach, so his future is in question. What isn't in question is how much he would have helped this season, after the Nets gave away their likely lottery pick to Boston and have no incentive to lose. Jack averaged 12.8 points and a team- and career-high 7.4 assists. That doesn't begin to tell the tale of his importance to this team. Jack was the only player to come to Brook Lopez's defense Saturday after he was horse-collared and thrown down by Boston's Jared Sullinger, or to check on Thaddeus Young when he dove into the front row for a loose ball. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: In no-Jack city Season-ending injury a huge blow for Nets

summary: "Like a lot of our players right now, there's no doubt that the effort is there, the preparation is there, but at the end of the day, it's about results right now," the coach said. "It's about better execution, and as a group, we saw it [Saturday] night, the execution was a little bit off and we couldn't capitalize." "It's getting there," [Derek Stepan] said Saturday night. "I think each game has gotten better. Certainly been a battle thus far. I just need to find a way to maybe get a goofy one or something like that and open the floodgates. I think I've been better each game and I think [Saturday] night was my best." "I think offensively we have to be better," Stepan said. "Offensively, we had our looks and the goalie was able to see everything. That'll be a focus going forward, to make sure we do a better job taking the goalie's eyes, making it difficult on him." author: Paul Schwartz
summary: Those anticipating or hoping for Odell Beckham Jr. to light it up in his return from a one-game suspension had to be disappointed with his showing Sunday. Beckham was relatively quiet in the Giants' 35-30 loss to the Eagles, with only five receptions for 54 yards - and only one catch for 12 yards in the first half. With the loss, the Giants finish in third place in the NFC East, meaning they will play the Rams on Oct. 23 next season in London. The rest of the 2016 road schedule: At Green Bay, at Minnesota, at Cleveland and at Pittsburgh in addition to road games against the Eagles, Cowboys and Redskins. At home, the Giants will play the Bears, Lions, Ravens, Saints and Bengals in addition to their three division rivals. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Sara Stewart
summary: If you think you're being fleeced paying more for a 3-D ticket, you're right. Not since 2009's "Avatar" has a film's 3-D tech been remotely worth the higher ticket price - yet it can be tough to find a 2-D showtime of a movie that's also available in 3-D. Roger Ebert was an early hater of the 3-D resurgence, ticking off the many ways the format sucks, saying "It is unsuitable for grown-up films of any seriousness." More recently, Marvel's Stan Lee, whose creations figured in a spate of 3-D movies, took to YouTube ranting, "I don't want 3-D pushed at me as if it's something new!" Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Jane Ridley
summary: At 238 pounds, 5-foot-3 [Jan Reuss] was taking heart pills, suffering from aching joints, and her bright personality had dimmed as she retreated into herself due to her size.The concern on [Mike Berland]'s face was enough to jolt the 67-year-old Reuss into following the "Fat-Burning Machine" regimen her son recently devised with his team of experts. "I loved Hagen-Dazs ice cream, Smucker's hot fudge sauce, apple pie, carrot cake, pizza and pasta," she confesses, also attributing her weight gain to the slowing down of her metabolism as she aged. "I had an insatiable appetite." "My friends can't believe it, and my husband loves it," concludes Reuss. "But what makes this experience so special is that my kids care about me so much and want me to be around for a long, long time." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: MOM'S WEIGHTY ISSUES

author: Jane Ridley
summary: "I did the New York City Marathon in 2013 and managed to gain 10 pounds," recalls the 47-year-old CEO of Edelman Berland, shaking his head. "Something was off." Spurred by his success, Berland formed a "focus group" of other dieters who followed the regimen - all of whom lost similarly impressive amounts of weight. It led to his just-published book - written with former US Olympic triathlon coach Gale Bernhardt - called "Become a Fat-Burning Machine: The 12-Week Diet." The Post is exclusively excerpting the book - already a best-seller on Amazon - this week. The main finding was the Manhattan-based father of two's diagnosis, by nutritionist Dr. Laura Lefkowitz, of "metabolic syndrome" - a condition of insulin resistance affecting 35 percent of Americans in which food is stored as fat rather than burned for energy. Berland had been encouraging his system to hoard fat by loading up on carbs like pasta and rice, as well as sugary fruits such as bananas. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: I SHED 70 LBS HERE'S HOW! After years of battling the bulge, Mike Berland got fed up - so he created a miracle diet plan. Now, he reveals his amazing get-fit regimen

summary: [Marissa Mayer] and Co. have been testing investors' patience for months. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: His players - judging from their heartfelt words and Eli Manning's teary eyes - would not agree, but early Monday afternoon, Tom Coughlin stressed: "This is not a sad occasion forme." Befitting his direct style, Coughlin after his final team meeting met with Giants co-owners John Mara and Steve Tisch and "informed them that it is in the best interest of the organization that I step down as head coach." This was the expected course of action, as Coughlin made it easy on ownership by resigning with one year remaining on his contract, one day after the Giants finished 6-10 for the second straight season, putting the playoffless streak at four consecutive years. It nevertheless was a stunning turn of events, as Coughlin, 69, was on the scene for 12 years, produced two Super Bowl victories for the franchise and is a likely future inductee into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. "It is difficult to come up with words adequate to describe the appreciation we have for everything Tom Coughlin has done for our franchise," Mara said. "In addition to delivering two Super Bowl titles, Tom represented us with class and dignity, and restored the pride to our entire organization. He has all the qualities you could ever ask for in a head coach, and set very high standards for whoever will succeed him." Succeeding Coughlin will not be easy and replacing him is a crucial move for Mara and [Jerry Reese], who returns despite a deterioration of the talent level on the roster. Offensive coordinator Ben McAdoo will be considered and the Giants must work quickly, as there are multiple openings throughout the NFL and teams are already lining up candidates for interviews. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: END OF AN ERA Saying time right for himself and Giants, Coughlin steps aside after 12 seasons

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "People want to tell me that I've changed; I'm still not very comfortable with that notion," [Tom Coughlin] told me in a private moment in the summer of 2008, six months after the Giants won the first of two Super Bowls under his watch. "I do think I've adjusted. And don't we always say that's what a coach has to do, make adjustments? At halftime. At practice. In a two-minute drill. Really, that's all this is. Adjustment." Oh, you remember those, right? Show up early for meetings or not at all. The "no sunglasses" rule. The no-crossing-your-legs-during-meetings rule. The old "Concentration Line" he'd literally drawn in the sand in Jacksonville. And don't forget the corollary Coughlin Beliefs, which included the notion that injuries were a "cancer" that were "mainly mental" (an observation that would haunt him later on). That is the version of Coughlin Giants fans will keep with them forever, because that's the one who would deliver those two Super Bowls, who would take his place alongside - if not slightly higher than - Bill Parcells and Jim Lee Howell and Steve Owen in the pantheon of Giants coaches. Reaching that level because he was willing to make the kind of fundamental change - er, "adjustment" - coaches too often are too stubborn to make. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: KEEP THE CHANGE Giants fans should cherish highs of 'adjusted' Coughlin

I think the guys that returned from last year should appreciate the work they put in to helping us maybe take a step forward. But we have a very, very long way to go."Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Fred Kerber
summary: "It can be a challenge because you also have young guys that are still trying to figure their way out, along with trying to figure out what we're trying to do as a team," [Carmelo Anthony] said. "You've got to have some type of patience when it comes to that. You never want to put that much pressure on the young guys and the new guys as well, because we're still trying to find our way, we're still trying to find some consistency. When we do find that, we're a hell of a team out there. And we find that on both ends of the court, I think we're a tough team to beat." "It's difficult to do," [Derek Fisher] said of that elusive consistency. "There are so many variables. Being healthy is one. We've done a good job there, keeping guys healthy. Our players have really invested in themselves as far as that goes. And then, two, forming the bonds and connective tissue necessary to be a really good team. We've got a lot of new guys, so it's hard to be at your best when everything is kind of new, night-in and night-out. It just takes time. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: More like it Knicks seek consistency after their heartening victory

author: Ken Davidoff
summary: Given the whispers that surround [Jeff Bagwell] and have kept him out of Cooperstown for five years, here are my parameters regarding illegal performance-enhancing drugs: If Major League Baseball suspended a player for an on-field transgression, I consider that damaging, although not disqualifying, to his candidacy. Barring such discipline, it's irrelevant. So it's not a matter of whether I think or don't think Bagwell used illegal PEDs. I simply don't care. And his offensive numbers (.948 OPS and 149 OPS+) speak for themselves. Will he break Tom Seaver's record of 98.84 percent support? I'm betting yes, for two reasons: 1. The elimination of about 90 voters who hadn't covered the game for 10 or more years seems to have removed much crankiness from the electorate; and 2. [Ken Griffey Jr.], who possesses no known ties to illegal PEDs, looks even better thanks to his less shiny contemporaries like [Barry Bonds]. In any case, Junior's overall accomplishments make him a slam dunk. Tim Raines is my 11th choice. I've voted for Mark McGwire in the past, and I'd vote for Gary Sheffield in the future. Sammy Sosa's 2003 suspension for a corked bat works against him. It's hard to support closers Trevor Hoffman, Lee Smith and Billy Wagner with the current logjam. Mad respect (but no votes) for the careers of Jim Edmonds, Nomar Garciaparra, Jeff Kent and Fred McGriff. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Jane ridley
summary: "Looking back, it was ridiculous," says Berland, 47, a lifelong carbohydrate addict who, at his heaviest in 2008, tipped the scales at 245 pounds. "The good choices [Marcela Miguel Berland] was making were staring me in the face, but I was just so set in my ways." Now, the veteran political pollster and CEO of Manhattan-based crisis-management and p.r.firmEdelman Berland has reversed the bad habits that date from his childhood. "The appealing thing about the Fat-Burning Machine diet, from a scientific perspective, is that it emphasizes clean, balanced eating," writes Simsin the forward to Berland's just published book, "Become a Fat-Burning Machine: The 12-Week Diet." The key theory behind the diet is that certain foods-notably complex carbohydrates such as breads, potatoes and pasta, as well as sugar-laden fruits -encourage the body to store fat. Others- mainly proteins such as lean meats, nuts, egg whites and leafy vegetables and "good" unsaturated fats like olive oil and avocados- trigger its fat-burning ability by optimizing the production and release of insulin, the hormone that helps your body turn blood sugar (glucose) into energy. "It's simple, but incredibly effective,"says Berland,who no longer craves the fat-storing foods he grew up loving."With the right kind of exercise[which The Post will outline Wednesday], this diet can turn anyone into a Fat-Burning Machine." Read on for the seven-day meal plan Berland has created for The Post, plus mouth-watering recipes and tips.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: EAT THIS AND BURN FAT How to enjoy steak, eggs and sweets - and still shed pounds

summary: [Dennis Friedrich], 50, who will step down on Jan. 15, is said to have broken the news to colleagues just before the holidays. There was no word on a successor. Brookfield's rep and Friedrich both declined to comment, but a source said, "It was amicable. He has a strong relationship with Global Office Division Chairman Ric Clark. There were no skeletons." Friedrich seemed as cheerful as ever at the Fried, Frank holiday party in early December. But sources suggested the growing complexity of Brookfield's corporate structure made for an "overcrowded environment," and Friedrich felt it was time go out on top rather than see his role diminished. Friedrich was promoted from chief operating officer of Brookfield Office Properties' US division to CEO in 2012. Brookfield Office Properties was later subsumed into Brookfield Property Partners, trading on the NYSE as BPY, which itself is a division of publicly traded Brookfield Asset Management (BAM). author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "Let's be honest," the owner of the Giants said Tuesday morning, when it became official the team was saying goodbye to Tom Coughlin and hello to at least another couple of years of Jerry Reese, "we've lost some credibility as an organization." Ten words that cut right to the truth of what presently ails the Giants, that had to cut like a razor blade to [John Mara]'s veins and arteries. First there was Coughlin's fire and brimstone farewell, in which he managed to channel both Patton ("We have an obligation to teach these young men the lessons, the principles and the life skills that they will need once their professional careers are over!") and Dear Abby ("Eli, it's not you," he said, looking right at his stricken quarterback, "It's not you. It's us. We win, we lose together.") with a little Friars Club wiseguy sprinkled in ("They don't panic every time there's a missed third down," he said of his bosses, "just after you go 6-10 twice.") And that was the easy part. "Even though everybody's involved with grading players, the players that we take, I don't try to have full control of everything. Our coaching staff is involved, our personnel staff is involved, everybody's involved." In other words: I'm responsible. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Giants need bridge over credibility gap

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "First of all,I wouldn't characterize it as a firing," [John Mara] said. "Listen, we had 12 great years. All good things have to come to an end at some point in time. But I can never begin to repay him for everything he's done for this franchise." [Tom Coughlin] said he would advise the next head coach that "he's going to work for a great organization, people that will support and back you, people that are real football people." Then, coyly, he added, "They don't panic every time there's a missed third down. Just after you go 6-10 twice." Asked if he had any regrets, Coughlin said, "If this was 7-9, I would have been in Mr. Mara's office, Mr. [Steve Tisch]'s office. How do you lose six games in 30 seconds and not be competitive? Your players play-I will not swear-their tails off." That does not sound like someone doubting he still could do the job. "He walks out the door with his head held high," Mara said. "We're very grateful for everything that he's done."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: A FIERY FAREWELL - & A COLD ASSESSMENT As Coughlin gives spirited goodbye, Mara delivers harsh judgment on GM

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "I think our offense certainly improved," [John Mara] said. "I think he's proven himself to be a very good teacher, has a very good handle on our offense. I think he communicates very well. I think he shows some leadership skills. I think he has some good qualities." "It's certainly a factor," Mara said. "At the end of the day you have to get the right man for the job. That can't be the overriding determination." "We want to get the right guy. It has to be the right person who can communicate with the players, can teach, has something to prove, all those kinds of things, a guy that wants to win Super Bowls. Coach [Tom Coughlin], he's going to be a tough act to follow. First of all, if a guy has thin skin, he shouldn't come here. That's the first thing I'll tell him. If you have thin skin, this is not the job for you. Don't come here." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Giants interested in Gase, Marrone

author: Steve Serby
summary: "He knows what the expectations are," [John Mara] said. "He knows we're not impulsive and we don't make rash, illogical decisions. He's done it before, I believe he can do it again. That's the bottom line." "I still believe that [S JERRY Reese] is the right guy to lead us going forward," Mara said. "Jerry put together two Super Bowl-winning teams. I would venture to say that if we were to poll all of you in this room two years ago about the top general managers in the league, every one of you in here would have him on the list. So now it's two years later, after another bad season ... do we want to throw all that out? I still think he's capable of putting a great team together. He's gonna get that opportunity. ... I still have full confidence in him." "Because I know how passionate I am about it," he began. "I know we've put together championship teams before. I know the big picture of what the National Football League is. I'm not a guy, you can ask a lot of people around the National Football League, everybody has their opinion. Somebody wrote me yesterday saying, 'You're taking some haymakers.' But that's part of the business." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: BART HUBBUCH
summary: "I want to thank [Judy], she's my quarterback," he said of his wife. "She is rock solid. She's what it's all about. Without her, the hub, the strength, that's where it comes from." He also thanked what he described as the Giants "extended family"-their fans. "To our fans, thank you very much," [Tom Coughlin] said. "Thank you so much for your support, including the one guy that sits up here in the tunnel. You know what? This guy never did quite get my name straight. A lot of different names he called me, but never did quite get it right. But I do say thank you to the fans." Although Coughlin came off the podium and walked by coowner John Mara without so much as looking at him immediately afterward, Coughlin complimented Mara and the rest of the Giants' owners as "real football people." "I'd tell [the next Giants coach] he's going to work for a great organization, people that will support and back you, people that are real football people," Coughlin said. "That could be another lecture of mine for the National Football League,which I'll refrain from right now. But they are football people. They don't panic every time there's a missed third down, just after you go 6-10 twice." But even with the two Lombardi trophies, Coughlin said the relationships he developed with his players is what will linger with him. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: Grateful to the end Thankful Coughlin defines self by 'unbreakable bond' with players

Coughlin also gave Manning a pep talk with the Giants passer facing the possibility of learning a third offense in four seasons unless the team hires offensive coordinator Ben McAdoo as head coach or retains him under whoever they do hire. "He's going to be right in here in about two days starting to work on next year, just like he always does,"Coughlin said. "That's never going to change. God bless him for it." author: Brian Costello
summary: I lean toward the latter, but would be cautious. If I'm [Mike Maccagnan], I'd offer him a three-year, $30 million deal with $15 million guaranteed in the first two years. If it takes a little more guaranteed money to get the deal done, do it. If he stumbles in 2016 or '17, you cut him before 2018. This is not like last year when the Jets had $50 million in cap space. They are projected to have about $16-18 million in cap space at the moment. If you franchise [MUHAMMAD WILKERSON], that is basically your entire spending. So, Maccagnan must find some room. Start by renegotiating tackle D'Brickashaw Ferguson's contract. Ferguson's cap number is $14 million in 2016. He is still a serviceable left tackle, but no longer one of the best in the league. Ferguson needs to take a pay cut. If you can get him for $7 million-$8 million per year with guaranteed money for just two years, that would work. summary: The Knicks got off to another solid start versus the Hawks, with [Kristaps Porzingis] dominating. In what has not been part of his game recently, Porzingis soared in for two putbacks in the opening minutes and hit a tough fallaway in the post. His first putback was an emphatic slam after [Robin Lopez]'s ugly missed hook shot. He scored six of the Knicks' first 12 points. Porzingis hit a pullup for 62-51 lead with 9:30 left in the third, then blocked Paul Millsap. Anthony hit Lopez for a dunk to make it 64-51 and Porzingis capped the run with a 3-pointer after [Jose Calderon] stole the ball, giving the Knicks the 66-51 bulge. THAT'S MINE! Carmelo Anthony, who finished with 23 points, 11 rebounds and seven assists, goes up for an easy layup in front of [Kent Bazemore] during the Knicks' win over the Hawks. (Getty Images) THAT'S MINE! Lance Thomas takes the ball away from Paul Millsap during the first half of the Knicks' 107-101 victory over the Hawks on Tuesday night. EPAReproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Mike Puma
summary: DePodesta, 43, was hired within weeks of general manager Sandy Alderson's arrival to the Mets in November 2010 as part of a front-office overhaul that put an emphasis on drafting and player development. During DePodesta's tenure, the Mets drafted Michael Conforto, Brandon Nimmo, Dominic Smith and Gavin Cecchini, among others. "He did a great job for us in scouting and player development and international, so we are going to have some type of loss," said [Ricciardi], who arrived to the Mets with DePodesta and joined assistant general manager John Ricco on the top rung of the organizational ladder under Alderson. "But I also feel strongly that we have enough internal experience that we should be able to handle this. He did a great job for us and we're happy for him. You get an opportunity to do something that may not present itself at a different point in life, from a friend's standpoint I'm just very happy for him."  WHAT THE HELL? Mets manager [Terry Collins] chats with former Mets VP of player development and amateur scouting Paul DePodesta in 2011. DePodesta on Tuesday made the strange move from the Amazin' front office to an executive spot with the NFL's Cleveland Browns. APReproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: DePODESTINY Mets aide makes shocking move to exec for Browns

author: Ken Davidoff
summary: The first, Sandy Alderson's cancer diagnosis, generated concerns and good thoughts for the Mets' general manager and his family. The second, Paul DePodesta's departure for the Cleveland Browns on Tuesday, created industry-wide shock and a healthy diversion from Hall of Fame vitriol in the Twitterverse. DePodesta, who had been the Mets' vice president of player development and scouting, will be the Browns' chief strategy officer, the NFL team announced. It's a stunning move, albeit narratively fitting for a guy whose cinematic portrayal already generated an Oscar nomination (for Jonah Hill in "Moneyball"). Can't wait to see how DePodesta, who played football for Harvard, integrates into the NFL culture and whether he can help the Browns end their extended malaise like he did the Mets'. We never will learn for certain if DePodesta would have succeeded Alderson, 68, in the GM's chair for the Mets, but it wasn't a slam dunk. DePodesta lasted just two years as the Dodgers' general manager before getting fired in the fall of 2005, and he never seriously pursued another GM opening. He seemed more comfortable working under the radar, evaluating talent and not needing to perform as the club spokesman for every maneuver. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Surprise departure latest blow in rough offseason for the Amazin' front office

author: Jane Ridley
summary: A firm believer in the "no pain, no gain" idea of fitness that frequently had him working out to the point of collapse, Mike Berland couldn't understand why he wasn't getting the results he wanted. "Miracle intervals - alternating a relaxed pace with short bursts of high-intensity movement - make you burn fat at a faster rate," explains Berland. "Insulin [the fat-regulating hormone] is released most effectively when you are slowing down or recovering, not when you're accelerating or maintaining a high level of intensity." "I was under the misapprehension that weight training would make me more bulky," says Berland. "But under [Gale Bernhardt]'s supervision, it didn't have that effect at all. author: Robert George
summary: As for us Jets fans - who generally looked askance at the rival with whom we've long shared a stadium - we couldn't have been more pleased: A New York team had laid low Bill Belichick's mighty, smug, arrogant Patriots, who got caught cheating against the Jets earlier that year. (That, in turn, uncovered the fact that the Patriots under Belichick had been illegally videotaping opponents' defensive signals for nearly a decade.) Many years ago, legendary coach Bill Parcells produced two offspring assistants - "Angel" [Tom Coughlin] and "Devil" Belichick (why do you think he wears the hoodie?). Both men were on Parcells' staff when the Giants beat the Buffalo Bills in Super Bowl XXV. But only one - when given the opportunity - opted to take a chance and coach in the bright lights of New York: That would be the good son, Tom Coughlin. Coughlin, meanwhile, proved himself the anti-Belichick. He didn't dominate the NFC East during his 12 years. But when he made the playoffs, he made it count - especially against the Patriots. Not only did he ruin the Pats' dreams in Super Bowl XLII - he did so again four years later in Super Bowl XLVI. These games weren't flukes: Coughlin has a 5-2 lifetime winning record against Darth Belichick.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Tom the Uniter By beating the Pats, Coughlin won Jets fans' love

author: Mark Cunningham
summary: Which doesn't change the ugly fact that nothing the president has proposed - not the trivial gun-control actions he announced in that speech, nor anything else he's put on the table in all his years in office - would have prevented Sandy Hook, or any of the other mass shootings of the [Obama] years. The only gun-law move that would put a serious dent in these deaths is mass confiscation (mandatory buyback, whatever). That's so far out of political reach that Obama feels compelled to talk about "gun safety" rather than "gun control." Yes, mass shootings seem to be up in recent years - but only slightly, if you set aside gang crime (which most folks don't think of in connection with Sandy Hook and so on). But we've had no changes in gun laws to explain that rise; you're better off blaming the advent of 24/7 news, or the Internet. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner.
