author: Mike Puma
summary: "Obviously I have a special place in New York City with these fans and they have done nothing but embrace me and honor me," [Mike Piazza] said. "We'll make it official [Thursday]." Tom Seaver is the only Hall of Famer wearing a Mets cap on his plaque. The inclusion of Piazza on the list likely will spur the Mets to retire his No. 31. "Without a doubt Mike Piazza was one of the top hitting catchers in the history of the game," Seaver said in a statement released by the Mets. "For Mike to compile the stats he did while catching is amazing. His election to Cooperstown is most deserving." Piazza's Hall of Fame chances his first three years on the ballot may have been dampened by rumors he used performance-enhancing drugs. "So may of those things are just out of my control," he said. "It's just something I can't worry about." Piazza established a record with 396 home runs hit as a catcher. Over his 16-year major league career, Piazza hit 427 homers with 1,335 RBIs and a .308 batting average. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: IN EXCLUSIVE COMPANY * Piazza going to Cooperstown * Joins Seaver as Mets in Hall

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: Perhaps this closes the ethereal wound that [Donald Grant] opened almost 40 years ago when he not only sent [Tom Seaver] to Cincinnati but antagonized his own fan base in a way that even the Mets' current caretakers have never done. [Mike Piazza] never won a championship here. For some, he will always be L.A. because he came up a Dodger, because his very best years were played out in Chavez Ravine, not by Flushing Bay. In recent years, all three times his name was entered into nomination for the Hall of Fame - and all three times he fell short - Mets fans were united in both disappointment and anger, emotions that not just every former player brings out in their former towns. And the joy that manifested on social media Wednesday ... Well, put it this way: It's been a hell of a year to be a Mets fan. On a day when Seaver's record vote total was at last surpassed by Ken Griffey Jr., he was at last joined in Cooperstown by another Met. He'll take the trade-off. Mets fans certainly will. Grant's Womb is officially closed. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: IN EXCLUSIVE COMPANY Franchise finally has its own position of strength

author: Mike Puma
summary: "To have the highest percentage is a shock, because I don't think that way," Griffey said. "The big thing is to get into the Hall of Fame. I was really surprised by the total." [Mike Piazza], in his fourth year on the ballot, received 83 percent of the vote. Candidates need to receive at least 75 percent of the votes cast by the Baseball Writers' Association of America for election to the Hall of Fame. "That decision is not left to me," Griffey "That decision is for [voters]." Griffey said he is so superstitious he has never set foot in the Hall of Fame, despite three times venturing to Cooperstown. "I have played in the Hall of Fame game three times and never set foot in the building," Griffey said. "The first time I walk in there I wanted to go in as a member."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Nearly perfect player Griffey 3 votes from unanimous, breaks Seaver's HOF record

author: Ken Davidoff
summary: [Mike Piazza] is inducted before proven guilty, and that's the way it should be. It's the guiding principle of our society, isn't it? That it took Piazza four years on the ballot before getting his due will be forgotten soon enough. Though our collective obsession with the illegal performance-enhancing drug guessing game will take longer to shake off, Piazza's triumph marks progress. "Fans understand there's no flawless institution," he said. "We all make mistakes as far as...We all need to understand that the game is healed and they've addressed the issue and we're moving on and being as positive as can be." It didn't quite match his written denial in his 2014 autobiography, "Long Shot." However, suspicion alone, no matter how reasonable- or, as Piazza put it, "these things" -shouldn't suffice in meeting the burden necessary to keep Piazza out of Cooperstown. I've heard the argument: "You're not determining his freedom, you're just deciding whether to honor him. You don't need to go all the way beyond reasonable doubt." Nope, not buying it. Let's not downplay this: Piazza experienced a life-changing event Wednesday. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: WHISPERS TO CHEERS Forget the rumors: Without proof, Piazza truly deserving

author: Kevin Kernan
summary: "[Michael] appreciates everything [Tommy Lasorda] did for him," [Vince Piazza] said. As for the Mets, Vince said, "I'm hoping Michael remains a Met forever."  "Thank God he's in. It's like a miracle. The hell Michael went through, the criticisms he took, the way they ripped him. He took the high road and, God, it's paid off. He's just one hell of a kid. He's finally getting the due he deserves, now they are talking about his abilities and what he's accomplished." Making the story more remarkable is that Vince has made an incredible recovery from a stroke and can't wait to make the trip to Cooperstown in July. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: Dad: He went through hell to get to Hall

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: There is no proven candidate who can inject the credibility that [Tom Coughlin] takes with him. The Giants hope [Ben McAdoo] or Adam Gase or Sean McDermott or [Doug Marrone] or someone else can forge a new direction and make a contribution close to Coughlin's.  [John Mara] said it as clearly as possible: "[Jerry Reese] knows this is on him." Reese must do what he has not done often enough - select quality players capable of cracking the lineup in this draft. With the No. 10 pick, find another star to make a splash like Odell Beckham Jr. (No. 12 in 2014). No more second-round stiffs like Clint Sintim or Marvin Austin; or third-round busts such as Ramses Barden, Travis Beckum, Jerrel Jernigan, Jayron Hosley or Damontre Moore; or fourth-round washouts similar to Bryan Kehl, Phillip Dillard, James Brewer, Adrien Robinson and Brandon Mosley. Figure out the injury mess: The Giants finished with 22 players on injured reserve, a third consecutive season with injuries ravaging their roster. No one can accuse Coughlin of being too hard on his players - they had "recovery day" Fridays, for goodness sakes. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: Handful of offseason issues 5 things Big Blue must do to get back on track

summary: If you don't get him, he's gonna be one next year, I promise you." summary: Packers at Cardinals: You can rest assured Bruce Arians read the riot act after the Cardinals' ghastly Week 17 no-show against the Seahawks. The same pass rush that sacked [Aaron Rodgers] eight times and returned two of his fumbles for touchdowns in a 38-8 obliteration on Dec. 27 will again rattle Rodgers, who will be rendered a one-dimensional quarterback. Patrick Peterson will keep Randall Cobb under control. [David Johnson], meet [Luke Kuechly]. Luke Kuechly, meet David Johnson. And while that's happening, Palmer spreads the ball around to Larry Fitzgerald, John Brown and Michael Floyd. Getting shredded by [Russell Wilson] in the regular-season finale helps Cardinals defensive coordinator James Bettcher prepare for Newton. When it's over, Palmer and Fitzgerald are dabbing - they're finally going to a Super Bowl. Cardinals-Patriots (in Santa Clara, Calif.): Star Wars: [Tom Brady], Gronk and [Julian Edelman] on one side, Palmer, Brown, Floyd, Fitzgerald and Johnson on the other side. Brady has endured too much to fail now. Arians decides to throw from the Patriots' 1-yard line instead of handing off to Johnson. Malcolm Butler intercepts. One for the thumb. One more Lombardi Trophy Roger Goodell is forced to hand to Brady. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Brian Lewis
summary: "I want [[Shane Larkin]] to go in, direct the team, push the ball, get up and guard guys in the backcourt as they're bringing the ball up court," said coach Lionel Hollins, who admitted Larkin wasn't comfortable running the whole playbook yet. "That's what he was doing off the bench, that's what I want him to do now that he's starting. "You'd expect these guys to all know the plays, but guys that don't start or play a lot of minutes tend to not get as many reps," said Hollins. "But him getting more reps at practice, it just naturally happens. I think [Larkin] knows the plays, but he's not comfortable in calling them, knowing what we're doing. But it'll come." "[It's] just honing in on what guys like. I know what [Bogdanovic] likes, I know what [Wayne Ellington] likes. I know how to get Joe [Johnson] going. I kind of know what Brook likes, I've just got to get it to him and get out of the way. Just thinking about that coming up the court, I've kind of figured that much out. Now it's actual game stuff, getting those minutes with those guys is the next thing to take that leap." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Lewis
summary: "There's a lot of stuff we have to tweak. We had a lot of turnovers. Right now we're just out of sync as far as running our stuff and executing," said Thaddeus Young, held to 11 points on 5-of-13 shooting. "With [Jarrett] going down, that's definitely tough for us because that's our starting point guard. ... They tried to get into us, run us out of our sets, and did a pretty good job. "Just practice, try to jam it into guys' heads this is what we need to do, this is the stuff we need to run, this is who we need to get the ball to and this is the way we should execute. ... Right now it's tough when your No. 1 guy goes down that's making everything happen for the team, and you have to get guys to step in and fill in. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't right off the bat." "I've just got to make sure everybody's in the right spots whenever we're in a set, make sure my team executes," said [Shane Larkin]. summary: "I think we know what Carmelo is to us," [Jose Calderon] said before the Knicks faced the Heat Wednesday. "The play was to get the ball back to him, but he wasn't there. Give credit to the defense. We kept moving the ball and [Robin Lopez] was open. We keep building on that trust with each other. But we know Carmelo's our guy. When we put the ball in his hands, we're comfortable. "That's generally how end-of-game situations happen," [Fisher] said of the Lopez-to-Calderon late hoop. "You draw things up that may or may not work. It's important for players to respond on what happens next. The first, second option is taken away. Robin flashed into the lane, received the ball and still kept his vision. Jose made a back cut, and we were able to finish the game off." "I don't know if it's a new normal [for Melo] statistically, but I do think because he's healthy, he's enjoying trying to play the game, allowing space for teammates to try to find their games," Fisher said. author: Dana Schuster
summary: Hoarding has become part of modern conversation thanks to shows like TLC's "Hoarding: Buried Alive." But few people have experienced the crippling behavior firsthand. Chelsea resident Judy Batalion, 38, tells The Post's Dana Schuster about how growing up with a hoarder for a mother led to a messy childhood and perfection-seeking adulthood, which she explores in her new memoir, "White Walls: A Memoir About Motherhood, Daughterhood, and the Mess In Between" (New American Library, out now). Early on, my father tried to throw things out, but it was endless and he eventually gave up - and I could see why. Sometimes I would try to vacuum and I'd get in trouble. "Don't touch anything," she'd say. "It's not your job." While away at school, my grandmother, Bubbie Zelda, who also suffered from hoarding, passed away. It was then that my mother's behavior turned pathological. She refused to leave the house, convinced she was being spied on. "They're after me," she'd say. "They're going to take the houses, everything." Her body turned larger, grayer, sweatier. And then, there were the suicide threats. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: MY HOARDER MOM MADE ME A NEAT FREAK After growing up amid her mother's piles of trash,a woman struggles with her own perfectionism

summary: In New York, hay can be sold at upstate auctions for up to $150 per bail, farming experts said. Unlike livestock, farmers don't tend to tag or brand hay, making it difficult for police to tell when it has been stolen, said Brian Waddingham, who runs a farming coalition in Iowa, where hay theft is rampant. "I can see why it's attractive to a thief in New York. Anyone can load hay onto a truck in 20 minutes, drive it 50 miles and sell it at an auction - and nobody can prove it's not theirs," he said. -Making 'bale': Police quizzing alleged hay stealers (below) hope they'll provide leads in the murder of mansion matriarch [Lois Colley] (inset). They're more prideful and take this job more seriously than people think," [Derek Fisher] said. I just think the guys are beginning to feel like we can be as good as anyone when we bring the right effort, the right mindset." The Knicks have already gained their landmark wins on this three game trip, surpassing last season's win total Wednesday with victory No. 18. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: [Adam Gase] earlier in the week impressed the Eagles in a sit-down that lasted a reported eight hours and they are already considering bringing him in for a second interview this weekend. The Dolphins and Browns are also on the Gase trail. Gase interviewed Thursday in Miami. Gase does not have any ties to the Giants, but he was the offensive coordinator the past three years for John Fox, in Denver and then Chicago, and the Giants can get all the inside information they need from Fox, a former Giants defensive coordinator and a coach Giants ownership greatly respects. Whoever he's worked with he's found ways to manage the system and make them successful." If the interview with Gase goes well, the Giants will have an interesting challenge differentiating him from [Ben McAdoo]. Gase and McAdoo, 38, are young offensive gurus linked to success with quarterbacks (Aaron Rodgers swears by McAdoo and Eli Manning is a devotee). "It's the hardest thing for me to fathom, I'm trying to get my arms around a person who had five interviews last year, didn't get a job, was fired, was [Peyton Manning]'s guy in Denver and never asked to stay, and on top of it, is coming off a 6-10 team that ranked 21st in offense," an NFL source said. "I don't get the 'hot' part. And he's very young. He couldn't get hired off of 12-4 and 13-3, how are you going to get hired off of 6-10? I don't get the 'hot' part. If that's hot I'd hate to see cold."Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: WHICH WAY WILL THEY 'O'? Giants' search could come down to Gase vs. McAdoo

author: Brian Costello
summary: The two young receivers from Clemson are precisely the type of receivers that give [Darrelle Revis] trouble and can beat him deep. They are quick receivers with great change-of-direction skills. This is a matchup problem for Revis. When Revis is up against a bigger receiver like Dez Bryant or Calvin Johnson, his physicality can still neutralize them. It is a fair question, but Revis' impact on the Jets cannot be measured simply by what he does on the field. The Jets desperately needed credibility when they signed Revis, and he instantly gave it to them. They had a star on the team again. He also fixed a position that had become a black hole on the team in 2014, John Idzik's final year as general manager. Falcons special teams coordinator Keith Armstrong is believed to be the front-runner to replace Bobby April with the Jets in the same role. Armstrong and Jets coach Todd Bowles were teammates at Temple. The Jets requested permission to interview Armstrong last year, but were denied. author: Hondo
summary: GM Jerry Reese, who survived the Giants' fourth straight playoff-less season, made a point of saying Tuesday he wasn't alone in assembling the team's weak roster. "Our coaching staff is involved, our personnel staff is involved, everybody's involved." That's funny; he never mentioned the collaborative process when the brilliance of drafting Odell Beckham Jr. was mentioned repeatedly. Hillary Clinton says she has adopted a New Year's resolution: "I'm going to let [Trump] live in his alternative reality and I'm not going to respond." Besides, The Portly Pantsuit already has her own "alternative reality," one that includes dodging sniper fire, making a killing as a first-time cattle futures investor, being dead broke when she and Bill left the White House and vast right-wing conspiracies. Donald Trump says Ted Cruz's citizenship could be "a very precarious issue for Republicans" if the Texas senator were to get the nomination. Maybe, but what about El Donaldo's citizenship? Sure, he was born in Queens, but where is that hosed-down hay field on top of his head from? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Dave Blezow
summary: THE Steelers suffered so many quarterback injuries this season - Ben Roethlisberger, Michael Vick, Landry Jones all were KO'd from the lineup at some point - that it's amazing that come Saturday night, they will have Big Ben in their lineup and the Bengals won't have Andy Dalton in theirs. The Chiefs also have a big edge in experience in key spots. Alex Smith has played three playoff games - he's 1-2, but has nine touchdowns and no interceptions, and had 407 yards in the memorable 49ers' 36-32 wild-card win over the Saints a few years back. And Andy Reid is 10-10 in his playoff career. The Texans' Brian Hoyer and Bill O'Brien make their first playoff appearances. The 'Skins finished the season on a four-game winning streak, scoring 35, 38 and 34 in the last three. They were 6-2 at home. The Packers lost their last two, outscored 58-21, with Aaron Rodgers getting sacked 13 times. It's concerning that they couldn't muster a better effort at home versus the Vikings with the NFC North title on the line. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Howie Kussoy
summary: "[They're] the nicest people in the world - the lady, who is elderly, puts her hand on my shoulder and says, 'Maybe we'll win next year,' " [Nick Saban] said this summer while discussing the expectations of the program. "So, you think we can have a bad season at Alabama?" It's easy to forget, but so many coaches failed before Saban arrived from the Miami Dolphins in 2007, with the previous decade featuring five coaches and four losing seasons. It's easy to forget the bridge from Paul "Bear" Bryant to Saban was littered with so many forgotten seasons, that the fallen power only again became an annual front-runner after Saban broke a 17-year title drought in 2009. Prior to that, the school had won just one championship in the previous 29 years. "Whatever has been accomplished in the past certainly doesn't have anything to do with what the future holds. This team has done a particularly good job of sort of having the kind of competitive character and want-to that you like to see in a team. They've worked really hard to improve, and they've always competed well whenever challenged." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: "If you stay out of third-and longs, that gives you a chance," [Dan Werner] said. "If you're having to throw, 10-, 15-yard routes down the field, when they know it's going to be a pass - they got a great scheme that messes with your protections and they have athletes that can get to the quarterback fast - it's going to be difficult." With all that said, it will be difficult for Clemson to be successful. "The thing that we've done that a lot of people are starting to move to is spreading people out," Werner said. "When you play someone like Alabama-so big, so physical, so athletic-the only chance I think is to spread them out, make them make plays in space." Werner said he thinks Clemson quarterback Deshaun Watson can be successful using his legs - not by going straight at Alabama, but with misdirection, designed draw plays and play actions keepers. author: Michael Riedel,On Broadway
summary: In the '70s, [Robert Stigwood], who was born in Adelaide, Australia, was everywhere. His entertainment empire, the Robert Stigwood Organization (and label, RSO Records), stretched from London to New York to Los Angeles and encompassed theater ("Jesus Christ Superstar," "Evita"), music (the Bee Gees, Cream) and movies ("Saturday Night Fever," "Grease"). Like all great impresarios, he was the master of the publicity stunt. Before "Evita" opened on Broadway, Stigwood learned that "Superman II" was being filmed. He made sure a big "Evita" ad appeared on one of the prop buses in the movie. "I remember meeting him once at 7:30 in the morning, and he was drinking a beer," says [Andrew Lloyd Webber]. "I said, 'Really, Robert, don't you think it's a bit early?' And he said, 'It's for the vitamin B.' " Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: George Willis
summary: "I learned a lot from [Bill Belichick]. No doubt about it," O'[Brien] said this week. "One thing I learn is you really can't leave any stone unturned. For instance, if you're getting ready for a regular-season game you may look at the last three or four games, or maybe you go back and look at a common opponent. But in this instance, you're looking at all the games. You're looking at all the snaps. You're looking for any edge that you can find to try to put your players in the best position to make plays." O'Brien was an assistant coach on Belichick's staff from 2007-11. Texans defensive coordinator Romeo Crennel was a long-time assistant under Belichick and Texans defensive tackle Vince Wilfork was the anchor for the Patriots' defensive line before signing with the Texans this season. That's why the playoffs feel like home even though the Texans are starving for postseason success as a franchise, having gone 1-1 during both the 2011 and 2012 seasons. "We've got a lot of guys on the coaching staff that have been in this position," O'Brien said. "We've been here before. It's not necessarily new to us, even though some of us haven't been here in a couple of years. We know what's at stake and we know how to prepare." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: O'Brien learns from experience under Patriots' Belichick

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: On Friday, Adam Gase met with [John Mara] and [Jerry Reese], the fourth candidate interviewed for the head-coaching vacancy created when the Giants decided to part ways with Tom Coughlin. The Giants' two coordinators, [Ben McAdoo] (offense) and Steve Spagnuolo (defense), were the first two interviews, followed by Teryl Austin, the Lions' defensive coordinator. Hopefully for the Giants, they were not blown away with Gase, this year's hot head-coach prospect, because there is a good chance he soon will be unavailable. Before talking to the Giants, he interviewed with the Browns, Eagles and Dolphins and Miami quickly set up a second interview with Gase for Saturday, according to multiple reports. Word in Miami is that Dolphins owner Stephen Ross wants Gase and a deal could come quickly. "I think he's a mastermind of a coach," [Rolle] said this week on WFAN. "He's very, very smart. He has that grit, that fire that you need, but he definitely has the balance. I've seen him get fired up a couple of times but a lot of times he's very calm and relaxed. He's a thinker. author: Howie Kussoy
summary: [Dabo Swinney], 46, was born in Birmingham and raised in Pelham, roughly an hour away from the campus where his idol, Paul "Bear" Bryant, made national championships the norm. Though no one in his family had ever graduated from college, Swinney imagined doing so at Tuscaloosa, where he envisioned playing for Alabama's legendary coach, whose TV show was a Sunday staple for Swinney and his father. "When we left Tuscaloosa, I cried and told Dabo there would never be another place like it," Swinney's wife, Kathleen, told The Post. "But I was wrong." "If you could say, 'Hey, you're going to get a chance to play the National Championship game at some point, who do you want it to be against?' I would pick Alabama, because they're the best," Swinney said. "We want to be the best, so let's go play the best team out there and see if we can get it done and measure up." author: Steve Serby
summary: John Mara and Steve Tisch granting their former coach permission to enter the Eagles' nest is more a classy move and sign of gratitude - it would have reeked of pettiness had they not - than any lack of fear [Tom Coughlin] can come back, at age 70 next season, and haunt them in his next coaching life. Imagine if Ben McAdoo doesn't get the Giants job and decides he doesn't want to stay for a new head coach ... how badly would Eli Manning's lower lip quiver if McAdoo left to cast his lot with Coughlin in Philadelphia? Steve Spagnuolo used to be an Eagle, you might recall. McAdoo already has interviewed for the Eagles job, and it's doubtful he broached Coughlin as his offensive coordinator. Eagles fans would embrace Coughlin the way Vikings fans embraced Brett Favre. Giants fans would have far less enmity for Coughlin than Packers fans had for Favre the traitor. Coughlin never would be reviled the way Pat Riley was when he bolted for Miami. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: That was [Tom Coughlin]'s verbal stiff-arm when anything he didn't want around him dared to veer into his lane. He would respond with a nugget and then immediately, and facetiously, thank the questioner for broaching a subject he wanted no part of discussing. The very last one of his Giants coaching career came during his remarkable final press conference. He responded "Not necessarily" when asked if his coaching career was finished and the natural follow-up, "If the right opportunity came along ..." was cut off by Coughlin. It hit Coughlin hard, learning he was perceived as not respecting the writers covering the Giants - essentially, working men and women doing their jobs. That bothered him. He used to get crazy when injuries became a topic, invariably turning him cranky and unresponsive. Once, I asked him, "Tom, when you sit with your coaching staff and plan practice, do you obsess over who is healthy enough to work and who is not?" He quickly said, "Of course." I responded, "Why can't I?"  "Humble in victory" is a good one. So is another Coughlin go-to line: "Remorse for opportunity lost." His "all-in" that sparked the 2011 Super Bowl run was similar to Pat Riley's "You're either in or you're out" but catchier.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: STEVE SERBY
summary: A: Heck no. He's way nicer than I was, man. He's a class act. I wasn't. I just think he's got a natural leadership about him. I think No. 1, he's a very humble person. He wants to be great. He's very critical of himself. He's a perfectionist, which is very important at the quarterback position. A: [Jon Gruden] and I are different. Jon's a very in-your-face type of guy. I'm more of a laid back-type of guy, but I have the ability to get in your face from time to time. It depends on the situation, really. I don't have a script on how to motivate. I don't have a book that Tuesday, I'm gonna motivate this way; Thursday I'm gonna motivate this way; for the Packer game I'm gonna do this. ... I kind of wait and see the mood of the team, what buttons I feel like I need to push, and that could be different. Sometimes I don't feel like I need to do a big motivational speech, and I don't. I try to adjust my motivational skills when needed, not over-motivate like some people do, because it goes in one ear, out the other. A: I think they're in a good place. I think winning the last four games has really helped. Put out a lot of demons here-you can't do this with the quarterback, you can't block, you can't rush the passer, you can't do this, you can't win on the road-we've done all that. I think the biggest thing that we had to instill in this group, the young guys and the veteran guys alike, is confidence. In order to get that, you gotta win some games. Now we just have to play the biggest games of our lives and play well. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: Saturday just continued a disturbing trend of slow starts for the Nets, outscored by 15, seven, nine and finally 10 points in the first quarter of their games since the calendar flipped. Eventually, the Nets finally found a way to get [Lopez] involved. After he'd had just three shots in the first half, he helped lead a surge in the third. The Nets reeled off nine unanswered points to cut the deficit down to five, and Lopez's conventional three-point play got them within 64-62 with 4:13 left in the third. The Nets never could get over the hump. Detroit built the lead back up, Ilyasova's 3-pointer capping an 8-2 run to make it 72-64. Stanley Johnson drilled an 18-foot jumper to make it 83-70 with eight minutes left, and just like that the deficit swelled to 90-72 on Anthony Tolliver's free throws. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: "You've got to start selling this for more than a dollar a bag! We lost four more men on this expedition!" the exasperated team leader tells the Kwik-E-Marti's manager, Apu, who responds in kind: "If you can think of a better way to get ice, I'd like to hear it." "The Hall of Fame has not seen an issue this pervasive since the Negro Leagues," said John Thorn, Major League Baseball's official historian. That, if you don't know, concerned folks' efforts - with Ted Williams sounding the bugle at his 1966 induction speech - to get deserving Negro League participants into the Hall. The illegal PED hailstorm, to the contrary, has become all about the desire to keep people out of the Hall. That language was wholly ignored until Mark McGwire joined the ballot for 2007. As for the notion that baseball's record book was "destroyed" by anomalistic run-scoring totals, "We call these anomalies because we are present-centered in our view," Thorn said. "Most people who turn up their noses at the possibly PED-boosted stats of the so-called Steroid Era pay no attention to the 1920s and '30s," when factors like segregation, the live ball and the outlawing of the spitball came into play. Like I've been saying all year, as long as we play defense we'll have a chance to win the game and we didn't do it today and it showed," said Whitehead (10 points), who is the Hall's leading scorer this season. summary: That was the news out of President Obama's televised town hall on gun control. He didn't break new ground with what he said, nor did he offer a persuasive rationale for issuing executive orders just because Congress won't do what he wants.  "Why can't your administration see that these restrictions make it harder for me to get a gun?" asked a woman who identified herself as a rape victim. Another woman, the widow of "American Sniper" Chris Kyle, also objected. "I want the hope that I have the right to protect myself," Taya Kyle said. She also challenged the president's rationale, saying: "We are at the lowest murder rate in our country. All-time low of murders. All-time high for gun ownership." Yet neither did he bridge the chasm on the substance of the issue. As the difficult questions and record gun sales show, Obama's approach up to now has been to speak to the choir and try to discredit any other view, creating a backlash instead of support. His fellow officers did all the right things to subdue these criminals," de [Blasio] said. "This is obviously a large group of people in a fight. A DOE spokeswoman said schools "ensure that parents are apprised of all incidents" with a phone call. In November, Mary Bozoyan, a veteran math teacher at William Cullen Bryant HS in Astoria, Queens, told a boy loitering outside her classroom, gesturing to friends, to leave. "He went to backhand my face and stopped short, inches away," Bozoyan recalled. "He said, 'I didn't hit you. You can't do anything.' " She reported the incident to a dean, but was never asked to fill out a report. "These kids don't feel there's any penalty," Bozoyan said. In Cologne, a police report kept under wraps for days described women having to "run a gantlet" of drunken, abusive "Arab and North African" men in the square bounded by the Cologne Cathedral, one of Germany's best-known Christian symbols, and its modernist glass Central Station. author: Michael Riedel
summary: The Nederlanders are going to raise the fabled Palace Theatre 29 feet to create space underneath it for retail. Actually, they prefer the word "elevate" because they don't want any confusion between "raise" and "raze." The Palace will be delicately lifted intact before undergoing a multimillion dollar restoration. So, can you go for a ride in the theater while it's being elevated? "You won't be able to feel it," says [Paul Boardman]. "That's how imperceptible the movement is." One Broadway insider outlines a doomsday scenario: "Why not move all the Broadway theaters over to the Hudson Yards some day, and have nothing but Applebee's and chain stores in Times Square?" he says. "That's the slippery slope we're on." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: Universal Pictures had promised to donate a "portion" of DVD and Blu-ray sales for "Fast & Furious 6" to Walker's Reach Out Worldwide nonprofit in 2014. He died in a November 2013 car crash with pal Roger Rodas. Walker, 40, was a passenger in the Porsche Carrera GT as the two left a Reach Out Worldwide event in California to raise money for the victims of Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines. Walker's brother, Cody Walker, joined the organization as its president in 2014 and received a $50,000 salary. author: Elisabeth Vincentelli
summary: Of all those would-be rivals, Fox's "MADtv" had the healthiest lifespan - 14 years - and on a good night really gave "SNL" a run for its money. Now, The CW is paying tribute to the series with "MADtv's 20th Anniversary Reunion" special, airing Tuesday at 8 p.m. With alums including Jordan Peele and Keegan-Michael Key ("Key & Peele") and Ike Barinholtz ("The Mindy Project"), "MADtv" spawned its share of talent. But rewatching it now, you're stuck by how much the show - which always was balanced along racial and gender lines - pushed the politically correct envelope. "It kills to watch all these 'Real Housewives' go by," [Nicole Parker] says. "And Lady Gaga and Katy Perry - I would have been all over them." She laughs. "It's painful!"Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Brian Lewis
summary: "After careful consideration, I've concluded that it's time for a fresh start and a new vision for the direction of the team," owner Mikhail Prokhorov said in a statement. "By making this decision now, it enables our organization to use the rest of the season to diligently evaluate candidates with proven track records. It's clear from our current state of affairs that we need new leadership." "With the right basketball management and coach in place, we are going to create a winning culture and identity and give Brooklyn a team that it can be proud of and enjoy watching," Prokhorov, who will speak during a press conference at 10 a.m. on Monday on YES, said. "We have learned a great deal during the past six years and our experiences will guide us for the future. Following the consolidation of team ownership last month, I can assure you that I'm more determined and committed than ever to build a winner." [Joe Johnson] is the only one left with the Nets, who don't have their own first-round pick until 2019. They're talent-poor with little hope, except for $40 million in cap space to spend this summer. It turns out King won't be the one entrusted with using it, with ESPN reporting Prokhorov has been subtly reaching out to other teams' front-office execs for weeks to gauge their interest in the GM job. author: ZACH BRAZILLER
summary: Deshaun Watson, college football's premier dual-threat quarterback, against the Alabama front seven, the best pass rush in the sport, has all the makings of an epic matchup. It's so intriguing, maybe they should push it back to New Year's Eve. The Crimson Tide didn't allow a quarterback to run for more than 29 yards this season in a particular game, but they didn't face anyone with the skill set or explosion of Watson, who ran for 1,032 yards and 12 touchdowns while throwing for 31 scores and completing 68.2 percent of his passes. Clemson will push the pace, hoping to limit the substitutions the ridiculously deep Alabama defense likes to make to stay fresh, and hope to be productive enough on the ground - the Tigers have averaged 229 rushing yards per game this year - to keep the Crimson Tide defensive front honest. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: INSIDE THE MATCHUPS

author: HOWIE KUSSOY
summary: "We probably won't win if he doesn't play well," Clemson coach Dabo Swinney said. "You don't win championships without your best players showing up and getting locked in and performing." On this stage, Nick Saban's teams always perform at their best. The Crimson Tide coach, undefeated in national championships games, is in position to win his fifth national title, which would place him alongside Alabama legend Paul "Bear" Bryant as the only college coaches to ever win that many. "Everybody knows they're good," [Deshaun Watson] said. "But we're good on offense, too." Good will not suffice against a team so dominant it maintains its invincibility despite already losing this season, against a defense that hasn't allowed a quarterback to rush for more than 30 yards this season and hasn't allowed a quarterback to run for more than 100 yards since Saban arrived in 2007. "People don't like us at all," [Reggie Ragland] said. "People talk all the time, 'We can't stop a mobile quarterback,' [but] we don't listen to them. ... When the game hits, that's the time to show them, to prove them wrong." Once again, Alabama may prove that defense wins championships. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: "I am having a dominant year. I do my job better than anybody else in the country," said Mackensie Alexander, Clemson's loquacious cornerback. "It's basically what they do with [Darrelle Revis]."  "He's in there as much as I'm watching it," Clemson defensive backs coach Mike Reed said with a laugh. "If I'm not in my office, he's in my office. Five minutes after a game, he's watching film.  "If you're thinking, you're stinking. He doesn't think a lot, he plays. Watching a lot of film allows you to just react." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: George Willis
summary: "We want to be a program that is competing at this level on a consistent basis," [Dabo Swinney] said. "I think to do that you've got to be a top-10, top-15 type program year in and year out. That's the thing that I'm most proud of with our program because only us and Alabama have had five 10-plus win seasons in a row. That's the type of consistency that you have to have and the type of culture that you have to establish in your program to have this opportunity. This is the culmination of seven years of a lot of consistency. Hopefully, this won't be our [only] time. Hopefully, we can be back. I don't know if we can make it four out of the next seven years. But it won't be for a lack of effort." "He's already won four national championships," Swinney said. "This is the first one I've sniffed as a coach and he's going for his fifth. It's incredible. People sometimes will say, 'Anybody can go win at Alabama'. Well, no, that's not the case. Not everybody can coach a great team. Not everybody can coach a great player and I think that he has a gift to be able to do that." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: We've got next Dabo, Clemson after Alabama's throne

summary: "I hate to jump to conclusions, or jump ahead. Let me just gather the information," Chiefs coach Andy Reid said. "It's not just down to his physical talents. He rubs off on everybody," [Alex Smith] said, "the competitor he is, what he brings on game day, that energy. Everybody kind of feeds off that. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: Even though Giants co-owner John Mara promised the search for a new head coach would be "extensive," it stands to reason that if he were sold on Ben McAdoo he already would have elevated the team's offensive coordinator into the job that for the past 12 years belonged to Tom Coughlin. How so? Coughlin was 57 when he was hired by the Giants in 2004. [Mike Smith] is 56. Coughlin rose in the coaching ranks with a highly successful stay in Jacksonville, going 45-19 in a four-year stretch and advancing to the AFC Championship game twice with an expansion team. Smith, in his first five years with the Falcons, went 56-24, won two division titles, made the playoffs four times and advanced to one NFC Championship game. "That had a big influence on me when we hired Tom back in 2004," Mara said last week on ESPN New York radio. "Here was a guy who had incredible energy and who really had something to prove. He had been fired in Jacksonville after two or three straight losing seasons and you could tell he wanted to come back and prove to everybody he was a great head coach, and sure enough he did that." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: It's deja vu Next up for Giants: Coughlin clone Smith

author: Phil Mushnick
summary: In other words, unless [Tom Coughlin] had lost his senses, 50 years in the forming, to the forces of pop culture, we knew that his defense of Odell Beckham Jr. after Beckham decided he was the only man who mattered during that cataclysmic loss to Carolina - an obscenity topped Saturday night before, then throughout Steelers versus Bengals (FOX's Joe Buck, during Sunday's Packers-Redskins, briefly but wisely tethered both significant "games," 21 days apart, as outstandingly senseless) - was hollow and pathetic. Coughlin had to have been sickened by Beckham's behavior as both defended team-defeating behavior with the illogical rationalizations of modernity. In response, how many players would declare, "I could never play for the Giants; I'm too selfish." Or, "I play too dirty; I'm too undisciplined for them." Wouldn't it be better to know before than too late? In [Mike Piazza]'s case, a steroid shadow must exist because sluggers of his era are as they should be: Guilty until proven innocent. That's not our fault; that's MLB's fault starting with "Bottom Line" Bud Selig, the anything-for-a-buck team owners from whom he exchanged winks, nods and revenue, and their equally greed-driven, "adversaries" (mutually silent partners), Donald Fehr's MLBPA. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Chump change Coughlin, Piazza corrupted by their eras

summary: Yet, not until a few seconds were left in the game - game? It resembled an elimination round among Cossacks - did [Phil Simms], just above a whisper, say we were witnessing "a disgrace." Moments earlier, after dehumanized Vontaze Burfict's late, near-criminal head-shot to Antonio Brown was shown in a replay, [Jim Nantz] managed a soft, "Oh, my goodness." In a playoff game, the best Simms could muster about this was, "That's a bad play." A bad play? Peko wasn't even in the game to make any kind of play! It was insane! author: Ken Davidoff
summary: The populism tied into Cespedes concerns more than just the skills of the free-agent outfielder himself. Cespedes, the face of [Sandy Alderson]'s late July 2015 makeover, predictably has become a litmus test for the Mets' fiscal flexibility. Their World Series appearance notwithstanding, the Mets still face a considerable trust deficit with their fan base in the wake of everything that has transpired since Bernard Madoff's December 2008 arrest. So when Alderson pointed out Thursday that the Mets' payroll stood at $85 million at the end of 2014 and could shoot up to the $115-to-$120 million range by Opening Day, that didn't land smoothly in the hearts or brains of longtime fans who could counter that Alderson's first Mets team, in 2011, carried a payroll surpassing $140 million. And these Mets, by virtue of the revenues generated by their deep postseason run, not to mention Michael Cuddyer's retirement, should have been able to increase their expenditures significantly from the $110 million neighborhood where they concluded last year. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Mr. unpopular Sandy's quiet offseason strategy not fans' favorite

author: Dan Martin
summary: "It was definitely an intense game, a game we wanted, but it's in the past," [Henrik Lundqvist] said after the team practiced in Tarrytown on Sunday. "You have to focus on your game. That's the most important thing right now: For me try to stop the puck, not focus too much on them or what they're doing. It's about us and what we need to do." "It's unfortunate I came out of it with an injury that had me sit out for a month, but I don't look back at it as anything other than a hockey play," [Derek Stepan] said. "We don't have any time to worry about things that happened in the past, especially a hit like that. Our focus needs to be on the two points we desperately need going forward here." "It's in the past now," Lundqvist said. "Let's move on. Hopefully it's a good hockey game." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: Power & Motor Yacht magazine is all about profiling the latest models - just right for the Powerball man or woman in you. A feature titled "Prime Mover" describes the MJM 50z, yours for $2.1 million. A test drive at 34 knots (40 mph) shows the comfort, and the galley and saloon area is "pleasant." (Our kind of pleasant, that is.) Interested in the new Bertram 35? Yes, it is styled after the Moppie (for those in the nautical know). Electronics that can improve the angler's day is one of the short features, and fishing can be so much easier when you're driving a boat that costs more than most houses. Town & Country is old money, so if that's your style, pick up a copy. The current issue includes jewelry suggestions for Florida snowbirds, including a Wendy Yue ring for $11,900. Former top British diplomat David Miliband speaks about how he spends his time resettling European refugees. As expected, the Ivanka Trump cover story is much more style than substance, with page-length pictures of The Donald's very pregnant 34-year-old daughter, including her standing elegantly in a dress, and seated fashionably on a couch while doing work. She says she is not part of her father's presidential campaign, and when asked if she might eventually enter politics, she coyly replies, "Who knows?" While Ivanka is very busy being married and running her dad's business empire, single ladies of similar wealth are sure to enjoy the mag's list of 50 top bachelors, with Google's Sergey Brin ranking No. 1. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Andrea Morabito
summary: "I was on a steady diet of 'Airplane' for about 10 years as a kid. That's sort of how I learned to laugh," [Rashida Jones] tells The Post. "The fact that anybody's even attempting this genre of comedy was so exciting for me." In addition to Jones ("Parks and Recreation, "The Office") as the titular Tribeca, the cast includes Hayes MacArthur as her optimistic partner, Jere Burns as their indignant squad captain, Dean Cole as a detective with a canine partner and Andre Vermeulen as the requisite quirky medical examiner. Episodes find the squad investigating "serious" cases like the murder of a ventriloquist and a rash of baker suicides. "The most important thing is that I don't point to a joke," Jones says. "I'm on a serious case, and if there happens to be a dog driving a car during that case, that's not my problem." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Mara will be in Houston the next two days for an NFL owners' meeting to discuss the relocation of teams to Los Angeles, meaning the Giants' interviews are on hiatus.  56-24, two NFC South division titles, four playoff berths, three Sporting News Coach of the Year awards. [Mike Smith]'s postseason failures are his rsum's greatest blemish: a record of 1-4, including a 24-2 loss to the Giants in a 2011 NFC wild-card game. Smith's best chance for a Super Bowl came in 2012, when the Falcons reached the NFC Championship game. Playing in Atlanta, the Falcons raced to a 17-0 lead early in the second quarter but did not score a point in the second half and lost to the 49ers, 28-24. The 17-point lead was the largest ever blown in an NFC title game. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: George Willis
summary: Still, Kelly's demise in Philadelphia shouldn't scare the NFL away from looking at the college ranks for head coaches. Nick Saban led the Alabama Crimson Tide against Dabo Swinney's Clemson Tigers for the College Football National Championship on Monday night at the University of Phoenix Stadium, and if both coaches weren't on the short list of every NFL team with a vacancy, then the short list needs to be expanded. Iowa coach Kirk Ferentz was an offensive line coach with the Browns and Ravens before becoming the Hawkeyes' head coach in 1999. They are quality college coaches with experience in the NFL. Notre Dame's Brian Kelly and Michigan State's Mark Dantonio are two others who could be on an NFL sidelines someday soon. The trouble college coaches have in moving to the NFL is they are accustomed to having full autonomy over their programs and often don't see eye to eye with general managers. It's easier to be king and dictator in college than in the NFL. But that doesn't always work in the NFL; Kelly was given full authority over football operations in Philadelphia and see how it ended. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: NFL should comb college sidelines for next coaches

author: HOWIE KUSSOY
summary: "I thought, well, I probably won't get a head-coaching job, but it will be easy to get an offensive coordinator job," [Lane Kiffin] said before last year's College Football Playoff, having been fired at USC during the 2013 season. "The phone wasn't ringing. ... In this profession, you can be really hot one minute and the next be unemployed." That is when Nick Saban called, the Alabama coach who had won three of the previous f ive national championships. That is when the 62-year-old no nonsense coach-who first offered Kiffin the position of offensive coordinator at Alabama in 2007 - took an even greater chance on a talented, but volatile and divisive young play-caller who burned every bridge he touched. "I think it's worked out as good as it can. I knew what I was getting into as far as I'm going here to learn from the best coach in college football, but I didn't really know I would learn as much as I did." Since arriving last season, Kiffin has only strengthened Saban's case as one of the best coaches ever, helping Alabama to back-to-back College Football Playoff appearances, while utilizing an up-tempo offense guided by two first-time starting quarterbacks - Blake Sims and Jake Coker. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: REVIVE & ADVANCE Resurrecting rep in Bama, Kiffin could get another chance to be head coach

author: HOWIE KUSSOY
summary: "When it comes to competing and making plays when we needed to make them, it was probably as good as it gets," Saban said. "I think that's the kind of competitors that win championships, and that's probably why we're sitting here." Tigers quarterback Deshaun Watson did all that was humanly possible, throwing for 405 yards and four touchdowns, while adding 73 yards on the ground, but Alabama's special teams saved the day, with Kenyan Drake's 95-yard kick return with 7:31 left in the fourth quarter giving the Crimson Tide a double digit cushion. "He's really done a great job for us all year in whatever his role has been," [Nick Saban] said of Drake. "I always like to see guys that are seniors who have been great contributors in the program do something special that's going to be a great memory to them, and that kickoff return was really something special." Though Alabama scored the game's first touchdown midway through the first quarter - [Derrick Henry] rumbled through a massive hole up the middle to run 50 yards untouched, marking his 20th straight game with a touchdown - Watson tied the game less than three minutes later, hitting former walk on Hunter Renfrow with a perfectly placed ball between two defenders for a 31-yard touchdown. "Coach Saban asked if I felt like doing it [and] I said, 'Sure,' " [Adam Griffith] said. "I think it was perfect timing.... That one was perfect." When Clemson cut the deficit to 38-33 with less than five minutes to play, [Howard] again broke free, hauling in a 63-yard strike to set up a 1-yard touchdown run from Henry with 1:07 remaining. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: TIDE & JOY Onside kick sparks Crimson over Clemson for Saban's fifth crown

But at the end of the day, I love my teammates, love my brothers, and you'll see us in [the national championship in] Tampa next year." "It will be motivation. I got to come back next year." "[Deshaun Watson] is the best player in the country," [Dabo Swinney] said after Watson ran for 145 yards and a touchdown and completed 16-of-31 passes for 187 yards and another score in a 37-17 victory over Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl on New Year's Eve. author: George Willis
summary: "Special teams had a lot to do with this win," Alabama coach Nick Saban said. "The onside kick sort of changed the momentum of the game. It was a great team win." Considering the scholarship limitations of this era, the balance of talent and the fact college football is more inclusive than in much of [Paul "Bear" Bryant]'s era, what Saban has done is remarkable to say the least. Whatever Saban's legacy winds up being, it will include his gamble on the onside kick. He called for it after Alabama tied the game 24-24 on a 33-yard field goal by Adam Griffith with 10:34 left in the game. "I made the decision to do it because we were tired on defense and weren't doing a good job of getting them stopped," Saban said. "I felt like if we didn't do something to change the momentum of the game we wouldn't have a chance to win." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Lewis
summary: "Coach Cal is a great coach," [Mikhail Prokhorov] said. "But we won't be discussing any names. I'm not in a hurry. We'll put a lot of names in the list. As soon as we're ready, as soon as deal is fixed, you will be the first to know." "I take full responsibility for the state of the team and I think Billy King did his best," said Prokhorov. "We need a fresh look. We should be able to take courage to turn down the opportunities, which maybe don't fit to our strategy. Maybe this is the second lesson from the last six years." "We're playing in the best market in the world and of course this is a market which makes a great pressure. That's why we need a players and a coach who can resist this pressure and survive. We need not only players who want to play for us, but they can play for us," said Prokhorov, adding in an interview with the YES Network, "Moscow and New York are like sister & brother: This is the same pressure. We need more tougher players." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

"I take full responsibility for the state of the team and I think Billy King did his best," said Prokhorov. "We need a fresh look. We should be able to take courage to turn down the opportunities, which maybe don't fit to our strategy. Maybe this is the second lesson from the last six years." "We're playing in the best market in the world and of course this is a market which makes a great pressure. That's why we need a players and a coach who can resist this pressure and survive. We need not only players who want to play for us, but they can play for us," said Prokhorov, adding in an interview with the YES Network, "Moscow and New York are like sister and brother: This is the same pressure. We need more tougher players." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

"If the leader of our team, the best scorer, is passing the ball and wants to do better for the team and help the team, if you're not him you can't not be doing the same thing. You've got to follow him and play the same way." "That's the key with the system, everybody is passing the ball, everybody is in different situations," said [Jose Calderon]. summary: You can attach any conspiracy theory you'd like to Labor's robust adjustments in December - but I won't. As I said, last month's 11,000 real gain in jobs was turned into a seasonally adjusted 292,000 increase. For December 2014, a real unadjusted gain of only 6,000 jobs was also turned into a solid increase of 252,000 jobs. Maybe that's why the experts were puzzled last Friday as the robust 292,000 new jobs were accompanied by nary a budge in the nation's labor participation rate. And wages are climbing only modestly. summary: The JPMorgan Chase CEO is preparing to rip out thousands of its $24,000-a-year Bloomberg terminals over the coming two or three years, which may crimp the private financial data company that's made Mike Bloomberg one of the world's richest men, The Post has learned exclusively. The New York-based bank is in the midst of negotiating contracts with Thomson Reuters - Bloomberg's main competitor - to replace at least 1,000 to 2,000 terminals worldwide during the next two years, according to a person directly familiar with the company's plans.  In 2011, Bloomberg ran a story that compared the bank to Nazis over a debt deal gone bad. Two years later, The Post first broke the news that Bloomberg reporters had used the terminal to snoop on bankers' whereabouts by employing terminal functions that weren't available to other users. summary: He's the first-ever openly gay legislator from Israel's ruling bloc - the equivalent of a gay Republican entering Congress. And while he's committed to LGBT rights, Ohana holds few of the "lefty" views typical of "minority" legislators in liberal democracies. "In the past, gay people were drawn to the left because there was no other option, but I believe we've finally matured as a community," [Amir Ohana] told The Post from Tel Aviv. "In Israel, LGBTs are now part of the military and business and political systems; we are everywhere. My party, the Likud, is Israel's largest - and it's natural that we are there, too." As in America, Israel's right wing "is viewed as ignorant and prejudiced and homophobic, and this is simply not true," Ohana continues. "The Likud's LGBT Caucus" - which Ohana co-founded - "is actually the largest gay political group in the entire nation." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Marc Berman
summary: "We're not happy to be close to maybe doing something," [Derek Fisher] said before the game. "I do think we're getting better. We're doing some really good things. We're not throwing parties and celebrations for what we're doing. We're working really, really hard. I hope to get to a point where we're not looking at what everyone else is doing because we got that good. If we stay focused on who we are, it doesn't matter what everyone else is doing." It's been a strange season with the East deeper than the West. Three teams that didn't make the playoffs last season have winning records - Orlando (20-18), Detroit (21-16) and Indiana (21-16), with the Pacers the lone Eastern team the Knicks still haven't played. Charlotte, which didn't make the playoffs last season, also has fallen back after being in the top eight most of the season. Charlotte is now at 17-20 and opened the door even wider for the resurgent Knicks. "I do think the guys are responding to adversity, adverse situations when a tough quarter isn't going well, able to fight back," Fisher said. "That's a really good sign for our team. It's been tough for everyone around the league except Golden State and San Antonio to win eight, nine games in a row and get traction. The Eastern Conference is somewhat surprising at how balanced it is." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "I like college football better because being a good recruiter, you create an advantage for yourself," [Nick Saban] said in an interview with Golf Channel, "because you can recruit as many good players as you can get to come, and you're not restricted by free agency or salary cap or draft picks and all that type of stuff." That way of life has worked out fairly well for Saban. Monday night, he won his fifth national championship, as Alabama beat Clemson 45-40 in Glendale, Ariz.-site of the Giants' titanic upset of the Patriots in Super Bowl XLII. Making an inquiry about Saban would be a bold and un-Giantslike maneuver. It is also probably a fruitless endeavor. Saban makes $7 million a year as the highest paid college football coach in the country and to get him out of Tuscaloosa, an NFL team would have to far exceed that figure. When he signed a contract extension a few years ago, Saban said it represented "a commitment to the University of Alabama for the rest of our career," referring to himself and his wife. "If we had Drew Brees, I might still be in Miami," Saban said. The Dolphins in 2006, unsure if Brees' shoulder was healthy, eschewed Brees in free agency and opted to trade for Daunte Culpepper. But we're a better team than that." The loss to the Cardinals was part of the Packers' late-season swoon that left few believing they even could beat the inferior Redskins team, which entered Sunday 0-3 against teams with winning records this season. "When you get to the playoffs, you don't have to talk about the regular season anymore. I don't know if you guys got the memo on that." Packers receiver Randall Cobb, who caught a [Aaron Rodgers] touchdown pass Sunday, called it "a new season." "This is playoff football," Cobb said. "You're a few games away from your ultimate goal. All you can ask for is an opportunity. We were blessed with the opportunity to be here, to be able to have a chance. Now we just have to make the most out of it." Teams only get so many chances to be special. The Packers seized that opportunity in 2010 when few saw it coming. It's entirely possible they can do it again in the next month. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: Hence, the key players to moving this market along would appear to be [Chris Davis] and the Orioles. If Davis' agent Scott Boras, the king of January signings, finds another suitor for Davis - the Cardinals could move forward from their ugly hacking scandal by picking up such a big bat - then Baltimore appears poised to act on [Cespedes] or Upton. If Baltimore and Davis re-up together, then the missions for Cespedes and [Justin Upton] would appear to grow tougher. A group of teams including the White Sox, Tigers and Angels all possess a clear need for outfield help, and those clubs have sent signals they don't envision themselves entering nine-figure territory. It falls upon Cespedes' representatives at Roc Nation Sports and Upton's agent Larry Reynolds to turn those signals north. It could be, as an executive from an AL club put it, "A few guys overplayed their hands." Regarding Cespedes, teams could be wary of his up-and-down on-base percentage, which registered .294 in 2013 and .301 in 2014 before rising to .328 last year. There also could be a belief that Cespedes' monster run with the Mets came largely at the expense of lesser pitching. And there's the general streakiness Mets fans witnessed, from August/September stud to World Series goat, which could have some suitors wary of a marriage. "From our forward standpoint, the four lines that we've got, we've got to get a little bit more. Somehow, some way, you've got to dig deep and you've got to find a way." "You've got one goal in the last six periods of hockey," Capuano said prior to the game. "I don't care what kind of defense that you play; at some point you're going to have to get a couple goals to win a game." "We're going to continue to look at things to make us better," Capuano said. "We're not satisfied with how things are right now." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Larry Brooks
summary: If general manager Jeff Gorton were serious about keeping the 29-year-old defenseman off the market, wouldn't you expect the Rangers to increase [Keith Yandle]'s ice time and responsibilities, especially since the only realistic way to clear out enough space would be to get second-pair lefty Marc Staal's permission to move him and his $5.7 million per contract that runs through 2020-21? By the way, I'm not particularly interested in pushing Birthday Boy Staal out the door at the age of 29, either, but it is the only logical scenario under which Yandle could stay. Trading [Dan Girardi] to keep Yandle would mean moving Ryan McDonagh permanently to the right side, which is not in anyone's plans. It would be unfair to heap a disproportionate amount of blame on Girardi for the Rangers' wobbly play in their own end, but it would also be dishonest to pretend that the hockey warrior's persistent struggles haven't taken a toll on everyone, including his partners. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Yandle business No reason for Rangers to keep little-used defender off market

author: ZACH BRAZILLER
summary: Deshaun Watson didn't leave University of Phoenix Stadium a champion Monday night, didn't lead Clemson to its first national championship in 34 years, but he did everything else, rolling up 478 yards of total offense - breaking Young's national championship game record of 467 - and four passing touchdowns in a heartbreaking 45-40 loss to Alabama and Nick Saban. Next season will begin with anticipation of what Watson can do next, how he can build off his breakthrough sophomore season when he was college football's most dynamic player. A number of big stars are back, creating a deep and exciting field for the Heisman Trophy, from Stanford's Christian McCaffrey to LSU's Leonard Fournette and Florida State's Dalvin Cook. If a defense like Alabama's can't even contain him, who, exactly, will? When asked what Watson needs to improve upon, offensive guard Eric Mac Lain interrupted the question, saying: "Nothing." But Watson seems already fueled by the loss. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: WATS' UP! Even in loss, Clemson QB establishes himself as the player to watch next season BACK TO SCHOOL

author: ZACH BRAZILLER
summary: GLENDALE, Ariz. - Even with an entertaining championship game that offered suspense, drama and an all-time individual performance, the College Football Playoff title game couldn't match last year's ratings. Improving upon the dreadful numbers from the semifinals on New Year's Eve yet still falling short of last year, Alabama's 45-40 win over Clemson on Monday night saw a 15 percent decrease from the inaugural College Football Playoff championship, according to numbers released by ESPN on Tuesday. The semifinals on New Year's Eve, meanwhile, saw a precipitous drop, of 36 percent from last year when the games were played on New Year's Day. However, College Football Playoff executive director Bill Hancock said on Friday the plan is to play the semis again on New Year's Eve. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: The $22 sweat sessions, offered five times a week, kick off with a "Soul Train"-style conga line to break the ice. Students then spend the rest of the one-hour class learning the step-by-step dance moves to a particular music video. Songs run the gamut from contemporary hits (think Drake's "Hotline Bling") to pop classics (Michael and Janet Jackson's "Scream"). "You do not have to be a professional," says [Akinah Rahmaan]. "Everyone comes in at different levels. Everyone is learning at the same pace, so there is no pressure to get it right the first time around." "You're not only getting in shape and having loads of fun," adds the Far Rockaway, Queens, resident, "you are learning your next scintillating dance move for the club." author: Reed Tucker,Dawn Lerman
summary: For the first time, the USDA put a cap on how much of the sweet stuff Americans should eat. It recommends that we get no more than 10 percent of our calories from sugar. For the average 2,000-calorie-per-day diet, that's 200 calories or about 50 grams. 1 16-ounce bottle of Coca-Cola (52 grams of sugar) That's the equivalent of scarfing 13 sugar cubes! Sugar's on the bad list, but what are you supposed to eat? The new USDA guidelines encourage a well-rounded diet full of vegetables, fruit, grains and a variety of proteins. Three to five 8-ounce cups of caffeine and moderate alcohol consumption - one drink per day for women, two for men - also appear to be safe, and the report recommends consuming two to three cups of low-fat dairy daily. Have a look at what should be on your plate. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Sour and sweet Forget Frappucinos. The feds are cracking down on sugar

author: Hardeep Phull
summary: The basic tenet of [Wim Hof]'s technique involves "controlled hyperventilation" - breathing until you feel lightheaded, then holding your breath for as long as you're comfortable. The practice is supposed to increase adrenaline, the immune-suppressing stress hormone normally produced in "fight or flight" situations, which allows the body to withstand extreme temperatures. Still, while turning off the immune system "can be dangerous," according to Dr. David B. Samadi of Lenox Hill Hospital, fine-tuning it may be beneficial to sufferers of chronic stress, whose "immune system is constantly turned on and fighting something that isn't actually there." "You see an ad for a drug that spends 10 seconds listing the benefits, but 20 seconds listing the side effects," says Hof acolyte Kristian Flores, a 39-year-old strength-and-conditioning coach based on the Upper East Side. "People want to return to a less synthetic existence, especially in New York, where we're constantly surrounded by concrete and glass." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Cindy Adams
summary: Summers back. At a stiflingly hot Midwest Democratic political convention, I wore a not-new red and white polka-dot cotton dress. David Dinkins introduced "Kick" Kennedy. We'd never before met. Her opening greeting? "You still wearing that old thing? I had it once. I threw mine out already." Meanwhile, age 20 New Yorker Samuel Dittenhoffer also headed out. Nicknamed Navajo Sam. Knowing he knew Billy the Kid, and thus Billy wouldn't harm him, Santa Fe's Spiegelberg store trusted him to deliver money. Wrapping 100,000 Mexican pesos (then $50,000) in paper to prevent rattling, he jammed them into fake tops and bottoms of big barrels marked "Chihuahua flour." Around Las Cruces, Billy the Kid rode up, tapped a barrel with his gun and said he could use flour. "Haven't had real good baked biscuits in a long time." Then jumped into Sam's front seat and exchanged flasks and sagas, like how he just robbed a stage coach: "The occupants turned over jewelry and cash. An old fumbling lady had only a five-dollar gold piece. Reminding me of my own beloved mother, I said, 'Keep it for a rainy day.' Later I learned she hid $300 in bank notes in her stockings." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Still alluring in her 90s

author: STEVE SERBY
summary: [John Mara] said this once on WFAN about the hiring of [Tom Coughlin]: "I wanted somebody that wanted to win as badly as I do. That was a trait that you could see in him right away. He obviously had the football smarts and the experience, and you knew he was gonna bring some discipline to the team." When [Ben McAdoo] was hired by the Packers in 2006 as tight ends coach, he said: "I've always been the dark horse in every job I've received, so I usually go in with a chip on my shoulder. Tome, it's a about dreaming big, working hard, taking care of business, and having a little fun while you're doing it."  McAdoo, a kid with a dream from Homer City, Pa., is a risk. All of the candidates were risks. The Giants have dared to be great. Maybe McAdoo is the next Andy Reid. Maybe he isn't. But he offers the chance for the greatest reward. I just wanted to take some initiative and making sure guys were high motivated and fighting to win the game." "It just depends on who I'm on the floor with," the normally soft-spoken Afflalo said. "With guys like [Carmelo Anthony], I don't have to be as vocal with him. He's been around a while and knows what to do. Same with Jose [Calderon] and Robin [Lopez]. Guys not typically in that position, I elevate it." "I'm comfortable with that situation," Afflalo said. "I've been the number one option, second option. "I know how to get the job done. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "Great respect for coach McAdoo and the whole offensive staff," [Manning] said after the season. "I think we've done good things and I feel very comfortable, I think we work well. Last year it was tough. It was a lot going on and very new and trying to learn, but I bought into it because I trusted him." Manning was devastated to see [Tom Coughlin] go, but strongly endorsed keeping McAdoo in the building. "I think our offense certainly improved," Mara last week said of McAdoo. "I think he's proven himself to be a very good teacher, has a very good handle on our offense. I think he communicates very well. I think he shows some leadership skills." After two years in McAdoo's offense, no one in the Giants' front office wanted to see the 35-year old Manning have to learn a new system. summary: He was called into head coach Mike Tomlin's office after the season, thinking he was getting a raise, but instead got a pink slip. The Steelers termed it a "retirement." After he did a remarkable job filling in for head coach Chuck Pagano while he was undergoing leukemia treatments in 2013, the Cardinals finally made Arians ahead coach for the first time since he was Temple's headcoach in the 1980s in his 30s. "What you're seeing is a guy that's taken all his years of experience and become one of the top coaches in the ers coach Bill Cowher, who worked with Arians in Kansas City, then brought him to Pittsburgh as his receivers coach from 2004-06. author: Brian Lewis
summary: Nets owner Mikhail Prokhorov said he plans to take his time with the hires and split the two positions. That likely deceases the odds of John Calipari, Nets CEO Brett Yormark's favorite, getting the job, even moreso than the $120 million asking price Calipari's business agent William Wesley reportedly circulated. Prokhorov's consigliere Dimitry Razumov will spearhead the search. He's not only a shrewd politician - like King - but has previously rebuilt two foundering teams. The 3-point-heavy speedball style so prevalent in today's NBA can largely be traced back to the Suns' Seven Seconds Or Less. With Prokhorov preferring a more uptempo attack - and telling interim Tony Brown as much - it begs the question of whether Mike D'Antoni would be considered? summary: "It's mainly because of Porzingis," [Frazier] told The Post Wednesday night. "Like Tuesday night, the Garden reverberated on everything this guy does, man. They get excited, whether it's scoring, blocking a shot, falling down. Everything, he's an energizer. "There's nothing like it," Frazier said, "and these guys have no clue of what's ahead for them. They just had a little inkling Tuesday night with all the cheers. They don't know that it can be this way in 41 games, plus the playoffs. They have no clue what the Garden can be, how provocative the crowd can be in catapulting your game. "You feel invincible as a player," Frazier said. "Every game you go into you're psyched and nobody knows that better than me - Game 7. I'm always talking about the crowd before that game. author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "Always hire a guy you know," George Young said on Dec. 15, 1982, and it was good that George Young knew who Bill Parcells was that day because outside of Oradell, N.J., there weren't a whole lot of people, Giants fans or not, who could have picked Parcells out of a lineup. Well, let's assume that Jerry Reese and John Mara aren't going to get that colorful when they explain why they opted for Ben McAdoo to replace Tom Coughlin as the Giants' new head coach after spending two years as the team's offensive coordinator. Your guess is as good as mine, and as good as the general manager's, and as good as the owner's. Maybe, five years from now, we will talk about them being the smartest guys in the room, about how they identified the right guy from a list of intriguing guys. Maybe. But we don't know.
