author: Raquel Laneri
summary: Not that Pignatelli is exactly a recluse: the yachts, the occasional scandal, the coterie of famous photographers and socialites. The inside cover of his new coffee table book, "The Great Beauty," which commemorates 20 years of Pier 59 and which Pignatelli shot himself on location at the famed Getty Villa in Rome, includes a list of names of the VIPs who have dropped by his studios, including Sting, both President Bushes, and even Monica Lewinsky. "Very sweet girl," he recalls of the infamous White House intern. Of President Bill Clinton: "You could really have a conversation with the man." His loft has seen its fair share of action, too. "I've had parties here with 200 people. Ivana Trump came here. Donald Trump came here" - no word of what Pignatelli, a supporter of refugee causes, makes of the latter's presidential bid. "But it's been 10 years since I've had a party here. Now I just do it at the studio." You could say that Rome-born Pignatelli comes from a family of bon vivants. His mother, the Princess Doris Pignatelli, a fixture of iconic nightclub "Cafe Society" in her day, even appeared in "La Dolce Vita," Federico Fellini's cinematic ode to excess and decay. But the young prince was a bit of a rebel. "I grew up very independent, as my parents were separated and I did not see much of them," he says. "I skipped school any opportunity I could. I was a bad student." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

"I think so. My mom said your dad is [Joel LeBaron] the prophet ... Joel was my dad, too," she said. Then, she pointed to the little girl in the front row. "She's our sister, too." "Ruthie, I need to tell you ... that I'm so sorry," she said. "I'm sorry for everything that you've gone through, for everything [Lane] has done to you. I do feel like things have gotten better. On the Mayor de Blasio front, Cuomo proposes creating what amounts to a receivership program for localities whose homelessness policies don't measure up to gubernatorial standards - guess where New York City's will rank - and also accepted with a flourish former Police Commissioner Ray Kelly's proposal to relieve the city of substantial responsibility for combating terrorism. Then there was the miscellaneous patronage and pandering - including proposals to vastly expand the state's set-asides for minority business enterprises and freeze tolls on the state Thruway until 2020. author: Elisabeth Vincentelli
summary: The show's idea of edginess consists of making Dr. Foster a morphine addict - completely different from what we've already seen on "The Knick," "Nurse Jackie" or "House," then. Also on hand is the obligatory handsome, brilliant, brooding surgeon - enter Dr. Jedediah Foster (Josh Radnor, from "How I Met Your Mother").  Needless to say, Dr. Foster doesn't have it easy at the hospital, especially since his willingness to treat everybody equally puts him at odds with Dr. Byron Hale (Norbert Leo Butz), who's loath to spend any time and energy on Southern patients. Co-created by "ER" alum David Zabel, "Mercy Street" is so conventional that it's TV's answer to a warm, decidedly unchallenging bath. Of course there are brave, noble free African-Americans (McKinley Belcher III, Shalita Grant). Of course there's a spoiled, sheltered Southern belle who'll eventually toughen up (Hannah James). author: Paul Schwartz
summary: The Eagles wanted [Tom Coughlin] badly, and Thursday they were prepared to make him an offer. Coughlin, though, wanted to bring along some of his coaching staff from the Giants, but with [Ben McAdoo] hired to replace him, much of that staff will be retained. Thus, Coughlin took himself out of contention and said thanks, but no thanks to the Eagles. Coughlin explored his options and was not going to jump at the chance for any job available to him. Coughlin spoke with the Eagles and then the 49ers about their openings; on Thursday the 49ers hired Kelly, the former Eagles coach. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Unable to raid staff, Coughlin passes on Birds

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: The Giants have gone 6-10 in both of [Ben McAdoo]'s seasons, despite McAdoo helping Eli Manning put together the finest statistical seasons of his 12-year career. The success with Manning, coupled with the relationship he fostered with the franchise quarterback, were key factors in giving McAdoo the promotion. "We were all impressed with his energy, his enthusiasm, his vision and his desire," [John Mara] said in the statement. "Ben has been preparing for this opportunity since he started coaching, and he has earned his stripes every step of the way." The Giants say McAdoo and [Jerry Reese] "will collaborate with the team's personnel departments in reshaping the Giants' roster." Mara put Reese on notice following the season for the lack of talent and depth on the roster. "Ben is very excited, and I'm very excited and happy for him," Reese said. "We are looking forward to working closely together, and can't wait to get moving with the offseason." Those who expect (and fear) little will change in the building with McAdoo taking over for [Tom Coughlin] may be mistaken. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: ALL IN 'DOO TIME McAdoo, 38, says he's prepared his entire career for this chance - and Giants believe he's ready

Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: McCarthy 'proud' of his former assistant

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "The other thing is, you're the face of the franchise," said [Jim Fassel], who added the hiring of [Ben McAdoo] is a good move."You're the guy talking to the media and if you can't articulate and you can't have composure when you need it for whatever you need to do with the media, you come off like a fool and the whole organization looks disorganized. That's why I think some guys make it and some guys don't make it." McAdoo ran the offense but he was respected on both sides of the ball. "He possesses similar qualities to Tom Coughlin, from what I've seen," cornerback Prince Amukamara said in a text message. "He always seems like a players' coach. Guys listen when he speaks." Offensive lineman Geoff Schwartz says McAdoo has "grown as a coach" the past two seasons. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: Fassel: Keep calling plays as head coach

author: STEVE SERBY
summary: "People understand when someone has purpose," [Rick Foust] said. "When [Ben McAdoo] walks into a room, he has purpose. He's not walking into that room for 27 reasons. He's walking into that room for one reason. There's a focus that says, 'This is the direction we're going.' " McAdoo coached offensive line in 1997 at Homer-Center when [Eric] coached defensive backs. "If you talk to Ben, if you know Ben, what you know about him is just he's honest, he's straightforward, he's not deceptive, he doesn't play any of the political-type games - he doesn't do any of those things," Rick Foust said. "He's gonna be right up-front, headed in a straight line, to try to get to whatever that goal is, wherever he's headed for. And I guess that will be the hard thing, trying to understand people who aren't that way. "It wasn't about Ben, it was about Eli being successful. Ben doesn't care whether they say, 'Hey, Ben McAdoo has done his stuff with Eli Manning that has made him better.' He doesn't care about that. I think that's how he sells himself. I think he sells himself by having people understand he has a job to do. He's gonna work hard to do his job, and to give you the best opportunity that he can give you. And he's gonna do that for the entire Giant football program right now, he's gonna do the best job he can to give that team the best opportunity to be successful. And I think there will be nobody on that staff or on that football team that won't agree with that and won't believe that."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: CARRYING THE LOAD McAdoo willing to work as hard as his players in order to win

author: Brian Costello
summary: "Absolutely we would consider using the franchise tag," [Mike Maccagnan] said of tagging someone in general and then got specific about [Muhammad Wilkerson]. "In a perfect world, we'd like very much to have [Damon Harrison] back in the organization," he said. "I've talked to [Todd Bowles] about that. We're both in agreement on his value. It's just a question, being a potential free agent, if we can make it work." "I think [Darrelle Revis] is a very good corner," Maccagnan said. author: Brian Costello
summary: "We'd like very much to get him back, obviously based on how he played this year, but I don't really want to get into the speculation aspect of it," Jets general manager Mike Maccagnan said Thursday. "I would simply leave it at we'll see how this thing works out." The bigger question for the Jets at the position is about who will be backing [Ryan Fitzpatrick] up. Jets coach Todd Bowles already declared Fitzpatrick the starter if he returns. So what happens to Geno Smith? The former starter received a lukewarm endorsement from Maccagnan, who said Smith is "under contract," words a player never wants to hear a GM say. That is basically a nice way of saying he's on the team for now. "With Geno, he's under contract," Maccagnan said. "We like the progress he's made and, quite frankly, how he handled the situation in the summer. Right now, I'd say going forward we're going to see how Geno and Bryce [Petty] progress with the offseason and go from there. That's assuming we are able to re-sign Ryan." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Hondo
summary: PACKERS-CARDINALS: Mr. [Aaron Rodgers] doesn't do so well when he leaves his neighborhood and visits Glendale, as was proven in the Packers' 38-8 thrashing three weeks ago. Don't be dissuaded by Green Bay's seeming resurgence on Sunday. The well-rested Cards' defense is far more stingy and manly than the Redskins'. As long as the Manitowoc County (Wisc.) Sheriff's Office doesn't engage in some sort of game-altering subterfuge, Arizona should slay the Pack again.  SEAHAWKS-PANTHERS: Camelot versus Kamelot. The Seahawks' charmed life ends Sunday when Kuechly & Co. dominate, Graham Gano doesn't miss any point-blank field goals and Jonathan Stewart holds onto the football. Count on Newton's law - for every action ... - to prevail: Cam's profuse dabbing will trigger much misery from the Seahags.  STEELERS-BRONCOS: Don't be scared off by Peyton Manning's nine one-and-done playoff appearances or his 0-5 record in sub-40 temperatures or the rust he has developed from not having started since Week 10. Do be scared off by the Steelers' dire injury situation, namely Ben Roethlisberger's sprained AC joint and torn shoulder ligaments, Antonio Brown's concussion and DeAngelo Williams' injured right foot. The general handicapping rule of thumb is: When a team with a totally depleted offense goes up against the league's No. 1 defense, follow "D" money. The celebratory doobies will burn through the night in Colorado.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Hondo fizzles after fast start NFL BETTOR'S GUIDE - DIVISIONAL ROUND

author: Dave Blezow
summary: Tough call, but leaning to the Cats because of a feeling we're ready for a new Super Bowl representative from the NFC. Watching last week's freeze-a-thon in Minnesota, didn't get the idea that the weather was the Seahawks' main problem.  BRONCOS (-7) over Steelers, Under 39 /[2]: It's the divisional round, but there are so many "wild cards" in the deck here. The Steelers' three biggest weapons - Ben Roethlisberger, Antonio Brown and DeAngelo Williams - all have serious injuries (though at least Big Ben is expected to play by most, and Brown is expected to play by Adam "Pacman" Jones). Earlier this season, Big Ben threw for 380 yards and Brown had 16 catches for 189 yards and two touchdowns against the No. 1 Denver yardage defense. It was just stunning. As was the final drive in the rain in Cincinnati with Big Ben's shoulder ravaged. [Dave Blezow]'S LOCK OF THE WEEK: Light, cam, action: Count on Newton and the Panthers to end the Seahawks' attempt at a third-straight Super Bowl on Sunday, writes Dave Blezow. author: Phil Mushnick
summary: While awaiting the "please stay on the line for the next available representative," we often reach the point when we consider hanging up (or hanging down; "hanging up" is anti-gravitational, no?). That's when we hear, "Your call is important to us." Who doesn't like a recording with a sense of humor? The same [Boomer Esiason] who can't suffer the incivilities he saw from pro athletes and their coaches in a playoff game on Saturday spends weekdays advancing social coarsening. He obligatorily trash-talks and deals in simple put-down artistry while purposefully speaking go-low words and idioms including "ass" "piss" and "sucks" - not the worst of pop-cultural choices, but words Weekend Boomer assiduously avoids, especially when expressing pro-civility sentiments in response to NFL malfeasance.  [Goodell]'s richly rewarded assistance in such matters - the not-for-profit NFL has paid him well over $100 million over the past five years - would be easier to indulge had he not been given to declarations such as, "It's all about the fans," and that fantasy league gambling - sucker-bet operations the NFL and its teams have thrown millions into for its cut of fans' losses - "is not gambling." title: Eagles tab Chiefs' Pederson

author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: It's a little too simplistic to say that as [John Tavares] goes, the Islanders go - but it's not far from the truth. For one, Tavares knows how important he is to the team and puts added pressure on himself to succeed. Coach Jack Capuano knows how integral Tavares is to the Islanders' success, as well, even if it's not ideal to be leaning so heavily on one player. "I always talk about being a complete player and doing good things without the puck," Tavares said. "I've had a lot of conversations with the coaching staff about that. That's where a lot of my offense comes from, I'm able to generate scoring chances from being strong in my own end. You know, it's just trying to overcome whatever you're going through. You don't want to let it inhibit any other parts of your game." "I just try to focus on doing the right things, and being strong without the puck, being strong in the faceoff circle, things that you can control - your work ethic, your habits, your attitude," Tavares said. "Certainly being a leader of the team, you don't want to reflect any negativity. You want to be hard on yourself and [have] high expectations and put pressure on yourself. But at the same time, you have to stick with your game." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: DUNCE CAP'T Tavares hunts for answers - & goals - with Isles

author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: "It's a huge win," said Cal Clutterbuck, the Islanders agitator who was in the middle of a lot of the on-ice angst. "The division is a close race, so it's a big win for all the other reasons other than the sexy ones." "I felt great tonight," said [Jaroslav Halak], who finished with 34 saves, the only one of the 27 shots he faced in the first two periods that beat him being a Marc Staal crashing-the-net deflection with 46 seconds left in the middle frame to give the Rangers a 1-0 lead. "Every time we play these guys, it's special." "We wake up [Friday], our fans feel pretty good, a little strut in their step," [John Tavares] said. "We know how much they care about [these games]. And certainly for us, we take a lot of pride in playing these guys. It's tight in the division right now, and we know how big these points are, so it's a lot of fun beating them." author: Larry Brooks
summary: It was 1-0 after two, Henrik Lundqvist looked as sharp and as locked in as he's been since Thanksgiving, and the Rangers seemed poised to lock down their most significant victory in ages, one that would have affirmed the team's recovery from last month's crash. "I've been saying for a while that we have been doing a lot of good things, and that's true again, but they find a way to capitalize on a power play early in the third and we can't hit the back of the net on ours," said Derek Stepan. "We generated looks, but we have to be able to score on the power play, and we didn't." For when [Brock Nelson] took a late jab at the puck under Lundqvist's pad, [Dylan McIlrath] took a couple of swats at the Islanders winger after he'd peeled to the boards. [Kevin Pollock] couldn't wait to call a penalty on the rookie, who had a solid night, and so he did, getting No. 6 for roughing at 3:23. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: SMALL BLUNDERS Rangers can't come up big when it matters most

author: Larry Brooks
summary: You might suggest mediocrity represents a step forward for the Rangers, who were 4-2-1 in their previous seven following the 3-9-2 crash through the holiday season, and you would be correct. But even while stabilizing, the Rangers haven't quite looked like themselves; haven't looked like the puck-moving, speed team they were in their first two seasons with Alain Vigneault behind the bench. The team's calling card stretch pass has disappeared, either taken away by opponents who, two years later, have adjusted to the tactic; or lost on the Rangers' own accord because of the team's scrambly work in the defensive zone. Even beyond those trouble spots, the Islanders haven't played with the same energy or moxie that marked their final season at the Coliseum. They haven't been able to establish the four-line, rolling thunder of an attack that identified the team last year, and has identified the Islanders against the Rangers for the last three or four seasons. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: DATE WITH MESS-TINY Struggling Rangers, Isles on playoff crash course

author: Marc Berman
summary: Days after the NBA announced the two-game suspension, [Matt Barnes] was still bitter and issued a New Year's Eve missive on Instagram, calling [Derek Fisher] "a snitch" and writing, in part, he "got dealt w for being a snake, then ran & told the Police & NBA.. Instead of taken that ass whoopin like a man & kept it moving....!" It didn't read like a player who had forgiven Fisher. Meanwhile, the union is convinced Barnes was suspended unfairly, believing strongly the matter was "a private issue." The Players Association feels the Barnes suspension was "a significant overreach by the league that didn't warrant discipline." "It was the type of conduct away from the court that didn't result in criminal allegations or injuries and was totally out of bounds for the league to impose discipline," one person familiar with the union's case told The Post. "It is nothing the league should be sticking their nose into. They feel very strongly Barnes has a very good appeal." Commenting on the appeal Thursday, Barnes, averaging 8.8 points, 5.1 rebounds and 1.2 steals, told ESPN, "I appreciate the support I've got from not only my peers throughout the NBA but NFL and from the entertainment world. It means a lot that the NBAPA has filed an appeal on my behalf, but I won't hold my breath.Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: According to MASNsports.com, the Orioles have made an offer to Cespedes after publicly pulling their seven-year, $150million deal from Chris Davis. ESPN reported the offer to [Cespedes] is for five years and between $75million and $90 million. The 30-year-old Cespedes batted .291 with 35 home runs and 105 RBIs while splitting time with the Tigers and Mets last year. Cespedes' torrid second half with the Mets - he blasted 17 home runs and drove in 44 RBI in just 57 games - helped lead them back to the World Series for the first time in 15 years. author: Mike Puma
summary: "I've played against plenty of former teammates before,"[David Wright] said. "I think [Murphy] might have a different feeling on it, but as far as I go, it's just going to be two very good teams playing against each other." Wright spent much of December in Los Angeles to receive advice on his back from renowned specialist Dr. Robert Watkins and work with his physical therapy staff. The Mets' physical therapist, John Zajac (who accompanied Wright to Los Angeles), is implementing the same routine for Wright in Port St. Lucie. "I don't know what the situation is with Cespedes and the Mets, but I do know that [Sandy Alderson] has earned the right to make these type of decisions,"Wright said. "You can't argue with the success he's had in turning this organization from the bottom of the NL East to National League champs last year, so I have all the confidence in the world that he will make the correct decisions." Wright also discussed his friend Daniel Murphy's departure to the rival Nationals, who signed the second baseman to a three year contract. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Lewis
summary: "When your coach is not panicking and he's staying positive and he's continued to motivate us, it's huge for us as far as an energy standpoint," [Thaddeus Young] said. "It makes us want to continue to go out there and continue to play, and it doesn't keep us thinking about what's happening before as much. "With us, I think our tendencies before [were] we were harping on the fact that we were going up leads and harping on the fact that we have some plays where we turned the ball over. But [Tony Brown]'s mentality is: 'Forget what happened before this, and let's try to push and try to win this game.' That's huge for us as a team. It says a lot that he believes in us, that he wants us to compete, he believes that we can continue to win the game at any point." "It's been good. [Brown has] freed everybody up to go play basketball," [Shane Larkin] said. "It's not a lot of stress out there, just go try to have fun, play hard, play with energy. Just go play, that's what he's preaching, so that's what we're doing. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Justin Terranova
summary: "The way that [Peyton Manning] finished up against the Chargers and the way his teammates celebrated with him was a great sign," CBS analyst and former Chargers quarterback Dan Fouts said. "To see him smile again - we hadn't seen Manning smile for a year - just to see the way it came down. ... It just gives me a good feeling about the support he'll get in this game."  "And the other thing is: If things don't go well, the Broncos know they have a backup quarterback in [Brock Osweiler] who can get the job done," said Fouts, who is calling the Chiefs-Patriots game in Foxboro on Saturday afternoon. "That's a real hidden plus for Denver." "The thing I noticed when Peyton Manning came into the game [against the Chargers] - all the little things: how he makes the defense wait and wait until he decides what to do," [Phil Simms] said. "You're always on edge and lose your aggressiveness sometimes when you play a quarterback like Peyton Manning because you're sitting over there guessing what he's going to do. author: Kyle Smith
summary: Whenever film critics are accused of having the best job on the planet, the two-word retort is obvious: "Ride Along." That one looks like "Annie Hall" compared to "Ride Along 2." In whipping up the banter for the two lead actors, screenwriters Phil Hay and Matt Manfredi deliver such excruciation that their names should become synonymous with embarrassment and woe. Back acne should be renamed after them, or pus or scrofula. They have [Ben Barber] wear a white outfit so [James Payton] can retort that Ben looks like a "marshmallow." When a car blows up, they have Ben say, "Do you have any idea what your insurance is going to do?" They have James reply to Ben's babbling about police technique with, "Why don't we try the shut-the-hell-up technique." They have the bad guy announce, "I'm really, really rich." Every so often there's a meaningless shootout or Ben and James simply punch each other randomly in the face. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: "I think America's getting more comfortable with guys like me because I've been around for a long time - they've gotten to know me," he tells The Post. With his new comedy "Ride Along 2" (co-starring comic Kevin Hart) in theaters Friday, we caught up with the 46-year-old Cube (real name: O'Shea Jackson). "Not at all. He comes with that life-of-the-party spirit. It's not an act; it stays on when the camera goes off. He always makes fun of me being old-school, saying things like, 'Cube's got bad knees.' I come back with the little man jokes: I call him 'Baby Gap' or say he got 'infant nuts' [laughs]!" "I didn't pay it much attention at all. My mom and sisters would be watching, but I'd be outside playing basketball. I started paying attention when Whoopi Goldberg won for 'Ghost' [in 1990]. That was when I started thinking, 'Oh wow, we can win one.'" Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Kyle Smith
summary: As it turned out, democracy doesn't arise from long-distance best wishes. For all the blood, bullets and fire shown in "13 Hours," there is a running theme: With brave men such as these available, why weren't more of them deployed to give Libya a chance? "Libya is officially a failed state," reads a grim title at the end of the film. Still, if "13 Hours" lacks the gravitas of "American Sniper," it's powerful stuff. [Michael Bay]'s goal is to put you right in these men's boots, to feel the heat, the fear, the fatigue, the weight of the weapons and the web of camaraderie. Sticking closely to the survivors' accounts of what happened that night, Bay captures in impressive detail the dizzying chaos. "13 Hours" injects you with raw testosterone, adrenaline - and anger at how the men never got the air support for which they repeatedly begged. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: ON TARGET! Explosive '13 Hours' powerfully recaptures the chaos and tragedy of Benghazi

"Most of the things people are saying about Bloomberg now - perhaps arrogant, difficult to deal with, won't negotiate price the way they should with other products - all of those things were being said about Reuters in the '90s when they were number one," he added.  "Bloomberg is a valuable partner of ours," Larry Di Rita, a BofA spokesman, told The Post. "Terminals are a big part of that partnership. We work with them on many different areas and definitely plan to continue doing so through this year and beyond. It is incorrect that this relationship will change in July of 2016." summary: That's why I'll always treasure [David Bowie], who died Sunday at age 69 of liver cancer, which he'd kept secret from all but those closest to him in his last 18 months of life. Adding cosmic insult to injury, CBGB, the now-closed punk-rock club on Manhattan's Bowery where I squandered many a brain cell during my misspent youth, was reopened last month as CBGB L.A.B. - lounge and bar - at Newark Liberty International Airport! I was determined to sample its $9 deviled eggs, $42 prime rib and $9 "disco fries" (ordered via iPad), but was crushed to learn that the eatery is located on the far side of security, making it necessary to buy a plane ticket before stomping on the corpses of rock legends past. Family members posted a message online informing the world that a private memorial ceremony in the legend's honor is to be held. Don't send flowers, cards or grieving stones. summary: There was plenty of fury from fans of the two big contenders snubbed for Best Picture nominations - "Carol" and "Straight Outta Compton." ("Star Wars: The Force Awakens" never had a real chance.) At least "Carol" landed nods for its stars - Cate Blanchett (Best Actress) and Rooney Mara, who was gerrymandered into Best Supporting Actress - and Best Adapted Screenplay. Brie Larson of "Room" looks like the leader for Best Actress, and [Leonardo DiCaprio] has no serious competition for Best Actor - his gonzo performance trumps even his tendency to be way too eager to win. Sylvester Stallone is the favorite for Best Supporting Actor in "Creed," but watch out for Mark Ruffalo or Christian Bale if "Spotlight" or "The Big Short" wins Best Picture. For Best Supporting Actress, it looks like a horse race between Mara, Rachel McAdams ("Spotlight") and Alicia Vikander ("The Danish Girl"). Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Steve serby
summary: "What I loved about it was the way he answered all your questions, and the way he didn't answer a lot of the questions," John Mara said with a laugh. "I thought that was terrific, and it seemed to me like he was somebody that's already been a head coach for 10 years, the way he answered some of those questions." "I asked, 'Do you think that he has head coach in him?' " Mara said, "and he said, 'Absolutely.' " "Believe me, I thought about the [Mike Tomlin] scenario quite a bit," Mara said. "He came out of nowhere, now he's one of the best coaches out there. Let's face it - more of them fail than not. But I think this guy has everything that he needs to be a successful head coach. Now we got to help him and get him better personnel." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: Indeed, the Giants did not tear their house down to the foundation. As much as co-owner John Mara declared this to be "a new era of Giants football," it is more of a renovation than a total rebuild. [Ben McAdoo], the offensive coordinator the past two years working for Tom Coughlin, was given a four-year contract, tasked to get the Giants back into Super Bowl contention after four consecutive years out of the playoffs and three straight losing seasons. McAdoo will change much of the operation after 12 years of Coughlin's reign, but this is a hire from within and not an organizational clean slate. Looking back on his rsum, including eight years in the Packers' organization, McAdoo said, "I'm hardened, battle tested and I've been groomed for this opportunity by Super Bowl winning coaches, players and organizations." He described himself as "baptized by fire." "Thinking of a way to honor Tom," McAdoo said. "We have our digital clocks they're all five minutes fast and we're going to stick with that, that's TC time, that's a part of Giants culture now." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: A THEORY OF EVOLUTION McAdoo won't tear down what Coughlin has built

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "[[McAdoo]] was upset at the way that it transpired, he put a lot of the blame on himself, and he realizes that he should have stepped in and done something," Giants owner John Mara said. "When you're an offensive coordinator and you got that play sheet in front you, you're not always focused specifically on what's going on in situations like that. He'll be the head coach now, depending on who he ends up with as his offensive coordinator, it's possible somebody else will be calling the plays. I think he understands that you can't let a situation like that linger."Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Zach Braziller
summary: "I think it took too long," he said jokingly about what he described as his "interesting journey." McAdoo began telling people his goal of coaching in the NFL when he first started coaching in Homer City, and his sister [Jodi Orr] privately hoped he had a backup plan. But she soon realized it wasn't a pipe dream.  "You knew this kid was destined to move up the line and hit the ultimate [prize]," said Albany associate head coach and offensive coordinator Joe Bernard, who hired McAdoo when he was at Fairfield. "I knew he would impress anywhere he was. He was driven to succeed. He was a grinder."  "I've never forgotten that first meeting with [Ben McAdoo] because just his desire and work ethic was evident from that day and it never ceased," [Mike McCarthy], the Packers head coach now, said when the Giants hired McAdoo two years ago to be their offensive coordinator. "That's the way he's always approached the game of football." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Born to coach McAdoo driven to become a Giant at every stage of football career

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: He hasn't had his way with all of them. Eli Manning, top pick of the 2004 draft, has beaten [Tom Brady] three times, two of which will haunt No. 12 to his dying days. But have a look at all the others: Michael Vick (2001), David Carr ('02), Carson Palmer ('03), JaMarcus Russell ('07), Matthew Stafford ('09) and Sam Bradford ('10). Before he's through, Andrew Luck ('12) may well break through against Brady, though to this point all he has done is retreat to the tuck position whenever the two have squared off. Cam Newton ('11) already has beaten Brady once, last year, and he may well be the league's MVP this year, and if things progress as they might he may get a crack at Brady in Santa Clara, Calif., in a couple of weeks. "I'd just say he's a good quarterback that's won a lot of football games," said Andy Reid, the coach of the Chiefs, who gave [Alex Smith] a second lease on his career after he had brought the 49ers to the brink of a Super Bowl only to lose his job to Colin Kaepernick. "He can throw it, he can run it, he can manage the game well. He understands the game; he gets it. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Costello
summary: "Go back and look at everything I said right after the game. Do you want something more than that?" [Bill Belichick] said this week when asked about the 41-14 blowout loss to Kansas City on Sept. 29, 2014. "That was a year and a half ago, so whatever you want I'm sure there's plenty of. I was asked 1,000 questions about it. If you don't have access to it, I'm sure you can get the transcripts of that." "You've got to play your biggest at the biggest moments against the best teams in the toughest conditions," [Tom Brady] said. "You've got to see what you're made of. That's what this tournament is all about." "He's a good player," Patriots safety Devin McCourty said. "Yards after the catch, he's only behind Gronk [[Rob Gronkowski]], so I think that speaks for itself. Whatever as a team we think of Gronk, this guy is right there. I think it's like three yards that separates them. He makes tough catches, he gets the ball in his hands, he makes plays, so [he's] definitely one of their best weapons offensively. So we'll have to know where he's at." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

"So it's going to be a more competitive game, I bet." "Well, the pressure's all going to be on them," Rodgers said. "They're coming off a tough loss at home against Seattle. Before that, they blew us out [38-8 on Dec. 27]. They're the Super Bowl favorites, and obviously the favorite team on Saturday night. So, we've just got to go out, be loose, let it all hang out, because the pressure's all on that side." "The pressure is only something you feel if you're not prepared," [Bruce Arians] said. author: Steve serby
summary: A: I was a diehard Giants fan. I friggin cried when [Lawrence Taylor] retired (laugh). He was it, man. I actually ended up meeting him once I got into the NFL. I was playing golf in Michael Jordan's golf tournament in the Bahamas. And sure enough, they paired me up with Lawrence Taylor. It's a childhood idol, this is the first time I ever met him. You can only imagine what happened on that first tee. I couldn't play golf great anyway at that time. But I was shaking in my boots. I'm sitting here playing golf with my childhood idol. ... I have to play with him for 18 holes and he's depending on me because it was like two-on-two like celebrity game. So it's kind of like his score and our score matters (laugh). He was shaking his head the whole 18 holes: "This guy's a hacker. He's horrible." I'm just looking at him, and I can't believe I'm actually on the same course, or the continent with this guy. A: I use it as fuel. The doubters, the people who feel like I can't do it. You got to have those people who doubt your ability, doubt your skills, for whatever reasons. You kind of have to use certain things sometimes to self-motivate. And for me it's been, for years: "He's undersized, he can't play the run, he can't get after the quarterback." Which is absolutely ridiculous. Because we're not playing basketball. From a basketball player, yeah, I need to be 6-8, I had to post up and friggin grab rebounds and block shots. But I'm not, this is not what we're doing here. I have to get Point B, I start at Point A. That's me. A: Well there's nothing like it from a professional standpoint. That's what you've been working for. Your goal was to win a championship. So just imagine, you know, you see a rainbow in the sky, you go to the end of the rainbow, there's a pot of gold sitting right there. It's something that you've been dreaming about, and it's finally come to fruition, and it's a complete total satisfaction. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: "He's athletic and mobile," [Terry Stotts] said. "It's been an adjustment more for him at the defensive end, adjusting to our style of defense because he likes to use [his] athleticism, and we are more of a conservative approach. Offensively, we have been giving him a lot more opportunities to do a lot of things, and he has been pretty good at it." The former Duke star had two productive seasons in Brooklyn, both resulting in trips to the playoffs. He averaged 8.1 points and 5.4 rebounds per contest during that time, but the combination of [Mason Plumlee] and center Brook [Robin Lopez] never matured into what the organization hoped. Interim Nets coach Tony Brown expected Lopez, at 275 pounds to Plumlee's 236, to be his team's biggest strength against the Blazers. "We've had a number of things that we have tried to do on game day, and maybe it just wasn't hitting home," Brown said. "Trying to simplify I think helps everybody as far as accountability." summary: Brooklyn interim coach Tony Brown was trying to get Brook Lopez, Joe Johnson, Wayne Ellington and Thaddeus Young back in after the Trail Blazers turned a six-point deficit into a five-point lead with 5:54 to play in the contest. Brown told his team to foul [Damian Lillard], Portland's point guard who had tortured the Nets all night, to allow for a substitution. "It was a smart play by him," Brown said. "Our guys were going to try to get the ball and try to foul him so he couldn't get off a shot. I take the credit for that one."  "It's still a work in progress," [Lopez] said. summary: "It's been great - my teammates, organization, other guys throughout the league, people from his team, people from other sports, people from the entertainment world," [Matt Barnes] said. "I've gotten a lot of support throughout the whole situation. Unfortunately, I got suspended. That's in the past. Now we are focused on playing against the players from the Knicks." Asked if [Derek Fisher] has done a better job, Barnes said: "We're focused on playing the Knicks. We're not worried about who's coaching them. Our focus is on Carmelo [[Anthony J. Causi]] and the rookie that they got who is playing amazing [Kristaps Porzingis] and [Arron] Afflalo and Derrick Williams. They got a talented team. That's what we're focused on right now. Barnes had called Fisher "a snake" and "snitch" in an Instagram post on New Year's Eve. After he went 6-for-6 from 3-point range and had a late steal in Thursday's win over Detroit, Barnes told The Commercial Appeal of Memphis this about the showdown with Fisher's team: "I know I've got to keep my mouth shut because [Fisher] will run and tell. We're really focused on playing that team. When I'm retired, him and I will cross paths." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: This tiff with [Clutterbuck] started when the Isles' fourth-line wing was tussling with the Rangers' skill players, Mats Zuccarello and Derick Brassard, behind the play. Clutterbuck also got into a verbal spat with Rangers trainer Jim Ramsay. Clutterbuck had said he and Ramsay "go back a long way," but a Rangers representative said Friday the two don't know each other at all.  "It's just calling him out," [Glass] said. "He's the toughest guy ever when it's Brassard and Zuccarello - and Ramsay - and I come around and he's a mute. So it's chicken. He wants to fight the little guys. He supposed to be physical player, a gritty player, then he's just silent when someone that actually might do something comes around? That's not how the game should be." "I can't say I'm doing it because it's the Islanders," Glass said. "I'd do it to anyone who acts like that in that situation."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Steve Cuozzo
summary: Raoul's is no Sarabeth's. Don't expect a torrent of fluffy-egg dishes. "Our chef, David Honeysett, and I wanted to avoid the eggs Benedict thing," says manager Karim Raoul, 37, whose father and uncle, Serge and Guy Raoul, founded (and still own) the place. "We wanted something different - not completely traditional." The star is Raoul's instant-classic hamburger, which - unlike at dinner, when a mere dozen are available, and only at the bar - can be enjoyed at tables. "We have maybe 25 or 30 of them at brunch," Karim says. The juice-oozing, au poivre-drenched Pat LaFrieda beef blend gives Minetta Tavern's exalted Black Label number a run for its money - and, at $23, it's $4 less than Minetta's. "It wasn't just the Dutch," Karim says. "I live upstairs. We own the building. And whenever I went out for my own brunch in the neighborhood, I'd have to wait an hour." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: BREAKFAST EPIPHANY After 4 decades of nighttime revelry, Soho stalwart Raoul's is finally brunching

author: James Covert
summary: Yahoo! on Friday fended off a shareholder salvo against Chief Executive Marissa Mayer, promising that she and the company's board will deliver "sustainable shareholder value." "Our board and management team have been and remain firmly committed to acting as good stewards of capital and delivering sustainable shareholder value," Yahoo! said in the statement. "We will share details on our future plans for Yahoo! on our upcoming earnings call." As of Friday's market close, that wasn't the case: Yahoo! shares lost 3.9 percent to close at $29.14 on Friday, giving the company a market cap of $27.5 billion. Yahoo!'s 15 percent stake in Alibaba was valued at about $25.7 billion on Friday, implying a value of $1.8 billion for Yahoo!'s core Internet businesses. author: Kevin Dugan
summary: The Fed, which had kept interest rates near zero for more than eight years through December and expanded its balance sheet to more than $14 trillion, is seen as being unable to do much to prop up the economy if there's another severe downturn, analysts said.  "This economy looks stuck in the mud, and with the Fed out of bullets and Washington on hold for the presidential election, there isn't anyone out there to ride to the rescue," Chris Rupkey, chief financial economist at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, said in his Friday note.  By midday, both Goldman Sachs and the Atlanta Fed had downgraded projected gross domestic product growth for the fourth quarter of 2015, with Goldman at 1.1 percent from a prior 1.4 percent and Atlanta now calling for 0.6 percent GDP growth versus 0.8 percent earlier. summary: How many times is the [Obama] administration going to let Iran poke its finger in America's eye, slap us in the face and laugh at us before we even release the $150 billion it'll be getting from us to help achieve its goal of "Death to America" ("Asking for Another Slap," Editorial, Jan. 14)?  Making our sailors get on their knees with their hands on their heads was just like a "perp walk" staged for the benefit of the media to show the world what they did to America. And America just asks for more - all so Obama can have his legacy with the Iran deal.  Iran captures one of our vessels, which drifted into its waters, holds the 10 sailors and forces them to their knees with hands folded behind their heads - and [John Kerry] proclaims that diplomacy works and we should be grateful to Iran? author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers - tweaking the Cardinals in a not-so-subtle game of psychological warfare in the lead-up to Saturday night's NFC divisional playoff game at University of Phoenix Stadium - was absolutely right when he said "all the pressure" was on the Cardinals. The Cardinals appeared to have sealed the game when they held the Packers on four downs on the ensuing possession. The Packers, with only one timeout and 2:42 remaining, went for a fourth-and-5 from their own 25 and Rodgers' pass to James Jones was low, skipping into his arms. What in the world?! After the Aaron Rodgers (inset top) connected with [Jeff Janis] on a 41-yard Hail Mary as time in regulation expired to tie the game, [Larry Fitzgerald] (inset left) and the Cardinals quickly answered in overtime with two big plays that culminated in Fitzgerald's 5-yard touchdown catch that sent Arizona to the NFC championship game. author: Brian Costello
summary: "You're not rooting too hard," [Tom Brady] said of next week's opponent. "Whatever happens, happens. Whether we play here or whether we play there, we're going to have to play really well. I think that's what it comes down to. They're two great football teams. We've played them both already, and it's going to take our best effort to beat them." New England bounced back from injuries and a week filled with distractions to dominate Kansas City, who had their 11-game winning streak snapped. The final score may not reflect it, but this game never felt in doubt and the Patriots are going for another Super Bowl. "We work our butts off to get into the playoffs and give ourselves a chance," safety Devin McCourty said. "You saw tonight. It wasn't pretty. It's not easy. To me, it means everything. You put all this work in to get to the playoffs and try to get to the AFC Championship. We're there now." The Patriots entered the games surrounded with questions about injuries and linebacker Chandler Jones, who was involved in a bizarre incident last weekend where he allegedly showed up at the Foxborough Police Department high. That led to a week about questions that Patriots coach Bill Belichick, who had a mysterious black eye of his own, deflected. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. "I think we made it tougher than it should have been, especially in the end," [Bruce Arians] said. "Most teams would have probably played prevent and that's what [defensive coordinator James Betcher] was going to play and I said, 'Hell no, let's blitz him.' And he made a great throw." "Come on, man, it sucks," linebacker Clay Matthews said. "You play this game to win Super Bowls. That is what greatness is defined by in this sport. Losing in that fashion, especially with the offense pulling that out with another Hail Mary is unbelievable." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: Yet the Packers beget the Steelers, who beget the Niners, who beget the Cowboys. And so we have these Patriots, and history is very insistent about this: Someday we'll see another team that takes our breath away and breaks out hears in equal measure. Time didn't stop when Vince Lombardi stepped down, when Terry Bradshaw retired, when Joe Montana got hurt, when Jerry Jones started to outsmart himself in Dallas. These are different times than those were, and this is a different game, a different sport than it was in the 1960s, the '70s, even the '90s. Fifty years of enforced parity was supposed to render it impossible for the Patriots to do what they've been doing, what they keep doing, what it looks like they'll keep doing until and unless they finally grow bored with the grind. This is 15 years they've been doing this now. Lombardi's Packers, they didn't even have a 10-year run. The Montana Niners, their shelf life was 1981-90. A good decade. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: THE SAME AS IT EVER WAS Appreciate amazing run before its too late

summary: "I don't think there's a hotter quarterback in the league right now than [Russell Wilson] - the tape validates that," ESPN analyst Ron Jaworski said last week. "You watch him play from the pocket, you watch the exquisite timing that he now has with his receiving corps. You're just starting to see the intelligence meet the talent." That game marked the turnaround of the Seahawks' season and seemingly Wilson's career as a passer. Already a dangerous runner, Wilson quieted critics of his arm by throwing 25 TD passes and just two INTs in the past eight games - one of the best stretches in NFL history and a big reason he ended up leading the league with a 110.1 passer rating. summary: There is added irony in the fact [Peyton Manning] will be the healthier quarterback, with Ben Roethlisberger forced to suck it up with a shoulder bludgeoned by Vontaze Burfict, and without the services of the wondrous Antonio Brown (concussion), the other Burfict victim, who torched cornerback Chris Harris in the Steelers' 34-27 win last month at Heinz Field. A compromised Big Ben, without Brown and without DeAngelo Williams against this elite Orange Crush defense, ought to make life easier for Manning, who is no longer equipped to win shootouts, and could use as much help as possible from his ground game. "I just wanted to do my job and do my job well," Manning said afterward. "I didn't think I needed to be super. I just needed to be good." "In the playoffs, you certainly just want to do your job to help your team win, no matter how old you are or how long you've been playing," Manning said. "There's no difference. It's an exciting time and never take for granted this opportunity." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "I've been here for 21 years-ever since I've been here our coaches, our head coach and our personnel have always been part of the process with personnel. That won't change," [Jerry Reese] said. "They're always a part of it. At the end of the day, it's my responsibility. If somebody doesn't get it right, if somebody doesn't pan out, it's the GM's responsibility, OK? It seems like we got that confused the last time, but it's my responsibility if somebody doesn't work out. Everybody is part of the process, OK? You guys got that?"  "We're looking at what we've done personnelwise, where we have made the mistakes in the draft, and why we have missed on guys," [John Mara] said. "Are our standards too rigid, or are they not rigid enough? Let's look at that and figure out what we need to improve, and do we need some additional people down there or do we need to make some changes? I know what our roster looks like and I know it has to get a heck of a lot better if we're going to put the fifth [Super Bowl] trophy in the case." Reese said he and [Tom Coughlin] had "a great relationship" and promised, "[Ben McAdoo] and I will do the same." As far as changes to the structure under him, Reese was tightlipped. author: STEVE SERBY
summary: A: I don't know if you can say it in one line in my opinion. It's someone being comfortable in their own skin. It's someone who takes the common sense approach to things where they're able to be themselves, they're able to get the best out of people, they're able to set expectations high, and really lead in a way that it keeps other people hold themselves accountable, and you only step in when you need to step in. A: That's an easy question: It's identity. They're sound fundamentally, they're smart, they're always in a position to be successful. ... They're tough, not just physically but emotionally and mentally. They're disciplined, they're dedicated, and they're committed to poise. And I think someone who's comfortable being uncomfortable in a pressure situation is important. And it's hard to know sometimes until you get to a Sunday, in either bad weather, or hot weather, or whatever it may be, in the fourth quarter when guys are pushing on each other for 60 minutes. Sometimes that's when the magic happens with these guys. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: Until now, through 49 Super Bowls, just five coaches have even ever worn facial hair: Mike Ditka (patron saint of the porn stache), Mike Holmgren (patron saint of the walrus stache), Bill Cowher (who has sported the Van Dyke/goatee from time to time, just not the day in Detroit when he won Super Bowl XL), Tony Dungy and Mike Tomlin (the only man with a beard to hoist the Lombardi Trophy, named for a man who would absolutely not have approved of a Van Dyke, a goatee or even a pencil-thin mustache for members of the coaching fraternity). If it's not to be for him, or for the Cardinals, then here's to you, [Ben McAdoo]. Actually, in what only can be termed a golden age for the goatee (and the Van Dyke) in New York City football circles, McAdoo now officially can engage in a personal race against Jets general manager Mike Maccagnan to see who (if either) can be first to hold a Super Bowl press conference sporting a goatee (or a Van Dyke). Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Hair-raising moment World awaits first Lombardi hoist by goatee'd coach

author: Brian Lewis
summary: "What I told them is I want to see a little bit more fight," [Tony Brown] said. "When you get into adversity, things are not going your way, it's easy to not do as much. We've got some guys not playing their best basketball, but they have to fight their way out of these situations. I can sit there all day and talk to them, run plays for them, but you've got to reach deep down and see how bad you want it. "During hard stretches hard times, can't make a shot, you can't just quit. That's what his message was. It was a powerful message and it hit home to a few guys." "I want to see some of our bench guys have an impact on a game and right now we're not seeing a lot of that," said Brown. "Right now we don't have a lot of soldiers and they're going to get an opportunity to play, but I can't continue to see them play this way and not consider making some changes. ... I want to see them play with a bit more passion. But some soul searching needs to be done here." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: Interim coach rips into Nets after latest flop

author: Brian Lewis
summary: ATLANTA - Nets owner Mikhail Prokhorov can change regimes all he wants - and firing coach Lionel Hollins last week was warranted - but he can't change his team's bad habit of rolling over. In interim coach Tony Brown's first game on Monday, the Nets were slaughtered by the Spurs. In his fourth game, they got hammered again by a Hawks team that was built in the Spurs' image, by former Gregg Popovich assistant Mike Budenholzer. Joe Johnson had 14 points and showed continued signs of breaking out of his malaise. ... Willie Reed missed Friday's game because of personal reasons. He joined the team Saturday nighta and was active, but didn't play. ... Sergey Karasev (sprained ankle) and Bargnani (sore right ankle) were injured during the game. We're all a basketball family. We'll see how many Knicks fans there are tonight."  "It's another game," Fisher said. "We're trying to win this game. [Carmelo Anthony] will be out so it will be more interesting for us as far as preparation, but we're here trying to win. The benefit of me playing as long as I did is I've seen it all." title: Barnes' harsh words for Fisher: 'Stay away from me'

author: Brian Lewis
summary: "I feel comfortable making calls, but I don't want to be up there doing that the whole time. We have enough offensive schemes in place that I don't necessarily have to do that," [Tony Brown] said. "Once our point guards get a better feel for what I'm looking for as far as the pace, what we need to run, I won't have to say a whole lot. "We talked to [Donald Sloan] and [Shane Larkin] to give them a cheat sheet of things they can call on the fly - especially on misses, or the other team is shooting free throws they can communicate to the team while they have a chance, not necessarily waiting for me to make a call," Brown said. "They already have a cheat sheet, like a football quarterback when he's got the wristband. ... It's that same mindframe - giving them something they can take more control of the team while they're on the floor." "His pace [was impressive]," Brown said. "He's been playing with good pace, so a lot of the stuff that we run, he's able to come off attacking. I think once he's coming off attacking, his ability to get it in the paint draws defenders and things start opening up for him. When he's doing that, we generally get some good looks. author: Marc Berman
summary: The Knicks weren't a failure in the season's mathematical first half. But they're not in playoff position either, stuck in 10th place. The bar has been set so low by coach Derek Fisher after last season's 17-65 humiliation that a 20-21 mark at the 41-game midpoint has the fan base in good spirits. There's nothing to nitpick about the 7-foot-3 Latvian's rookie season. Despite everything being new - from culture to language to learning a new basketball system - Porzingis has mastered it. He has been an instinctive shot-blocking machine, a highlight reel on the offensive glass and recently finding his confidence from 3-point range - his greatest big-man skill. A solid, well-liked teammate, engaging with fans and media, he has made it look easy in averaging 13.9 points and 8.0 rebounds, becoming the first player to make both 40 3-pointers and 75 blocks in his first 40 games. He is showing the makings of a superstar. After missing the first eight games, [Arron Afflalo] usually is the second scoring option and Anthony's wingman like in Denver. The Knicks are 10-3 when he scores 15-plus points, showing how vital he is to team success. Just needs a touch more consistency, but his scoring average (14.0) has made the signing [Phil Jackson]'s second-best offseason move. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: GRADING ON A CURVE Knicks improved from 17-win disaster

author: Brian Lewis
summary: After resetting his team last Sunday by canning coach Lionel Hollins and removing GM Billy King, owner Mikhail Prokhorov admitted the tough lessons he has learned. NBA commissioner Adam Silver backed the Russian, telling reporters in London on Thursday "there are no shortcuts to building winning franchises in the NBA. It's step-by-step, and I think that's a process he is willing to go through it now." The consummate pro, a playoff vet and good chemistry guy, he would have value on a winner. But he's 34, the NBA's second-highest paid player at $24.9 million, and averaging just 11.3 points on 38.1 percent shooting. His career is an A. But this season's production and salary are graded here. It's hard to say if the Nets are better under Brown, but they clearly are happier. Talk to anybody in the locker room and it's clear Hollins' negative vibe left a pall over the room. Creating a more positive atmosphere and fixing the team's psyche will be Brown's first chore. summary: Think of it. author: George Willis
summary: "There's just something about the heavyweights," [Brett Yormark] said. "One of the things we were able to do is play to the history. We've marketed the fact that since there hasn't been a heavyweight title fight in Brooklyn in 115 years you might want to come out and see it. I think it worked. The heavyweights are great for excitement and anticipation and the fact there are two of them make it that much better." "I'm talking eight big shows, major championship nights," Yormark said. "It's all about dates. It's not just about the building. It's whether you can coordinate will all the different parties; the promoters, the fighters, the broadcast partner." "I'm a big fan of [Deontay Wilder]," Yormark said. "He's certainly on a mission to accomplish that. I'm not sure if [Saturday] is the first step to that, but in due time if he stays active, he has a really good shot. Most importantly, it's what he wants. He's a very confident young man and he has a great conviction. When he wants something he goes for it. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: George Willis
summary: "He gave me a great fight," [Deontay Wilder] said. "It's been 115 years since there was a heavyweight title fight [in Brooklyn]. I did what I wanted to do. I gave the people a knockout." That was more action than the early going to Wilder's fight with [Artur Szpilka]. The first four rounds were spent with each fighter trying to draw the other into his game plan. Szpilka, a southpaw, was 4 inches shorter than the 6-foot-7 Wilder, and used constant movement trying to get inside his taller opponent's reach. Wilder seemed content to wait to counter when Szpilka got within striking distance. Szpilka (20-2, 15 KOs) had a good round in the seventh, rocking the champion with a sharp right hand. But Wilder also landed a hard right that Szpilka initially weathered. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: Gen. John Kelly, USMC, is retiring after more than four decades as an active-duty Marine. His "greatest fear," he says, is that the vast "equal opportunity" pressure for women in combat roles will lead the Pentagon to water down standards. Kelly doubts that will last: "Whether it's 12 months from now, four years from now . . . the question will be asked whether we've [truly] let women into these other roles." Ideologues who don't see the results they want will ask, "Why aren't [women] staying in those roles? Why aren't they advancing as infantry people?" On top of that, he's ordered the Marines to adopt politically correct titles by changing every "man" label. That implies the Marines are about to lose every "rifleman" - when every Marine is a rifleman.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: A Marine's No. 1 Fear EDITORIAL

author: Kyle Smith
summary: One of the final, devastating, images in the Benghazi film "13 Hours" is of an American flag lying in a pool of filthy water and debris after the jihadi raid on two American outposts in Libya. As the movie was shown to New York critics Tuesday night, President Obama was giving his "Everything Is Awesome" State of the Union speech, droning the words, "Anyone claiming that America's economy is in decline is peddling fiction . . . The United States of America is the most powerful nation on Earth, period. Period. It's not even close. It's not even close. It's not even close." In "13 Hours," the officious CIA station chief in Benghazi who stands in for every technocrat you've ever met tells the brawny security contractors who will soon save him from death, "You're hired help. There is no real threat here. We won the revolution for these people." He thinks he can't be wrong because "We have the brightest minds from the Farm - educated at Harvard and Yale." A lady spy with a French accent who works in Benghazi tells one of the security contractors (ex-military men), "I know what I'm doing" because it's her second tour in a war zone. A contractor replies laconically, "It's my 12th."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: 'They're laughing at us' '13 Hours' captures what Americans really feel about our standing in the world

author: Michael Gray
summary: Yet the Obama administration is the first two-term presidency that has not posted a 3-percent GDP growth on an annualized basis for 8 years. Even Franklin Delano Roosevelt posted 3 percent growth year during the Great Depression.  Obama bragged about the economy in the State of the Union, pointing to the low unemployment rate. But under this White House's job-recovery program, the US added roughly 1.5 million bartenders and wait staff, while losing an equal number of manufacturing jobs, according to Job Creators Network figures.  The United States has "the strongest, most durable economy in the world," Obama boasted Tuesday. But only for the few. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Michael Goodwin
summary: Fortunately, Thursday's GOP debate showed without doubt that, despite other fault lines among them, the seven major candidates are united in their conviction that [Obama] is dead wrong. The contenders took turns blasting Obama's failure to even acknowledge the role of Islam, and promised to destroy Islamic State instead of merely trying to contain it. The emerging clarity on the Democratic side comes with a twist. The dead heat in Iowa between [Hillary Clinton] and Sen. Bernie Sanders adds to the belief that Clinton is going backward. She's behind in New Hampshire, and her team is touting a "firewall" in the South, suggesting they are lowering public expectations and their own goals for the first two tests. Coming on top of the widespread doubts about Clinton's integrity and the greater enthusiasm among Sanders' supporters, the FBI probe has the potential to fatally wound her. Even the stock-market chaos and economic slowdown work against her because of her long ties to Wall Street, and because of Sanders' socialist screeds. Although the RealClearPolitics average of national polls has her ahead by nearly 9 points, a Sanders win in both Iowa and New Hampshire would shatter any sense of inevitability.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Robert Rorke
summary: Paul Dano is terrific as foolish, idealistic Prince Pierre Bezukhov on "War and Peace," premiering Monday. Former "Downton Abbey" co-star Lily James as Natasha in "War and Peace."The story traces the fortunes of two men, the idealistic Prince Pierre Bezukhov (Paul Dano) and the haughty Prince Andrei Bolknosky (James Norton), in 1805 Russia, when Napoleon's advance through Europe served as a giant wake-up call. Each man takes a knock, Andrei in the Battle of Austerlitz, Pierre on the battlefield of love. After he inherits a fortune, Pierre is preyed upon by a gold-digging hussy and her avaricious father. Marriage for both men is a disaster. Andrei's wife dies in childbirth. Pierre's Helene banishes him from the bedroom. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: "Nobody wants to see me dance," [Carson Palmer] said. "I hug; I don't dance." There were countless hugs to be doled out Saturday night, but the first went to Palmer's top receiver, Larry Fitzgerald. All he did was carry the only franchise he's played for in his 12 seasons on his back in the second half, scoring the game-winning touchdown in overtime moments after he'd gained 75 yards on an incredible catch-and-run. "That's not my place," he said. "I'm a player." Teammates said they "could see it in his eyes" how much "he wanted it" in the second half. "I'm so happy for him," said tight end Jermaine Gresham, who played with Palmer in Cincinnati. "Words can't describe it. He was just even-keeled all the way through. Even after we won, he was in here telling us, 'We got work to do next week. We can't be satisfied with this.' Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. There are only four teams playing next week, and we're one of them. And that game means a lot, so we've got to try to get as healthy as we can and see if we can put together our best game of the year." "You know it's definitely as a grind, but they come in here, like this group, and I've said this the last couple of years, too, these guys come in here every day, their pencils are sharpened, they're sitting right there in those seats, they're ready to go, they're attentive, they want to learn, they want to know how to get better, they want to compete and they just do that on a daily basis. I got to respond to that and find new ways how to score." "I get frustrated when I'm missing shots and didn't do everything I need to for the shot to go in," said Porzingis, averaging 13.9 points and eight rebounds. author: Larry Brooks
summary: Coach Alain Vigneault kept the Marc Staal-Dan Girardi pair intact while pairing [Dylan McIlrath] with Keith Yandle and Dan Boyle with Ryan McDonagh. The Caps chose to match the Alex Ovechkin-Nicklas Backstrom-T.J. Oshie top unit against Staal and Girardi in a case where each team got the matchup it preferred. The [Derek Stepan] line accounted for the goal that gave the Rangers a 1-0 lead at 10:17 of the first off a left-wing draw won by the Blueshirts' center. McDonagh's low drive was tipped in by [Chris Kreider] for his second goal in as many games after the winger had scored just once in the previous 11. The Rangers - and the Staal-Girardi pair - were strong against the Ovechkin line. McIlrath was physical at even-strength and on the penalty kill. But [Brassard] took a senseless holding the stick penalty that allowed the Caps to go on the power play, on which Ovechkin struck from the left circle to tie the match at 18:01 after sidestepping McIlrath in the left circle. author: Zach Braziller
summary: Duke and Kentucky are, naturally, perfect examples. While both remain Sweet 16 contenders, neither look like Final Four shoe-ins, as many predicted in November. Skal Labissiere, Kentucky's 6-foot-11 freshman, is the poster child, playing so far below his predicted impact, but he isn't alone. Fellow Kentucky freshman Isaiah Briscoe has struggled, too, and even the Wildcats best freshman - Jamal Murray - hasn't exactly played up to his lofty draft stock, despite averaging a team-leading 17.8 points per game.  The best teams in the country, the teams you would pencil in for the Final Four at this moment, don't rely on freshmen. Oklahoma and Kansas, Michigan State and Maryland, Villanova and North Carolina, have some talented first-year players, players who are nothing more than minor contributors. They rely on upperclassmen. Aside from [Ben Simmons], the national player of the year contenders are rife with years of college basketball experience - players such as Providence's Kris Dunn, Oklahoma's Buddy Hield, North Carolina's Brice Johnson, and the list goes on.  It will sadly be remembered for Jordan Washington's open-hand slap to the face of Monmouth's Chris Brady that forced the Gaels to suspend Washington two games. More discipline from the MAAC could be on the way. But I'd like to remember what proceeded it, the kind of basketball that was worthy of the national broadcast. Here's hoping these teams play twice more - Feb. 19 at Monmouth and again in the MAAC Tournament.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Fresh baked Hyped newcomers not living up to their lofty billing

author: Kirsten Fleming
summary: When it comes to makeup, [Theresa Caputo] favors a toned-down look with neutral colors, letting her hair and nails steal the show. Her favorite brands range from prestige to drugstore. "I love Chanel foundation because it's good on-camera," she says, "but then I will use Maybelline mascara." Caputo has her hair trimmed every two weeks at ID Salon in Woodbury, LI. At home, she sprays Milbon styling mist on the roots, uses a leave-in treatment (CHI "Silk Infusion") at the top, and blows her locks dry before putting in rollers. She then hits the bottoms with a flat iron and finishes with Matrix hair spray. "My hairdresser says people will say, 'I want my hair like Theresa's,' " Caputo says. summary: The Weekly Standard, as if to run and hide from the GOP chaos, runs a cover story about architect Frank Gehry. It's actually a great, in-depth profile (a welcome distraction?). Likewise, there are excellent book columns, and a smart-but-sad feature on Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel (Will he resign? "Who cares? Chicago's problems run much deeper than one bad mayor.") Which is why it's such a shame that the magazine's provocatively titled editorial, "Neither [Hillary Clinton] nor Trump" is such a dud. Editor William Kristol weeps and moans that it will be all over for the nation if Hillary or [Donald J. Trump] is elected president before concluding, lamely, that somehow it won't. We'll need more to stem the supposedly sinister tide of "New York values" than this, William. The New Yorker's Jane Mayer fires off her latest salvo against the Koch Brothers, alleging they are mounting an aggressive PR campaign to mend their image. Last week, the New York Times ran a piece from her upcoming, Koch-roasting book that accused their father of doing business with the Nazis. Now, she's spotlighting the Koch's funding for criminal justice reform - reducing prison sentences for nonviolent drug offenders, for example. As Mayer desperately searches for the dark side of this, she comes up short, citing praise of the Kochs from none other than Obama's senior adviser Valerie Jarrett. Van Jones, a prominent criminal-justice-reform advocate, says, "If you're sitting in prison right now you're not praying that the Koch brothers won't help." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: He would be pained, no doubt, by the fact that we have yet to fully realize his dream of a time when people would be judged solely "by the content of their character" and "not on the color of their skin." For King's was a universal message of equality and dignity for all: "Let us not seek to satisfy our thirst for freedom by drinking from the cup of bitterness and hatred," he warned.  Then, too, we nowadays largely idealize his crusade - forgetting the issues that made him even more controversial: his opposition to militarism; his denunciation of America as "the greatest purveyor of violence in the world today"; his warning that the greatest threat to black progress was "the white moderate who is more devoted to 'order' than to racial justice." author: Michael Starr
summary: Once I left my old job I wanted to take a year off ... to take my face off TV for a while. I wanted to do something completely different on Netflix than what I was doing on E! - without trying to turn myself into Barbara Walters or making a complete ass out of myself. I thought I'd pick four subjects [for the "Chelsea Does" documentaries] that interested me. The shows I love are "Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel" and "60 Minutes," so I want to do a faster, cooler, informational version of those shows. And I want it to have personality. I want to educate the audience and myself and be well-rounded - but without pranks or impersonations. It won't have an "SNL" vibe. It's just me at the helm, giving people news. We're not going to have a set format with a monologue and desk and two guests and a band. There are so many shows like that on now that it makes my head bleed. "Everything about marriage always kind of sickened me, other than the commitment itself." - -[Chelsea Handler] on the "Chelsea Does Marriage" episode of her documentary seriesReproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "There was a lot of bad out there," Porzingis admitted. "But it won't be so bad if we're able to learn from it." Pretty sage advice from a kid who wasn't here last season and has no reason to accept any medals for trying. That's a good thing. And so is this: With so many people looking at the Knicks and seeing a potential playoff team, it's time to treat them that way, time to hand them their big-boy pants and judge them as you would any other team with playoff aspirations. No more asterisks. No more curves. Just because patience has been the order of the season thus far doesn't mean the Knicks' faithful are required to become Stepford Fans. That's one of the necessary elements that follows from a first half to the season that provided genuine hope, that uncovered Kristaps Porzingis as a star in waiting (exhale, by the way: He insists the foot he tweaked Monday will be fine), that proved Arron Afflalo could be a legitimate second scorer to Anthony (even if sometimes it seems Melo hasn't gotten the memo), that has seen them stay mostly competitive even on nights they're out-matched.
