author: Fred Kerber
summary: "I looked up, and the lead kept getting cut and cut and cut," [Carmelo Anthony] said. "I knew it was going to be a longer night." For everybody. The Knicks ended their losing streak, outlasting the NBA-worst Sixers, 119-113 in two overtimes as Anthony logged 49 minutes during the Martin Luther King Jr. Day matinee. It wasn't pretty, it certainly wasn't easy, and it appeared costly as rookie Kristaps Porzingis exited late in the fourth quarter with a right foot injury. "The game was never really over," Knicks coach Derek Fisher said. "They just kept playing." For the Sixers (5-38), Jahlil Okafor (20 points) was an offensive force early. Ish Smith (16 points, 16 assists, despite 8-of-28 shooting) was a penetrating machine. Nerlens Noel (18 points) was a second-half brute, and the likes of Isaiah Canaan (16 points) and Robert Covington (11 points) continually hit big shots. Okafor came out in the third quarter and never returned as Philadelphia coach Brett Brown went with small-ball-and Noel. "I live for moments like that." Canaan missed a desperate heave, and the first overtime saw more of the roller-coaster scenario. The Sixers went up four behind Smith. The Knicks rallied and, on 7-of-7 free-throw shooting, led by three with under 10 seconds left. This time, Covington pulled the "Great Escape" act and banked a 25-footer with 7.4 seconds left. Anthony missed a potential game-winner inside the foul line. On to Overtime No. 2. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: SCAREHEADS! Knicks let up, then need 2OT to beat NBA-worst Sixers

summary: "We did a good job of taking care of the ball a majority of the second half," said Brook Lopez, who had a team-high 29 points and 10 boards while Joe Johnson added 22. "That's how they made their run in the first half, and that's how they ended the game. Our turnovers really hurt us." "We got a little careless with the ball, in some instances trying to make the right play, trying to make the right reads. Some of them just weren't there," [Donald Sloan] said. "They did a good job with their hands getting deflections, and had a couple run-outs. That got the momentum going their way, and we just never recovered." "They got into us a little more defensively. Some of the passes we were making were challenged," said [Tony Brown], praising Lopez and Johnson. "We're still searching. We need one, two, three more guys to give us something and maybe we can cut some of the runs teams are making on us." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: STEVE SERBY
summary: A generational quarterback duel, as John Elway's Broncos look to redeem themselves from their Super Bowl XLVIII blowout against the Seahawks. Then there is Demaryius Thomas' mother, recently released from prison, getting to watch her son play in a Super Bowl, the Panthers trying to win their first Super Bowl, and DeMarcus Ware trying to win his first. The potential for a double-digit Pats victory with [Bill Belichick] having two weeks to devise a plan for Newton. Kill the head and the body dies. Newton has a history of being a big-game player, but he'd be better off playing ball control with [Jonathan Stewart]'s help to keep [Tom Brady] off the field. By Super Sunday, we'll likely be tired of hearing [Josh Norman] and Co. rail on and on about a lack of respect. At least, that part of the viewing audience that will be rooting against the Patriots will be. author: Bart Hubbuch
summary: Not only does that extend [Tom Brady]'s all-time NFL record (Joe Montana is a distant second with seven career appearances), but Brady now has more title-game trips than 27 other teams. "It's beyond what I'd ever imagined in my wildest dreams," Brady said Monday during an appearance on WEEI radio in Boston. "I remember the first one I ever participated in, which was in Pittsburgh. ... Fifteen years later, to be a part of 10 of those, I never imagined that any of this was ever even possible. Peyton Manning has what looks to be one last chance to get the better of Brady on Sunday, but their "rivalry" will still end up in the record books decidedly in Brady's favor. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "I said, 'You need to surround yourself with experienced people,' " [John Mara] said by way of advice to [Ben McAdoo]. "He's smart enough to understand and I think he will surround himself with the right people, and he's got a great resource in [Steve Spagnuolo] here who's been a head coach. I'm sure Steve will help him a little bit." McAdoo's coaching staff has yet to take full shape, but it is already clear it will not resemble [Tom Coughlin]'s crew. McAdoo wanted to add former Dolphins head coach Joe Philbin to work with the quarterbacks, but Philbin was hired by the Colts. Mike Sullivan, a Coughlin favorite, is expected to be promoted to offensive coordinator from quarterbacks coach. For a new quarterbacks coach, McAdoo, according to FOX Sports, may turn to Frank Cignetti, the former Rams offensive coordinator. Cignetti was a coach at Indiana University of Pennsylvania when McAdoo was a student at the school. Offensive assistant Ryan Roeder, a former quarterback at Albany, is an in-house candidate for the quarterbacks coach role. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "The surgery is definitely going to help me a lot," [Jason Pierre-Paul] said on Dec. 30. "I can't grip out of my middle finger, it can't close right now. That's the reason why I'm in the club. Once I have my surgery I'll be fine. I'm excited to actually get it done. Something I knew I had to get done at the end of the season." "My guess is, let's face it, the Good Lord gave us fingers and a thumb for a reason," defensive coordinator Steve Spagnuolo said late in the season. "In this game, it's good to have two hands to do things. When you've got one that you don't use, there's got to be times when it's a disadvantage." "I don't think it's going to be a major issue," he said. "My hand hasn't stopped me from playing. It's stopped me from doing a couple of things but in reality that will be fixed." author: Larry Brooks
summary: If THE 2013-14 and 2014-15 Rangers were called Zed, do you know what we'd be saying right now? Zed's dead, baby; Zed's dead. It's interesting, isn't it? Somehow, even with an offensive zone start percentage of 61.9 that is seventh-highest in the NHL among defensemen ([Keith Yandle]'s 69.6 percent leads the league), [Dan Boyle] has the fewest number of even-strength points (two goals, two assists, four points) among the Rangers' six regulars on the blue line. He basically speaks in a canned two-answers-fit-all loop. Doesn't make [Alain Vigneault] a bad guy - he is far from that - but you know almost nothing more about the team after talking with him than beforehand. So you're left grasping for answers, much like the Rangers are grasping for solutions. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Kevin Kernan
summary: "We've got a great team coming back. Our pitching staff is going to keep us in games," [Michael Conforto] told The Post this week from his home in Redmond, Wash. "I think we have some really good bats. I think we're all very, very excited to try to make it back to that World Series and finish it the right way this year." "She always told me whatever you are doing, whether it's sports or something else in life you want to do, you have to obsess over it," Conforto said. "You have to make it something that is very, very important to you. That's how you become great. That's where the work comes in and making it a priority over everything else, and it's really helped me. "When we're done with our work we like to meet up with old teachers, old coaches. There are so many of them around this area," Conforto said. "I really love it here. This time of year it's raining and gloomy, but growing up here, especially in baseball, there is a different aspect to the players who grow up here and play in the rain a bit. You really got to want to be out there." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: David Kaufman
summary: The extra "push," mentally and physically, is what drew Jennifer Haykin, 30, to the extreme classes at Row House, where she works out at least three times per week. Although the regular 50-minute rows "certainly leave me tired and sweaty, I wanted to get more out of being there," says Haykin, who works in ad sales and lives on the Upper East Side. In December, she was the first woman to complete the half-marathon row, clocking in at 93 minutes.  These extended workouts are not without perils. Any sort of double training can place one at serious risk of overtraining syndrome, says professor Susan Vannucci, Ph.D., of the Brain and Mind Research Institute at Weill Cornell Medical College. "[The syndrome] can cause fatigue, mood swings and even impact your immune system," she says. "Double workouts should not be avoided by any means, but get proper rest, drink lots of fluids and be very mindful of any adverse warning signs." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: "Historically, the rate of Type 2 has been higher among African-Americans and Hispanic populations, and lower incomes," says dietitian and nutritionist Cher Pastore. "So some people may think, 'That's not me.' But that's changing." [Rob Kardashian] may not fit those categories, but he checks one of the most important boxes: He'd gained weight - by some accounts, around 100 pounds over the past couple of years. "The first step is usually lifestyle modification - changing the way they eat, losing weight." This isn't always easy for young patients. "They feel that they can do whatever they want, because [they think] diseases like diabetes aren't going to happen for many years," [Amy Stephens] says. Additionally, one of the biggest changes [Erik Rosales] implemented was to switch from soda to water: "Don't drink calories," [Louis J. Aronne] says. "How simple is that?" author: JOHNNY OLEKSINSKI
summary: Efron's hourlong workouts often happen after a day of filming, when [Williamson] meets the actor at a local gym. For abs, Efron will do what Williamson calls "blood volume training," or three exercises back-to-back-to-back to increase blood flow to the muscles. "[[Zac Efron]'s] to the point where he'll have an alarm set when it's time to eat," Williamson says. And what's on the menu? He'll start off the day with - shocker! - carbs. But not pasta or bread - think oatmeal, sweet potatoes and quinoa. For lunch and dinner, the grub is healthy fats, veggies and lean protein: avocados, almond butter and chicken. The trim actor steers clear of processed foods, sodium and added sugar. "It's part of who he is now," Williamson says. "He got bit by the bug." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: haley Goldberg
summary: "I was so constipated and miserable," she says. "My stomach was always grumbling, and I was hungry. [At first] I wouldn't eat anything that wasn't naturally gluten-free, and then I would [eat] gluten-free pretzels and gluten-free bread and bagels, and it just wasn't doing it. It was just adding more weight on, and I felt so bloated." Nutritionist Peter Osborne, author of the forthcoming book "No Grain, No Pain," falls into the anti-gluten camp. He believes the protein can lead to problems with the thyroid, skin and joints. "There's no harm in not eating gluten or grain," he says, shrugging off contrary claims. "It's like any field of science: There are always two sides." "We've had a lot of times when they ask, 'Is this a preference for you?' " she says. "But going out now isn't nearly as scary as when we started [going gluten-free]. I can take my son to Disneyland now." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: GLUTEN IS NOT THE ENEMY The fad diet is all the rage - but it can lead to weight gain and vitamin deficiencies, warn experts

author: John Crudele
summary: Politicians and Wall Street would like you believe that the economic problems in our country are all related to China. This gives them a scapegoat: "We were having steady growth until China's economy collapsed. It's China's fault." More importantly, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta thinks the economy grew at an annual rate of just 0.6 percent in the fourth quarter. The Atlanta Fed's GDPNow estimate is about as official as you'll get until the actual figure is announced by the Commerce Department on Jan. 29.  Why are investors reacting negatively to the slowing economy now, even though we've gone through this before? Mainly because "bad news was good news" all those other times - meaning, if the economy showed weakness, investors were sure the Federal Reserve would ride to its rescue and keep interest rates down through trickery like quantitative easing (QE). author: Robert A George
summary: In last week's debate, Marco Rubio lit into [Ted Cruz] with a lengthy harangue of supposed flip-flops on immigration, trade, ethanol and other issues. Rubio charged Cruz was no "consistent conservative." In short, Rubio was calling Cruz out as being politically "slick."  Clinton wasn't always universally beloved in his own party - and for similar "me-first" reasons. There was major pushback when he and other moderate (primarily Southern) senators and governors formed the Democratic Leadership Council after the party's far-left wing led it to electoral wipeouts in 1972 (when Clinton worked on the McGovern campaign), 1980, 1984 and 1988. Jesse Jackson dismissed the DLC as "Democrats for the Leisure Class."  Same goes for foreign policy: Cruz has played up his criticism of "neo-cons" - a tactic that lets him criticize both the more explicitly hawkish Marco Rubio and [Hillary Clinton] (a two-fer much like "New York values" works against Hillary and The Donald simultaneously). It's a nod to the Rand Paul libertarians and the Pat Buchanan paleo-conservatives at the same time. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: The Clintonian Cruz How Ted's just like Slick Willy

author: Ken Davidoff
summary: In good conscience, [Cespedes] can't come back to New York if a $100 million gap exists between the Mets' best offer and that of other suitors. That might very well come to fruition in the next few days; with both Upton ($132.75 million) and Chris Davis ($161 million, including deferred money, from the Orioles) off the board, only Cespedes can keep Cespedes from cashing in very shortly. Love, to get back to [Terry Collins]' words, is in the eye of the beholder, and the Mets understandably still behold only vague mentions of a short-term deal with their prized 2015 trade acquisition. On Tuesday night, Mets general manager Sandy Alderson told season-ticket holders, "We continue to have conversations with Cespedes' agent. That's all I can say at this time," according to the Mets' Twitter feed. These are the Mets, which means that of course their own rental-stud Cespedes takes the longest to sign - intensifying the desires of rabid Mets fans who, understandably again, just don't trust the folks who operate the club's purse strings. Of course they did everything right to land their top choice Ben Zobrist besides 1) not hiring Zobrist's old manager Joe Maddon a year ago and 2) not moving their team closer to the Nashville area where Zobrist makes his offseason home, and they therefore get zero credit. summary: "I really believe this - a lot of people might disagree with me, which is fine - but I really think 5-on-5, we're playing a lot better, both defensively and offensively," [Alain Vigneault] said. "Specialty teams are having some issues. Again, that's on me. I'm the one that signs off on everything. We have to do a better job there, and we will. We'll continue to work at it and get better." "You're never going to be perfect on the ice," Vigneault said. "J.T.'s pass last game, that's one play from his book that we're trying to take away from him so that he becomes a little bit more consistent. But at the end of the day, you're going to make some plays like that.  "If you notice on that play, we could've stopped that goal. The puck ended up on the side, J.T. could have hit the guy, Marc [Staal] and [Dan Girardi] [Girardi] could've done a better job in front of our net. Could've stopped that goal even though we made that awful turnover. You can make one mistake, but that second and third mistake, a lot of times that's going to cost you. That's what we're trying to get away from." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: Asked if it was important to win and not just play another fruitless good game, Mats Zuccarello laughingly said: "Yeah, and we've got to show that Zed's not dead yet," a direct reference to a column by The Post's Larry Brooks in Tuesday's paper. author: Lindsay Putnam
summary: Lisa Kotin's been an addict her entire life - but instead of drugs or alcohol, her vice is sugar. She spent decades bingeing on anything sweet and tried everything from fad diets to Overeaters Anonymous to kick her destructive habit. And when sugar no longer filled the void, she turned to men. Here, the 58-year-old actress and author of "My Confection: Odyssey of a Sugar Addict" (Beacon Press, out now) tells The Post's Lindsay Putnam about the darkest days of her addiction and how she's finally kicked the habit. I got pregnant when I was 24 - it wasn't a conscious decision not to put my diaphragm in correctly, but when you're eating sugar like I was, you're out of your mind and not thinking straight. I had an abortion, buckled down on my schoolwork and finally graduated from NYU at 26. I've quit sugar, but I still relapse, just like a drug addict. I've been sober now for 26 days. (I had some of my daughter's M&Ms on Christmas Day.) I'm back down to 125 pounds, but temptation is everywhere, in everything. I try not to eat anything just because it has sugar, and if it does happen to have a little sugar, it has to be beyond the fifth ingredient listed. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: I WAS ADDICTED TO SUGAR & SEX Cakes, cookies and reckless encounters with random men were her drugs of choice. How one woman's strange addiction almost killed her

author: David Kaufman
summary: The entire affair was the work of Dean Spade, an associate professor at Seattle University School of Law - and self-described "Jewish trans activist" - who helped lead the campaign to oust A Wider Bridge from the conference. Spade has an extensive paper trail of having Israeli groups banned from American LGBT events, including a particularly embarrassing 2012 incident that required a formal apology from the City of Seattle's LGBT Commission.  This time, in place of contrition, Creating Change has invoked now-ubiquitous clichs such as "constructive dialogue" and "safe space" to defend both rejecting and re-welcoming A Wider Bridge. How a group's banishment and then reinvitation could possibly both be done under the rubric of creating a safe space has gone unexplained.  Feckless and reckless, Creating Change has proven, yet again, that LGBT inclusiveness stops at Israel's front door. In doing so, they've not only handed a victory to the extremist academy, but allowed theory and emotion to triumph over free speech, critical thinking and a true marketplace of ideas. This isn't about Israelis or Arabs, Muslims or Jews - but a system that rewards fear, placates bullies and privileges shrieking and shrillness over intelligent discourse and reasoned debate.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Michael Goodwin
summary: The mayor tried a similar scam with Uber. His funders in that caper were medallion owners, and de Blasio obliged them by claiming that Uber was causing congestion and should be stopped. But a recent $2 million study the mayor commissioned essentially concluded that de Blasio made up his own "facts," just as he is now making up his own "facts" about accidents and congestion caused by the horses. Asked how much the stable fix would cost, de Blasio told reporters, "we don't have a final figure," while insisting it would be a "good investment." Yet news organizations report that other city officials readily put the cost of the renovation at $25 million.  Why wouldn't the mayor come clean on the price? If he really believes it's a good use of $25 million of taxpayer money, he should argue his case. But to give the price would open his claim of a "good investment" to a cost-benefit challenge, which he clearly doesn't want. Transparency for thee, but not for me. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: The "innocent out of his depth" sub-genre is a familiar one, but writer Tom Rob Smith gives it a fresh spin. "London Spy" isn't so much about throwing [Danny] in the middle of action-y capers as it is about how people become who they are - and what it costs them. Spearheaded by Ben Whishaw and Charlotte Rampling, "London Spy" is a psychological drama about identity and loss. There may be "spy" in the title, but we don't even see the bad guys - or explosions, chases or fights. There are so few thriller shenanigans that even John Le Carr feels action-packed in comparison. I think it's a good goal to have as a player because you have to be intentional about doing that. There's a lot that goes into playing all 82 games in terms of taking care of your body, getting rest, etcetera. Whether or not it happens, we'll see. He's playing really intense minutes right now." "He seems fine," Fisher said. "He went through shootaround this morning. No issues. It's that time of year. A lot of guys are banged up. You find a way to push through it if you can. author: George Willis
summary: The Nets are looking every bit like a team playing out the season. [Tony Brown] isn't exactly rallying the troops. Instead of trumpeting the "next man up" approach, he seemed to lament the losses of [Jarrett Jack] and Hollis-Jefferson since a narrow 90-88 defeat at Cleveland on Nov. 28.  "Not having Jarrett, not having Rondae impacts the game," Brown said. "We miss Jarrett. We miss his leadership. We miss his intelligence at the end of games, and his playing-making ability. " Being an underdog on their home floor with half the building cheering for the other team was supposed to be part of the Nets' past; now it's their present. Owner Mikhail Prokhorov had predicted a championship within five years, but the Nets would be lucky to be competitive five years from now. They are paying the price for gambling their future on big names and high-priced talent such as Paul Pierce, Deron Williams, Kevin Garnett, and Andrei Kirilenko. Even worse, the Nets are 28th of 30 teams in home attendance, averaging 14,941 coming into Wednesday's game, and the only team in the NBA with a negative operating income though ranked No. 7 in current value, according to Forbes. author: STEVE SERBY
summary: "I used to take him to the [Philadelphia] airport on Friday, so he would take his [recruiting] trips or go home," [Mike Muscella] said. "And then on Sundays, I'd pick him up from the airport. And I used to buy him a sandwich - roast beef and cheese hoagie - from John's Village Market, and we'd go back up at the field house, and go into my office. ... He would jump me from behind and we'd be wrestling in our athletic building, just the two of us. So that's what we'd do every Sunday - until he pinned me, and that was it." "I used to kid him about being a little heavy," [Walt Harris] said. "We had a kid on our team - I won't say his name - but I used to say, '[Larry Fitzgerald], you look like that guy.' He didn't like that. I said, 'You're not going to be able to handle the heat.' You should try to see the game, it's unbelievable the catches he makes. When we clinch the game, he nuzzles up next to me on the sideline and says: 'Hey, Coach, think I'm in shape?' " "He said, 'Coach, it's all good,' " Muscella said. author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: "We were both in the equipment room watching the game," [Peyton Manning] said. "[DeMarcus Ware] is a big-time second-guesser. I really enjoyed his commentary during the game. The hot dogs aren't bad in there, I'll say that, but I'd much prefer to be on the playing field. I know he does, as well." Ware recalled how he and Manning watched the first half from the sideline, but when it began to snow in the second half they went inside, where they both donned headsets so they could hear the coaches' calls and watched the game on TV with the sound muted. "It's so weird to see when a quarterback gets a call and see how he feels about the play," Ware said. "It was a totally different deal to sort of experience that. Peyton one time when Malik [Jackson] missed a tackle, said, 'DeMarcus, go out there and tell them that we need to run this play.'" Ware said he ran back to the field and delivered Manning's message "and it actually worked." He said another time, "I told Peyton, 'Hey, tell Brock [Osweiler, backup quarterback] that he needs to do this.' He puts his stuff on and goes out there and [instructs Osweiler]." "It was just funny to see that," Ware said. "It was fun at that time."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: "It seems frustrating for a fan, the pucks aren't going in, but for us, we know we're there," [Miller] said. "I think we're more aware of that as professionals that we're getting the looks and we're carrying the play. I think we did a good job of just staying with it." "When was it - last year, or my first year? - when I said he needs to figure it out?" the coach said with a smile. "Well, he's figuring it out. As you get older and you get more mature, you learn things, you apply those things, and that's what he's done." Here is another point of reference, about the beginning of December, just before the Rangers went into their 3-9-2 swoon, from which they only recently (and partially) have emerged with a 5-4-1 record over their past 10. It was then that Miller was one of the few members of the team to be putting forth strong efforts on a nightly basis - and he still wasn't getting rewarded with top six minutes. But he put his head down and kept working, a clear sign a maturity that wasn't there a year or two ago. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Howie Kussoy
summary: After upsets of Wichita State and Providence, the Pirates entered Wednesday's game against Villanova assured they wouldn't be overlooked, yet still went toe-to-toe with the No. 4 Wildcats and nearly shocked the two-time defending conference champions for the third straight season, before falling, 72-71, at the Prudential Center. The packed crowd relished the opportunity to knock off the two-time defending league champions, rocking from the game's start and treating each early lead and deficit-cutting shot as if a win were imminent. With Villanova center Daniel Ochefu - who had a season-high 20 points and 18 rebounds in the teams' previous meeting - collecting more fouls than points in a scoreless first half, Seton Hall took an early 12-8 lead despite missing its first five shots of the game. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Howie Kussoy
summary: The Pirates had shot after shot to take down the Big East's best, earning opportunities by ripping them away from the two-time defending conference champions. But when it mattered most, Seton Hall's sophomore-heavy squad couldn't match the Wildcats' experience, leaving the Pirates on the losing end of a 72-71 heartbreaker at Prudential Center - and so close to where they want to be. Led by Josh Hart's 15 points and 10 rebounds, Villanova's outside shooting opened another eight-point lead early in the second half, but the conference's dominant team of the past three seasons couldn't put the Pirates away. Fighting booth and nail: Seton Hall's [Isaiah Whitehead], who scored 19 of his 21 points in the second half, is fouled by Villanova's Phil Booth during the Pirates' heartbreaking 72-71 loss at Prudential Center. author: ZACH BRAZILLER
summary: Chris Russo is in the final year of his SiriusXM deal and has a little more time left on his MLB Network contract for his afternoon "High Heat" program. On the surface, it would seem like a tantalizing option for both parties: a chance for Russo to come back as a WFAN savior and a chance for the station to turn to a voice their listeners know and care about. There would be many obstacles to overcome, but if any bad blood between the two sides lingers from the 2008 breakup, it seems to have thawed recently with the "[Mike Francesa] & the Mad Dog" charity reunion, which will be simulcast on WFAN. SiriusXM has Stephen A. Smith as a potential new sports face if Russo departs, so how hard would they push to keep Russo if it came down to a bidding war? "It's time to do something else and experience something else," Francesa said. "I don't think it's the end of me broadcasting." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Sally Brompton
summary: You will be rather excitable today and the smallest thing will set you off. You won't know yourself which way you are going to jump next, so don't be surprised if others, even those you are closest to emotionally, stay out of your way.  Whatever else you do today, don't panic. Your life is NOT falling apart - you are just looking at things from too negative an angle. You may be a bit down at the moment but later on your mood and your viewpoint will be more positive.  Make the most of today's positive influences to impress employers and other important people. summary: Ex-Mayor Rudy Giuliani's business partner, Marc Mukasey (inset), has put his Beekman Place condo on the market for $1.57million. "It's the sexiest apartment you'll find on 50th Street," Mukasey tells us. "I love the apartment. It's a cool, East Side loft that is perfect for a bachelor or as a pied-a-terre." Mukasey says he is giving it up for bigger Fifth Avenue digs that are "more for someone in the prime of his life." The Beekman Place apartment comes with keyed elevator access. author: Zachary Kussin
summary: Few US enclaves compete with Bal Harbour for exclusivity and few Bal Harbour homes can compete with a new property at 252 Bal Bay Drive. Set just a stone's throw from the swanky Bal Harbour Shops, there's a single-family listing asking a cool $36 million that offers these privileges. This 20,198-square-foot, Chad Oppenheim-designed pad has eight bedrooms, nine bathrooms and one half bath. It's also located on a waterfront plot - just 300 yards from one of two Miami Beach inlets that join the Atlantic with the bay - and comes with its own dock. There's also a 70-foot glass infinity pool facing the bay, which is surrounded by landscaping designed by Fernando Wong. Another day, another Pritzker Prize-winning architect designing for the Magic City. The latest is Renzo Piano, whose Renzo Piano Building Workshop is designing Eight Seven Park, a 70-unit beachfront condo at 8701 Collins Ave. in North Beach. It's one of the firm's first residential projects in the Western Hemisphere. Prices are not yet available, but apartments will measure roughly 1,400 to 7,000 square feet and are slated for completion in 2018. American oak, Italian stone and glass walls are just some touches included in the pads' interiors. But every condo will come with wraparound terraces from 15 to 25 feet wide that look out to panoramic vistas. Eighty Seven Park will also be packed with amenities - including a spa, salon, library and an enoteca for wine and food - but the most notable are its green features. The lobby will have a leafy orangery, plus a year-round botanical exhibit with orchids and cacti. Can't wait for a building construction to finish? That's okay. Oceanfront Townhomes 9501 - a seven-townhouse development located at 9501 Collins Ave. - is ready for immediate occupancy. Six townhouses remain for sale, with prices from $3.75 to $7.25 million. And they're quite roomy - with combined indoor/outdoor measurements beginning at 5,200 square feet and reaching to 6,202 square feet. The Steven G.-designed interiors feature white-gloss porcelain and bleached hardwood flooring, Duravit bathrooms and fixtures, glass-enclosed elevators and - with a big nod to area Jewish residents - kosher kitchens, which also have name-brand appliances. Outside, each home has a private roof terrace with kitchens and plunge pools. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: MIAMI NICE Across the Magic City, new real estate keeps blooming despite whispers of a slowdown BUYERS ON THE BEACH

author: Mackenzie Dawson
summary: "Often people are 'people pleasers' up until their 40s," says [Sandy Weiner]. "They have lived their lives in answer to someone else's choices and requests. And suddenly it's an awakening of, 'I don't want to live my life out of alignment.'" "Happiness is about experiences, not money," says Depaul. "If I didn't have new experiences, my life would consist of working and watching television. I'm always striving toward a new thing I want to do." Or, as 82-year-old New Yorker Harry Edelson, author of the book "Positivity: How To Be Happier, Healthier, Smarter and More Prosperous," and a man who claims to have never had a bad day, puts it: "To me, [the idea of a midlife crisis] is philosophical BS. You can call it old-age crisis, high-school crisis, whatever. It's all in the mind. If you started calling it 'a midlife horizon' and say it's great, that would catch on, too. You've got to think positively all the time, and good things happen."Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Steve Cuozzo
summary: Andrew Cuomo promises New Yorkers a "legacy" bundle of transit and infrastructure goodies, most of them in or near New York City. A "new" Penn Station! A new LaGuardia Airport! He's cited great public works of the past, like the Erie Canal, as their inspiration. Although Cuomo said plans were finally under way for a replacement tube, called the Gateway, it's little thanks to him. He delayed things when he sniffed last year, "It's not my tunnel," and threw the ball back into New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie's lap. This is a joke, of course. Cuomo offered no such proposal, although many in the real estate and business communities say it's the most important missing link in the metropolitan area's transit network. New York is unique among world financial capitals in lacking a direct train line - a "one-seat ride" between its international airport and central business district. author: Michael Starr
summary: "I feel pressure every day to get it right," says "Today" show weatherman Al Roker. "This is no different, it's just that probably more people will pay attention to it." Still, it never fails. Our weather heroes become goats (for a day or two) if they're wrong. If that "expected foot of snow" turns into 3 inches, we blame them. If it's more, we blame them. "There was a snowstorm a few years ago that we missed, and everyone was apoplectic about it," says Roker. "To me, the upside was, you didn't have to shovel my mistake." "My own son asked me about the forecast the other day," says Roker. "When I told him, he looked at me and said, 'That's not what [Ch. 4 meteorologist] Chris Cimino said.' summary: "He worked extremely hard to get back from the ACL injury [in 2014], and I think he's playing the best football [he's ever played]. It was the first playoff win (in three tries) of Palmer's career. "I was just wanting [it] so bad, maybe too bad, and being tentative," Palmer said this week. "That's not my style. This is not a tentative offense and I think being tentative bit us in the butt in the first half, and we came out with a different mindset, and I came out with a different mindset at halftime." author: Hondo
summary: PATRIOTS-BRONCOS: Peyton Manning's game has regressed so much his wife, Ashley, is preparing an email chain asking everyone to "pray for Peyton." From a purely offensive standpoint, this is a complete mismatch. The Pats have The Great Brady and his 36 touchdown passes against just seven picks throwing to Gronk The Great and The Twin Terrors, Edelman and Amendola. Then there's Manning (nine TDs, 17 picks) straining to deliver his assortment of floaters, wobblers, wounded ducks and dying quails to his band of greasy-fingered receivers. Nevertheless, the question must be asked: Does offense win championships? Of course not. "Offense sells tickets," Bear Bryant said, "but defense wins championships." Ergo, go with the Bear and back the Broncs and their No. 1-ranked defense to answer Ashley's prayers and send her HGH-free old-timer out in style. For the scowling Hoodie, it's on to Santa Clara - if he can get a ticket. CARDINALS-PANTHERS: Hondo has become totally gun-shy on Arizona after watching Carson Palmer luck his way into his first playoff win. You saw it - the two picks, the three near picks, including Packers' CB Sam Shields dropping a probable game-sealer late in the fourth, the ricochet TD pass to Michael Floyd. Clearly, Palmer was nervous, which supports one of Mr. [Aitch]'s handicapping postulates: Big-time games bring out big-time anxiety in big-time duds. Nor was Hondo impressed with Arians' blitzes on the two Hail Marys, which forced OT and ruined a perfectly good push. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Marc Berman
summary: A BRIEF chant rose up at Staples Center on Wednesday night during the Lakers' loss to the Kings: "We want Phil." Sorry, Los Angeles, you can't have him. Knicks owner James Dolan won't let go of president Phil Jackson just yet. While the Lakers' braintrust passed on Kristaps Porzingis with the second pick to take D'Angelo Russell, Dolan is said to be so enamored with the 7-foot-3 Latvian, Jackson can do no wrong in the owner's eyes. [Arron Afflalo] and [Robin Lopez] were Jackson's top two free-agent signings. The tandem is earning its keep after slow starts. [Carmelo Anthony] trusts his former Denver playoff mate more than he has trusted any teammate, including Smith. Anthony's cross-court bullet to Afflalo for a 3-poiner late in regulation in Wednesday's 118-111 overtime win over Utah was a perfect illustration. "I think as he's gotten more comfortable as the season's gone on, understanding where those opportunities will come from in this particular offense," coach Derek Fisher said of Lopez. "I think he's been able to find a level that he's actually capable of sustaining." Fisher, a Jackson hire, has used substitution rotation that often can be baffling, but the nitpicking on every move that doesn't work out is a bit much. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: The MLB Network's Jon Heyman reported Thursday that Cespedes' representatives and the Nationals were discussing a five-year deal that could exceed nine figures, and many folks here at the Major League Baseball quarterly owners' meetings anticipated Washington would defy the logic of its roster and indeed land the Mets' cult hero, consequently sending large segments of the local fan base into an epic rage. Those projections naturally are far from perfect; among the many components they don't take into account are the in-season improvements the Mets made last year with internal and external changes. Nevertheless, you take Cespedes out of the Mets' lineup and put him in the [Nats]' lineup? That makes for a rather obvious power shift in the short term. @Mets If you guys don't sign Cespedes and let him go to the Nats, I'm boycotting the mets. You won't get a cent from me you cheap &?$!s @kire1325  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: YO, NO! Adding Cespedes would swing East back to Nats

[Shane Larkin] is confident the new pace will ultimately result in the success he had earlier in the season and is hopeful the impact will be the same for the team. But even if the Nets' season becomes increasingly irrelevant, the young guard won't allow the team's struggle to impact his game, as it did during last season's stint with the 17-win Knicks. "I think a lot of times you could see [the frustration] on my face last year, but this year I'm not gonna pity myself," Larkin said. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: "Twenty years ago, when you talked to National League owners about the DH, you'd think you were talking some heretical comment," [Rob Manfred] said, upon the conclusion of Major League Baseball's quarterly owners' meetings. "We have a newer group. There's been turnover. I think our owners in general have demonstrated a willingness to change the game in ways that we think would be good for the fans. Always respecting the history and the traditions for the sport." On the other side, Manfred noted, the existence of the DH in the American League and the absence of it in the NL serves as "the biggest remnant of league identity," from the pre-interleague play days when the leagues operated as separate entities. "I think that's a significant issue," Manfred added. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: NL could add DH for 2017 season BASEBALL NOTES

author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: "Right now, we're just focused on [Friday]," goalie Henrik Lundqvist said. "But we know, with three games to go, let's leave everything out there for the three games, and we'll see where we are. Of course you want to win, of course you want to end on a good note, but it's important that we just focus on [Friday] now and move on from there." "I think it's that you relax a little bit more if you go in on a high note," Lundqvist said. "It's easier to let the game go because that's really what the break is all about. You get away from the game, recharge. If you analyze too many things, it's hard to get away from. I think that's the biggest thing.  "Like I've said, our 5-on-5 play, defensively and offensively, is getting much better," [Alain Vigneault] said. "It's improving. We've got that on the right track. Now we've got to fix the other areas." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Phil Mushnick
summary: The solution: [John Scott] could have said, "Thanks, but no thanks," then could have borrowed, "If nominated, I will not run; if elected, I will not serve." He could have (should have) declared that such an honor belongs to the deserving, thus "I will take no worthy player's place; I will not play." Nope, Scott's in; he's eager to be on the ice Jan. 31 in Nashville. Scott, recently traded to Montreal then sent to the minors, said: "It's one of those things where not everybody gets to go. ... You've got to roll with it and have fun with it." On MSG, Walt Frazier was flabbergasted. "You've got to practice that!" he said - a clear insinuation that Derek Fisher's team either doesn't or doesn't grasp it. During replays, Frazier identified the obvious moments when the Knicks could and should have fouled prior to Hayward's shot. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Zach Braziller
summary: "It's really just been an amazing opportunity more than anything. I got into sports. I got into football. Obviously, you want to grow your role. You want to go into the next thing. It's an entry-level coaching position. I'm going to start here on the coaching track and go from here."  She's the first woman with the title as coach, in her 12th season in the NFL. The 30-year-old [Kathryn Smith], a St. John's alumna who grew up in DeWitt, N.Y., got her first break in 2003, when the Jets hired her as a game-day special events intern. She was named a college scouting intern in 2005 and a player personnel assistant in 2007. She became the assistant to then-Jets coach Rex Ryan in 2014 and followed him to Buffalo last year.  "It's been pretty extraordinary, the reaction, and I realize that it's groundbreaking," Smith told the team's website. "I might be the first, but I think very quickly there are going to be many other women in the league. So I may be the first, but I don't think I'll be the only one for very long." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Michael Riedel,On Broadway
summary: What of the memory of [Carol Channing]'s Dolly? She looms large in the part - and lives on in the glorious original cast recording. So, yes, the role is hers. But like all great parts, it should be played by great stars, and it'll be swell to have Dolly back where she belongs - on Broadway and at, I'm hearing, the St. James, where "Dolly" debuted in 1964. There were rumors of revivals in recent years. Queen Latifah seemed to top everyone's list as Channing's heir. But [Bette Midler] is fitting. She's a brassy diva with a voice made for a galloping Jerry Herman tune. She's the kind of star Broadway used to make before the era of "American Idol," when the leading ladies became big-voiced pop vocalists. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Hardeep Phull
summary: [Donny McCaslin] was visiting [David Bowie]'s New York office to hear "Blackstar," an album the jazz musician features heavily on, for the first time in its entirety. "I was sitting in this room alone and as I got lost in the album, I closed my eyes," McCaslin tells The Post. "Then, I opened them, turned around and David was just sitting there. He'd ghosted in!" McCaslin had been informed of Bowie's illness well before the recording started, but it didn't affect the sessions. "He was always funny, gracious and fully engaged," says the 49-year-old. "We'd talk about literature, music, and there was a lot of joking around. We'd order food from a deli in Soho that [Bowie's producer] Tony Visconti recommended. It was relaxed." title: He's jazzed to carry Bowie's legacy

author: Kyle Smith
summary: A problem with "The 5th Wave," adapted from Rick Yancey's best-selling young adult novel, is that there is nothing scary in it - unless you count the panic I felt when I realized my college classmate Ron Livingston is now old enough to play the dad of a movie lead. He and all the other adults get pushed aside by an Army colonel (Liev Schreiber, who deserves better) as the kids trade banter, learn to fight and swear revenge on "the others," as the aliens are known. The undercaffeinated middle of the film consists of dopey twists, slow-burning gazes and dialogue that aims for "heartfelt" but comes out "unfortunate." "Love's not a trick, it's real!" we're told. Save it to write in your bestie's yearbook. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Teenage wasteland

"That's why I think women will enjoy the flip we're offering here. This is the female answer to 'Fifty Shades of Grey.'" I think you have to expect that. It's called the "Oscars." It's named after a white dude. It's not as if it's called the "Jamals" or the "Leroys." We need to make more movies and be more productive. author: Barbara Hoffman
summary: "I haven't seen him for decades," she says. "I don't expect anything of him, so I don't worry about it. He gave us the greatest gift in the '60s - an arsenal of music to just listen to and enjoy, or take into battle. That's way more than you can ask." "He was always very nice to me," she says, "[but] we didn't agree on anything. He'd say, 'I'm going to make a computer that won't just duplicate a Beethoven sonata - it will be better!' "And I'd say, 'Excuse me? What about the soul? Where's the soul in it?' He'd say, 'It'll just be better,' and I'd be dumbfounded . . . and then we'd grab dinner." That was usually Indian food, she says, though later, even food was a struggle. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Kyle Smith
summary: "If you think back 10 years ago, the Academy was doing a better job," [George Clooney] said. "Think about how many more African-Americans were nominated." (By "African-American," Clooney meant "black." He would not have chided the Academy for failing to choose any 'African-American' nominees if Idris Elba, Lupita Nyong'o and Chiwetel Ejiofor, none of whom are American, had been nominated.) Clooney cited "Creed," "Concussion," "Straight Outta Compton" and "Beasts of No Nation" as films that "could have been nominated" but weren't, implying that racial bias is the reason they weren't. Great films and indelible performances get left off the list all the time, every year. "The Shining" didn't get any Oscar nominations. Nor did "Groundhog Day," "His Girl Friday," "Mean Streets," "Modern Times," "Sullivan's Travels," "Reservoir Dogs" or "The Searchers." Every film ever made has been "snubbed" for Best Picture, except for the handful that connected with Oscar voters at the exact moment they were filling out their ballots. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: IT'S NOT ALL BLACK & WHITE No, George Clooney, the Oscars are not racist - just look at the numbers over the past 15 years

author: Keith J Kelly
summary: Kelly Holland, veteran of the porn movie and adult publishing business, is currently head of the subsidiary within Friend Finder that publishes Penthouse. She told USA Today on Thursday that the reports earlier this week that the print edition was being abandoned were "misinterpreted" by the media. "We are truly committed to the magazine," Holland said to USA Today. "There's gravitas about the print page that you can't replace." As confusion seemed to reign on the corporate plans for Penthouse, neither Holland nor [Ezra Shashoua] returned calls or emails seeking comment on Thursday. But it looks for the moment that Penthouse in the short term will still be available in print. But for how much longer is anybody's guess.  "After more than 25 years at American Vogue,[Grace Coddington] will assume the role of Creative Director at Large and take on additional projects outside the magazine," a Vogue spokeswoman said. Even while takng on outside work, Coddington will still get to keep an office at Vogue and sources said she will be still supervise four cover shoots a year for the magazine. No direct replacement has been named. And so far, there's no posting about it on @condenastcareers.Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: Their leadership told us for months that [Cespedes] very likely wasn't going to come back after his superb three-month fling, and they based that on a common-sense assumption. After all, the Mets didn't want to give Cespedes more than three years, and the idea that he would settle for such a short deal after hitting 35 home runs and capturing so much attention appeared nothing short of preposterous. Cespedes' eccentric personality, the same personality that had Mets fans more than happy to bid him good riddance following a bad World Series, ultimately worked to the Mets' advantage. He really did want to come back to his fourth employer, it turned out. So much so that, even after an offer from the rival Nationals hit the nine-figure mark, Cespedes instructed his representatives at Roc Nation Sports to call the Mets and talk through that three-year deal. The Mets? The Mets far exceeded their primary goal, which was not to take too much of a public-relations beating from Cespedes' departure. They get back their middle-of-the-lineup force and consequently, arguably, become the clear favorites to defend their National League East title. They provide serious coverage for the likes of youngsters Michael Conforto and Travis d'Arnaud and injury-prone veteran David Wright, and they give Juan Lagares a safety net in re-proving himself after his terrible 2015. Lagares can start against lefty pitchers and come in late for defense when either Cespedes or Alejandro De Aza plays center field against righties. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Everything's coming up Amazin'

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: Not long after that, Zack Wheeler reached out to Sandy Alderson, wanting the Mets general manager to know how badly he wanted to stick around, too. Now, look: [Flores] is a young player, and the Mets were all he knew. Wheeler was a wounded pitcher, on the mend from Tommy John surgery, watching what his rotation brethren were doing day after day. Now [Cespedes] stays in the band. The Mets, hovering under a cloud of inferiority for so long, have emerged as a destination place. And why not? There's all that pitching. There's the NL pennant they'll raise toward the sky at Citi Field on April 8. And now, there is Cespedes, who did the most incredible thing Friday night: He left a huge pile of money on the table in favor of a lesser pile of money. That's not just a culture change. That's a full-blown metamorphosis. Twenty-five days till pitchers and catchers. Who's ready now? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. We have to get our hands up, bat some balls down and we just have to get there, plain and simple." "That's a problem for everybody, obviously," Broncos defensive coordinator Wade Phillips said. "You'd like to double-cover everybody they have. They split him out a lot, [which] gives you problems because of his size [against smaller cornerbacks]. When you have smaller people [on him], it's tough because he's so strong." "We're starving," [Ward] said. "We need that 'ship. I try not to listen to all of the noise. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: The move doubles the number of Giants in the game, as [Manning] joins his top receiver, Odell Beckham Jr., who on Friday was named one of four Pro Bowl captains, along with Rams defensive lineman Aaron Donald, Bengals defensive lineman Geno Atkins and Falcons running back Devonta Freeman. The captains will help determine rosters for Team [Michael] Irvin and Team [Jerry] Rice. Perhaps Beckham will have some sway and get Manning on his team. Despite Manning's performance, he could not prevent the Giants from finishing 6-10 for the second straight season, prompting the change at head coach from Tom Coughlin to Ben McAdoo, Manning's offensive coordinator the past two years. McAdoo is putting together his coaching staff, and it looks as if "Samurai Mike" will not be coming to the Giants. Mike Singletary, the Hall of Fame linebacker whose wide-eyed stare as a player and unorthodox motivational maneuvers as a coach gave new meaning to the word "intense," was not offered the job of linebackers coach on McAdoo's staff after interviewing with the Giants on Thursday. author: Steve Serby
summary: "We looked at ourselves and compared our players to their players, and we had bigger players," [Tom Pratt] said. "And we had very good players. It was still a mystery as far as, 'Are these guys better than we are?' At halftime I think that's when the realization hit us all that, 'Hey, wait a minute, we can win this football game. All we have to do is go out and play the next 30 minutes and get it done.' Well, as history shows, we didn't. We had some negative things happen to us, and they won the game." "The music I'm not quite up to speed on and all that sort of thing, but football is still football," Pratt said. "From when I started playing, coaching, whatever, it's still football, and I think players today relate to that. Once you're inside your own walls and you're on the practice field, you're in game situations, the players, they want to be as good as they can be. So whatever help they can get or knowledge they can get, they're looking for." "It's sad to see guys get banged up," Pratt said. "It's an issue that I don't know how it'll be solved. I know the league is working hard to try to work on helmets and safety equipment and of course the rules. And also I think it's important that the players buy into it, and I think they have. We want this game to still be a very competitive game, but use good judgment while you're playing." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: The blows and the blood only seemed to inspire [Chris Paul], who teamed with [DeAndre Jordan] to score 13 of the Clippers' next 17 points and spark the visitors to an easy 116-88 victory at the Garden. It ended the Knicks' six-game home winning streak. It also offered a reminder that despite their improved play of late, the Knicks (22-23) still can't match the heart and toughness of a grizzled team like the Clippers.  "I sort of flipped out, too," he said. "I don't think I hate anything more than getting my lip busted. You can't eat for a week." "The right way to use it is when you're ahead," [Doc Rivers] said. summary: "Sometimes in games like this where we've taken a couple steps forward, guys are really looking forward to certain opportunities and certain moments, and I thought we played with a little tension and stress because we wanted it so bad," Knicks coach Derek Fisher said. "The game got away from the start. They were physically faster and better. ... They were by far the better team tonight and proved that from start to finish." "They just made us make a decision and they were just reading off really well what we were doing," Porzingis said. "It's a tough situation. That's a really tough matchup for any team to play against, [Chris Paul] and [DeAndre Jordan]. We're going to have to find a way how to stop that." The Clippers were up 55-45 at halftime, and the Knicks briefly revived hope in the first few minutes of the second half, cutting the Clippers (28-15) lead to five, but Paul, who opened 1-of-8, crushed the Garden's growing optimism again. After hitting back-to-back jumpers and a 3-pointer, Paul put the Clippers up 64-52 with another lob to Jordan. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. "Me and Danny looked at each other and smiled and said, 'We might have something with this guy.' Things were going well, but we knew things were going to be going well the next couple years." "There's a big difference in my confidence and my comfort just being on the floor," [Dwaun Anderson] said. "It was hard for me to get comfortable, especially for me mentally coming from somewhere where I was the main guy and transferring from Michigan State, there were a lot of expectations of me. I can understand it, but I think it got to me and I felt more pressure and it messed with my nerves and my confidence. The hype of it, people had high expectations of me and I'd see in places people saying I didn't play to my full potential, getting nervous knowing the spotlight was on me. "Obviously it'd be a big difference in the experience, but what could've been isn't what happened so I don't really put too much thought into it," Anderson said. I don't let myself think about the media recognition and the hype. I want to stay true to myself and what I'm passionate about. I intend to get recognition from the fighting and not from anything else. Everything else falls into place if you're passionate about it and do well with it." "I'm just ready for what opportunities come," Holm said. "I was OK with July as long as it was going to be a guarantee. I didn't want them to say July and then it turned into October and the next thing you know it's going to be a year since I've fought. I'm in the sport because I like to fight. I don't want it to be all about what makes sense money-wise or what makes sense career-wise. I'm passionate about fighting, and so I want to be able to fight." author: Barbara Hoffman
summary: Most artists have mentors or schools or, at least, other artists with whom they compare notes. "Outsider" artists have only themselves. Self-taught - and, in some cases, incarcerated, whether in mental institutions or prisons - they make art that's shockingly individual, whether they're working in watercolors or shredded postage stamps. [Andrew Edlin]'s own connection to insider art is personal: "My father's younger brother, Paul, who's deaf, was making collages made up of tiny slivers of postage stamps - they almost look like [Byzantine] mosaics. author: Elisabeth Vincentelli
summary: January is a slow month for new streaming, so you might want to try Amazon's "Mad Dogs" - whose 10-episode first season was uploaded Friday - if only because it's there. The premise: Four American dudes visit a buddy in Belize and find themselves embroiled in a crime caper. Based on David Peace's cult noir novels, the made-for-TV "Red Riding" trilogy (Hulu) tracks several violent incidents in Yorkshire, England, from 1974 to '83. The trilogy is hard to beat for unsettling mood, but the cast of the first one, "Red Riding 1974," particularly stands out: Look for a pre-"Downton Abbey" Michelle Dockery. Four words: "Mad Max: Fury Road." George Miller's heart-attack-inducing action flick is now on HBO and, hot damn, it's great!Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: WASHINGTON - Sensitive information on spies reportedly has been found on at least one email on Hillary Clinton's private server - as Defense Secretary Robert Gates warned it's likely that several countries were able to hack into the server. Congressional investigators reported in October that Clinton's e-mail account was the target of hackers from China, South Korea and Germany. Russian hackers also tried to breach the account in 2011, hoping Clinton would click on e-mails sent as phony traffic tickets.  Clinton on Thursday night denied a report on Infowars.com that she continued using the private account even after being told it had been hacked. "It's totally untrue," she said. author: STEVE SERBY
summary: [Peyton Manning] no longer can engage [Tom Brady] in a shootout. This isn't January 2007, when Manning threw for 349 yards and brought the Colts back from a 21-3 deficit at Indianapolis for a 38-34 victory. This isn't November 2009, when Bill Belichick was so spooked by Manning that he went for it on fourth-and-2 from his own 28 with a six-point lead and 2:08 remaining. And didn't get it. And lost. This will be Jan. 24, 2016, when Brady still is playing at a level no quarterback could play - not even Joe Montana, not even John Unitas, not even John Elway. And Manning, back after two months of rehab, is playing the way 39-year-old quarterbacks historically play. Belichick won't be afraid to dare Manning to beat him while at the same time asking Brady to go win it. It was Elway who set the bar when, at ages 37 and 38, he finally delivered Super Bowl championships to Denver. That was 17 years ago. Manning's mandate when Elway sold him on the Broncos was to deliver another one. Manning took a $4 million paycut before this season. And now the $15 million question is whether he can fashion an Elway ending. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: FINAL FANTASY Glorious rivalry likely comes to end in Mile High clash

"I wouldn't compare it to any of those rivalries, but I think playing someone 17 times is pretty cool - especially someone as great as him," Brady said. "To play against those Peyton Manning-led teams, you know you've got to play 60 minutes, and you're going to be in for a tough game." "It's part of the game," [Rob Gronkowski] said of the low blows. "I've been seeing it all year. I've been seeing it my whole career. I've just got to get low, get my shoulder down, protect the ball, just protect myself in any way when I see a lot of guys coming or when I know there's not a chance to make that many yards, possibly just go down on that play." author: STEVE SERBY
summary: A: I'm definitely proud to be the first player to come back from that and still be able to play at a high level. When people said it couldn't be done, the fact that I've been able to play at this level is one thing that I'm extremely proud of, because I'm still contributing to this team four, five years after going through that. And at the same time, I could never even think about the knee anymore, it's just all about going out and playing the game. A: I'm a huge LeBron James fan, and I'm a huge Stephen Curry fan. Watching those guys grow into the men that they've become, the leaders that they've become for their team. Being here in Charlotte and seeing Steph [who went to college at nearby Davidson], the way he rose to stardom, didn't get heavily recruited, and everybody told him that he couldn't do the things that he's doing right now. I feel like he's the best NBA player in the league right now. A: It was pretty painful. As a young kid, you didn't really understand what I was going through at the time. I didn't realize that it's extremely hard to get to this point. For me coming in my first year, I'm thinking like, "OK, this is what's expected. If we don't win right now, we'll be back here." And, it's been 11 years and I'm still now finally making it back. So that's one thing that I'll make sure that I'm stressing to the guys right now so take advantage of this opportunity to seize this moment because you never know when it's gonna come around again. summary: "What is not mentioned is the hot seat that [Gary Kubiak] stepped into was hotter than any seat in the league," [John Elway] said in an interview this week. What a long, strange trip it's been for Elway and Kubiak, who served as Elway's backup from 1983-91 as a player then was Elway's position coach and offensive coordinator from 1995-98. "The way he managed [the quarterbacks], it was a tough situation because there obviously were a lot of people that wanted to see [Peyton Manning] playing and you've got a football team that you got to take care of. author: Richard Witt
summary: BRONCOS (+3) over Patriots / UNDER 44 /[2]: The Tom Brady/Rob Gronkowski combination has proven devastating against so many foes, and Denver is no exception. Brady/Gronk won here easily in late 2011, though that was against Tim Tebow, not Peyton Manning. Earlier this season, Brady's regular-season loss here was finalized without access to Julian Edelman or Danny Amendola ... and against Brock Osweiler (not Manning). Manning has beaten Brady in two of their four playoff meetings ... once in Indianapolis as a Colt in the game leading to Manning's lone Super Bowl win, and the other, two years ago, as a Bronco, in a game in which Gronkowski didn't play.  Referee Ed "Guns" Hochuli has been assigned this match. The Broncos have exceeded expectations in their games Hochuli's worked since 2008 (6-0), and the Patriots are just 3-4 in Hochuli games since 2010. Home teams have covered under Hochuli's oversight at a 71 percent clip (higher than the league average) - and underdogs have covered at 59 percent when Hochuli's wearing the white cap. These readings reflect most-recent sustained samples (thanks, to Bet Labs Sports). All this may not bother New England, but it appears of legitimate historical interest. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Have 'dogs in fight Broncos, Cards can cover in conference championships

author: Ken Davidoff
summary: Before the Mets acquired [Cespedes], the website FanGraphs projected the 2016 Mets to finish 83-79. Now? 86-76. The primary impetus for that, FanGraphs managing editor Dave Cameron confirmed in an email, is Cespedes. The Nationals, at 88-74, still stand above the Mets. For the moment, though, I'll put the Mets above Washington, which has whiffed this winter in efforts to add Cespedes, Jason Heyward and Ben Zobrist. Now, Mets general manager Sandy Alderson made clear recently - when it appeared that re-signing Cespedes was a long shot - he didn't view Cespedes as a great fit in center field. He isn't. Yet if you watched Cespedes patrol center field during his time with the Mets, you know that, with the exception of two profoundly bizarre misplays in the World Series, he didn't embarrass himself out there (and he should play left field against lefties, with the superior Juan Lagares patrolling center field). The same can be said for the Mets' new middle infielders [Neil Walker] and [Asdrubal Cabrera], neither of whom will wow you with their range but - unlike their immediate predecessors Daniel Murphy and [Wilmer Flores]- will make the plays they should make. They're sure-handed. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: CESPEDES TO THE RESCUE! After saving Mets' season, he does it in offseason, too

author: Ken Davidoff
summary: A: It makes him wholly superfluous. The Mets signed him with the idea of platooning the lefty-hitting [De Aza] and the righty-swinging [Juan Lagares] in center field. Now, the Mets' best lineup against right-handers will feature [Cespedes], who hits righties better than southpaws even though he bats from the right side, in center field. De Aza basically will hang around as a pinch-hitter and injury reserve. The Mets should at least explore a trade of him. Lagares is signed through 2019 on an extremely team-friendly contract - he will make a total of $22.5 million over the next four seasons. Because Cespedes probably will opt out of his contract after this coming season, it wouldn't behoove the Mets to sell low on Lagares after his discouraging 2015. Better to use 2016 to rebuild his body, his psyche and his value. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Marc Berman
summary: Back on that night against the Hornets, the Knicks inbounded to with 0.6 seconds left. The 7-foot-3 Latvian, who had been struggling with his shot, fired up a 3-point prayer that miraculously rattled in. The referees counted the bucket and the Knicks celebrated joyously until a review ruled the ball was still on Porzingis' fingertips as the clock ran out. The basket was waved off, but a folk hero was born. Porzingis was back Saturday night, but the Knicks weren't close enough to the Hornets to get another chance at a last-second miracle, falling behind by 21 after three quarters and losing 97-84. Porzingis had a block of Kemba Walker on the first possession and hit an early 3-pointer, but finished with an unremarkable night with 13 points (hitting four of nine shots), five fouls and four rebounds, none on the offensive glass. Block Party: Kristaps Porzingis blocks a shot by the Hornets' Kemba Walker during the first half of the Knicks' 97-84 loss in Charlotte on Saturday night. title: Begin again Porzingis revists site of his breakout shot

author: Marc Berman
summary: "It's hard for a rookie coach to come in and be in a situation like that where one guy [James] is such a big influence on a whole organization," [Lou Amundson] said. "That's a tough position to be in. However, you need in that situation to be assertive and make sure your players know you're going to hold them accountable, every one of them, and they're going to respect you. In the NBA, coaching is more managing than coaching. "It didn't feel like it should feel," Amundson said. "A team with championship aspirations, that's not how it was supposed to feel. Teams go through ups and downs, but I just think the atmosphere and energy wasn't there. It wasn't a healthy atmosphere. Teams go through issues, but it still feels you work through stuff being productive. In that disagreement, it didn't feel like that. But they did manage to get it together." author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "It was a mistake," [Frank Cashen] would remember years later, "but, my goodness, you'd have thought we'd committed a felony."  Then it was over: Five years, $8.4 million, and in the press conference that took place in the freshly-vacated Jets locker room, Fred Wilpon quipped, "[Keith Hernandez], it's a pleasure to pay the money," and when asked a few minutes later if he had been tempted to test free agent waters, Hernandez said, serious as a tax audit: "How much do you need?" The rest, as they say, became history within a couple of years. "It wasn't about the money," [Mike Piazza] tried to insist, and Wilpon was there that day, too, and acknowledged that for the Mets it really wasn't about the money as much as sending a message to their fans: "We've made some mistakes the last few years. I don't think there's any point in arguing that point." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Larry Brooks
summary: The most frightening aspect about the AHL fight on Tuesday - in which San Antonio's Daniel Maggio's straight right to the face literally knocked out San Diego's Brian McGrattan - is that the incident caused barely a ripple in the industry, as if this sort of thing should be accepted as a cost of doing business in the world of pro hockey.  Within context, there can be such a thing as "good" fight - spontaneous and in legitimate defense of a grievously wronged teammate. But there is no context under which punches to the skull can be described as "good." Concussions don't discriminate. author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: The owners asked [Lou Lamoriello] if he just wanted them to tell [Brendan Shanahan] he wasn't interested, but that's not the way Lamoriello operates - especially with a person like Shanahan, whom he had drafted with the No. 2-overall selection in the 1987 draft. A unique relationship between employer and employee, indeed. "With the relationship and the friendship that I had with Brendan from when he was a player, in drafting [him] and also playing [in New Jersey], it was something that we kept for years, so if anyone would tell Brendan, it should be me," Lamoriello told The Post. "So I spoke to Brendan and said the interest wasn't there. Then Brendan, who did get permission, spoke to me again. And it became a little intriguing. Then eventually, it became sort of like a challenge." "There was no pressure applied on him," Shanahan said. "But it was me telling him, 'You know what, you're not done. You're still a GM, and you're exactly what we need.' I had to tell him that about a little over 10 times." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: Some of the new hires are of the connect-the-dots variety, with clear and obvious ties to [Ben McAdoo]. [Frank Cignetti], brought in to coach the quarterbacks, like McAdoo, is a graduate of Indiana University of Pennsylvania - located about 10 miles from McAdoo's hometown of Homer City, Pa. Cignetti's father, Frank Sr., was the football coach at the school when McAdoo was a student there. Cignetti, 50, has coached quarterbacks for the 49ers, Saints and Rams and was the offensive coordinator at Rutgers (for Greg Schiano) and with the Rams. "In the league a lot of times what happens is head coaches hire who they've worked with in the past and who they're familiar with, there's a comfort level there," McAdoo said. "We're not operating that way. We're comfortable looking at a bunch of different guys we may not have worked with in the past. As long as we feel they fit, we're looking for some diversity and some different personalities as well. We want a bunch of different guys. We like to identify different ways of doing things, shake things up a little bit." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Claire Atkinson
summary: Netflix, the "House of Cards" distributor, last week objected to Relativity's plan to exit bankruptcy, calling it woefully lacking in "meaningful insight as to who day-to-day management will be." It's no idle question in that the streaming service has a licensing agreement that each year delivers tens of millions of dollars to Relativity for a set number of movies. In bankruptcy, however, the studio hasn't come close to fulfilling its obligations - a default that, Netflix says, "cannot be cured." Netflix doesn't directly question the star's management ability, but it does question whether a post-bankrupt Relativity will have leadership "with the skills, experience, and industry connections to produce and distribute quality films." summary: Chuck's investigation into Axe Capital is derailed when he has to divert resources to a case against rival hedge-funder Stephen Birch (Jerry O'Connell). Detective Wozniak (Ray Liotta) sends Harlee (Jennifer Lopez) on an errand that reveals he has a silent partner in the big score. Wozniak also realizes Donnie (Michael Esper) has been withholding information. Meanwhile, Harlee feigns cooperation with FBI Agent Stahl (Warren Kole), but unwittingly leads the agency to incriminating evidence. Series premiere. Fox attempts a revival of TV's most popular sci-fi series. Charismatic political show host Tad O'Malley (Joel McHale) reaches out to recluse Fox Mulder (David Duchovny) and Dana Scully ([Gillian Anderson]) to bolster his evidence that those pesky aliens are among us. author: Billy Heller
summary: The meaning of words can subtly alter as they are said in different languages. In Savit's debut novel, Anna Lania, age 7, notices a lot about language and meaning. As the daughter of a Polish linguistics professor she speaks a half-dozen of them well. As a Jew in 1939, she picks up on many secretive signs of danger. When her father is arrested, Anna finds a new protector known as the Swallow Man. He has an intuitive ability to escape notice, and this skill, plus Anna's multilingual abilities, are the pair's only protection as they evade Nazis through World War II Europe. author: Ralph Peters
summary: That danger may be coming to a head, because market forces are doing what no Western leader dared: applying the brakes. With oil and gas prices plummeting, Russia's economy's shrinking, inflation's soaring, the ruble's collapsing, pensions are losing value, wages can't keep pace - and the first hairline cracks in [Vladimir Putin]'s popularity are showing. The czar won't fall tomorrow, but the grumbling has begun. Putin's single weakness has been his poor grasp of economics. Instead of diversifying Russia's economy when the times were good, he relied on oil and gas production - which he could control, restricting Russia's new aristocracy of wealth to the manageable size of the old court nobility. A diversified economy would have diffused his authority. In the words of the greatest American economist of our time, Cyndi Lauper, "Money changes everything." Putin's inattention to market fundamentals is hurting him now. Although Russia's projected budget - amended week to week - seeks to fence funds for Putin's cherished military buildup, it becomes a greater challenge by the day. I feel as if he's my brother, except that brothers and sisters are rarely as close as we are."
