summary: According to court papers filed in Arizona on Jan. 15 and obtained by Page Six: "[Chip Saggau] represented to [Steven Mehta] that from time to time [Alice Cooper] and [Cooper's charity] Solid Rock Foundation would assist him in selling cars through the Barrett-Jackson auction." Saggau allegedly boasted "that Cooper's celebrity status would bring a higher winning bid at the auction." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Michael Goodwin
summary: Over a soundtrack of the duo's 1968 hit "America," the [Bernie Sanders] ad shows farmers, families and enthusiastic crowds at his rallies. A mosaic of faces flashes by in a bid to rekindle the idealism of older voters who remember the song and its swelling refrain of "All come to look for America."  She's slumping in the polls now, but it's not likely she'll follow Sanders into the oldies bin. Think of the landmines if she tried to spark voter nostalgia with, say, The Beatles' hit "Yesterday."  Then there's [Donald Trump]. Not surprisingly, the GOP front-runner has eclectic tastes, playing Elton John's "Rocket Man," Adele's "Skyfall," opera star Luciano Pavarotti and Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Phantom of the Opera." summary: "I grabbed my daughter and went to say hi," recalls [Tim Durkin], who had just bought tickets for the Boss' The River Tour, which comes to Madison Square Garden Sunday and Wednesday. He was so down to earth," says the 46-year-old Wall, NJ, resident, who was tickled when his idol agreed to a portrait session. Sammy Steinlight, who often sees [Bruce Springsteen] at the WindMill burger shack in Long Branch, agrees. "There's no entourage. There's no escort," says Steinlight, who was at Asbury Park's Stone Pony in 2004 when the singer walked in the door with Sean Penn and played for a half-empty bar. "A few years ago, he went to the ATM to get tip money, and the machine was broken. author: JENNIFER GOULD KEIL
summary: "He is totally in tune with everything that is going on here," says one [Donald Trump] executive. "Even the smallest things, like choosing the color of the carpets, the chandeliers, the sconces and the paint palettes in his buildings to the placement of the cup on one of his golf courses." Trump "always works expeditiously," the executive says. "But now he expects to hear pitches within 20, 30 or 90 seconds instead of three minutes. The amount of time has been truncated, like 'Shark Tank.' " Trump said he begins most days at 5 a.m. He reads the papers, watches the news and by 7:30 a.m. he'll take an elevator from his penthouse to his office. His campaign headquarters are a few floors below. So what's on the desk? "See this photo?" Trump says, as he reaches for an unframed photo of himself with Michael Jackson, floating on one of the piles on his desk. "That's me with Michael. Sure he had his problems, but he was a genius." summary: Michael Bloomberg's latest flirtation with a run for the Oval Office gives an added dimension to those "New York values." author: Andrea Morabito
summary: "The two reactions are, 'Wow, that's so cool' - and, after a few moments' reflection, 'But that's so creepy,' " [Rob Spence] says. "I've actually started wondering, do we want to have constant video of our lives? It's just another data set. And I don't know the answer, but I think no, we don't want that. But it's coming anyway." Spence's eye-cam resembles a regular eye prosthesis, embedded with a camera that is equipped with a radio frequency micro-transmitter. The camera is not connected to the optic nerve - meaning Spence can't see out of it. Rather, what the "eye" sees is visible on a handheld monitor, and Spence can turn the camera on and off with the tap of a magnet. For now, Spence can get about one to three minutes of shooting time before the eye-cam overheats, so he's selective about how he employs it. Professionally, he's used it to film other people's bionic arms and legs for a commissioned documentary about prostheses and cybernetics. But he's also been goofing around, like when he attempted some "cyborg comedy" at a Toronto bar's open-mike night. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Costello
summary: "It's not really time to reflect," [Peyton Manning] said. "We have two weeks left." Manning got a huge assist from a relentless Broncos pass rush that rattled [Tom Brady] all day. Linebacker Von Miller, a pending free agent, drove up his asking price with a monster day, recording 2.5 sacks and an interception. The Patriots got on the scoreboard after a huge Broncos mistake. Manning threw a lateral to running back Ronnie Hillman that was initially called an incomplete pass. Hillman made no effort to pick the ball up off the ground, but Patriots linebacker Jonathan Freeny did. The refs overturned the call after a [Bill Belichick] challenge and awarded New England the ball on the Denver 22. Two plays and a penalty later, Steven Jackson scored from 1-yard out to make it 7-6 late in the first quarter. Patriots kicker Stephen Gostkowski missed the second extra point of his career to keep it 7-6. ROCKY MOUNTAIN HIGH: Peyton Manning waves to fans after leading the Broncos to a 20-18 victory over the Patriots in the AFC Championship game in Denver. Manning threw for 176 yards and two touchdowns. Broncos running back Ronnie Hillman ( far left) celebrates on the field. Getty Images (2)Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: STEVE SERBY
summary: "Look, as we get older, we can't run as fast, we can't jump as high, we can't throw as far," former Broncos Hall of Fame tight end Shannon Sharpe said. "But his mind is sharp. When they had a bad play, they were outnumbered, he got 'em into a good play. "My contributions are different," Manning said, "but I'm fortunate and grateful that I had an opportunity to contribute still, in some way. It's a great honor to be going back to the Super Bowl, playing Super Bowl 50. It's gonna be a fun two weeks." Brady (23 hits) had no fun against a ferocious, relentless, suffocating Wade Phillips defense led by Von Miller (2.5 sacks, one interception) that beat him up the way the Super Bowl XLII Giants did and made him feel as if he were locked inside a Park Avenue conference room with Roger Goodell, Ted Wells and the NFL legal team. "He's a great player," Brady said, "and someone I've always admired." Someone he'll be watching on Super Sunday. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Sanders broke open down the middle on first down, but Manning overthrew him in the end zone. No problem. author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: If the Panthers beat the Broncos in Santa Clara in two weeks' time - and just based on the eye test both teams provided Sunday, it sure seems like that's going to be a popular choice - the Panthers will have to be entered into what will surely be the most surprising and improbable conversation imaginable: the one that ranks the best teams of all time. "We did what a lot of people said we couldn't do," a jubilant Newton said after the final gun Sunday, climaxing what had been a three-hour party at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, N.C. "But it's not over yet." The Broncos will surely provide Newton and the rest of the Carolina offense with a stiffer, sterner test than either the Seahawks or the Cardinals were able to provide these first two playoff games. Gone will be the home-field advantage, thanks to the Super setting, Levi's Stadium, which all but defines what a "neutral" site ought to be. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. "He's a big man and you've got to know how to get him to the ground for sure. He's a future Hall of Famer so there's not a lot he can't do." "I've been here 12 years," Fitzgerald said. author: Marc Berman
summary: Getting pressured by Carolina's swarming defense, [Palmer] notched three turnovers in the first half - including two fumbles - that contributing to the Cardinals' 24-7 halftime deficit. The low-key Palmer, whose teammates call him a "recluse," doesn't celebrate much on the field anyway, but Sunday there was only reason to cry. One week after getting his first playoff victory in a modest outing, he was disastrous in the 35-degree Carolina night. Coming out for the third quarter, Palmer didn't get help. On the first possession, future Hall-of-Fame receiver Larry Fitzgerald dropped a short pass right in his clutches. In fact, the first Palmer-Fitzgerald connection didn't occur until late in the third quarter - a 6-yard delivery. Carolina's banged-up secondary won the individual battles. It's the second straight year the Cardinals have ended their season on this Carolina turf. But this time the Cards didn't have their third-string quarterback, Ryan Lindley, as field general, but Palmer, who had a season-ending knee injury in 2014. However, Palmer resembled the more ordinary version of his unbecoming Raiders' days. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Marc Berman
summary: "I didn't pay as much attention in the beginning of the season to breakfast," [Porzingis] said. "I wanted to get to the gym. I'd eat something quick and go to work out. So now I'm getting up one hour, 1 1/2 hours earlier and having a big breakfast so I have energy for the whole day. I'm really focusing on breakfast." Porzingis' breakfast fare isn't anything outlandish - just large portions. "I was so weak and sleepy because of the blood - I wasn't eating enough," Porzingis said. "Food changed from Lativan food to Spanish food and I couldn't adjust. I was working out a lot, [had] a growing body and I got anemia. I have a few moments when my iron levels are low, I get sleepy and as soon as that happens, I take my iron pills and I'm fine." Porzingis,who clearly doesn't want to miss a game, has played recently through a shoulder injury and a bruised foot, but some nights he's a lot more lively than others. Porzingis revealed he played for a week with jammed index fingers on each hand that swelled up, but have since healed. "He's put on the amount of weight that's good for where he is now," [Derek Fisher] said. "It's always hard to hold or gain weight during the season because of the workload and how much energy you expend. It's proportionate to your overall strength in terms of how much weight he can carry and strength ratio. He's 20 years old and as he physically matures he'll gain weight naturally. ... We'll try to do what we need to do this summer." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Phil Mushnick
summary: On ONE hand, it's a sad, touching story. Syracuse University alumni and friends of basketball are being urged, through A GoFundMe campaign, to contribute money to cover the medical needs of NYC then SU star Dwayne "Pearl" Washington, who, at 52, is believed to be destitute and known to be suffering mightily from cancer. On the other hand, it's a sad institutionalized, disgust-raising story. Washington, 1986 first-round pick of the Nets who played three NBA seasons, was a full-scholarship enrollee at SU, a strong academic university - unless one's recruited to play basketball or football. Thus Washington has nothing to show for it, nothing to demonstrate that his college presence was designed for anything more or better than to win the coach and the school ballgames until his eligibility expired, his presence no longer required. What's the percentage or likelihood of good students going bust years after college, compared with scholarship-recruited football and basketball players? The former's failure is surprising; the latter's stands to repetitive logic. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Cap & drown 'Pearl' Washington's tragic story shows how we use, dispose of 'student'-athletes EQUAL TIME

summary: So when [Rob Senderoff], the Kent State coach, saw [Jimmy Hall]'s name on a list of potential transfers, he didn't dismiss him. Sure, he knew all about Hall's problems - in late November 2012, he was one of four Hofstra men's basketball players arrested and charged with felony burglary after admitting to stealing more than $10,000 worth of laptop computers, iPads and other items from fellow students - and initially the plan was to recruit him for down the road. Hall was attending ASA junior college in Brooklyn at the time. "To see him become successful and do well and stay on the right track and produce, it's something I root for," said Steve DeMeo, a former Hofstra assistant who is now coaching at junior college Northwest Florida. "I'm happy for Jimmy Hall." The Zags' run of 17 NCAA Tournament berths could be in jeopardy. After a recent loss to St. Mary's, Gonzaga is actually in second place in the West Coast Conference, an uncustomary position, and Mark Few's team lacks its usual quota of impressive non-conference victories. UConn and Tennessee doesn't cut it, a major reason its RPI is an underwhelming 60. The injury to Przemek Karnowski has hurt Gonzaga's biggest strength, the front court, and redshirt freshman point guard Josh Perkins has battled consistency issues. summary: A rough week for the New Yorker's copy editors, who OK'd a report on the GOP primaries that accuses Sarah Palin of "no-nothingism." To be fair, their attention was likely dulled by the umpteenth dispatch from this magazine heralding the apocalypse of the Republican Party. "We like raw truth," says a Pentacostal Trump supporter, retreading the argument that the GOP establishment's time-tested bullet points are fast losing traction with voters. So when are we going to see the piece about how Democrat voters are fed up with Hillary as they rally behind a self-proclaimed socialist? A far better bet in this week's reading is the profile of physicist-turned-jazz pianist Vijay Iyer. Time puts the water catastrophe in Flint, Mich., on its cover, which is fair enough, but skewering politicians over that one is like shooting fish in a toxic barrel. There is some fair coverage of the far more interesting presidential race, including a piece by Sam Frizell that argues Bernie Sanders' campaign is in sore need of a "second act" beyond populist economics - a criticism that Sanders continues to resist. "Republicans race toward know-nothing nativism, and Democrats stumble towards socialism," Joe Klein complains. Whether you agree with him or not, at least he didn't botch the usage on "know-nothing."  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: Betsy McCaughey was right to criticize the Obama administration for threatening school districts with racial-discrimination lawsuits when they suspend more black students due to the fact that "black students misbehave more often" ("How Blas Is Making NYC Schools Unsafe," Betsy McCaughey, PostOpinion, Jan. 20).  McCaughey tries to laugh off RJ, calling it talk therapy. Actually, it's an evidence-based system that empowers students to address conflicts, encourages accountability and has been employed nationally with great success. If the NYPD doesn't believe RJ "groom[s] criminals," why would we? [De Blasio] and Chancellor Carmen Faria should be duly investigated and possibly charged with crimes against New York City students and parents. summary: Here's the thing: Success and other top charters do special ed the way it's supposed to be done. They work hard to help these kids learn their way out of the program.  It's telling that the suit hits Success for refusing to promote kids who aren't ready for the next grade. That's worth applause, not a court fight - and it's what the regular public schools claim to do, as well.  A third of the city's regular public schools don't have enough rooms to accommodate the greatest-need special-needs students, the ones in "12-1-1" programs (12 students, one teacher, one aide). Park Slope special-needs parent Doug McCurry made that point on these pages a year ago. (His son now thrives in a Success school.)  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Fredric U Dicker
summary: "[Andrew] has contempt for Albany. He's restless and tired of what he sees as the 'small-ball' job of governor. He wants to get back to Washington, and he knows his only hope is a Republican president he can challenge in four years," said the source, who has known Cuomo for more than 20 years, including during Cuomo's time as Bill Clinton's housing secretary. "If you examine things closely the turning points were, first, the Occupy Wall Street movement, which scared him, then the re-election of [President] Obama, which he doubted, and finally, the strong showing by an unknown [Zephyr Teachout] running against him in the 2014 primary," continued the source, who said he admired Cuomo's "careful political calculations" but not "his cynical and calculated willingness to abandon any position for his own advancement." The source said Cuomo's frequent "embarrassing and over- the-top" praise of the Rev. Al Sharpton, who in the past insulted Cuomo's father, Gov. Mario Cuomo, during the Tawana Brawley racial hoax, "makes sense in the context of the governor wanting to lock up black support in his run for president." author: Kyle Smith
summary: As the news media start blasting out stories about "[Carlos Danger]" amid the 2013 mayoral race that [Anthony Weiner] was winning, we check in on the deluge of jokes told by TV comics as well as the shellshocked mood inside Weiner's Fifth Avenue campaign office. We are right there in the room with Weiner and his wife, Huma Abedin, a top aide to Hillary Clinton, immediately after the second group of quick pics of a Weiner who has misplaced his underpants hits the media.  The unstated implication is that everything in "Weiner" applies to the Clintons, only more so. When Weiner reads an editorial defending him about all the things he didn't do - didn't rape anyone, didn't sexually assault anyone, didn't commit adultery, didn't misuse his office, etc. - many of the allegations have credibly been made against Bill Clinton. (There is a minute or two of film considering news reports that Hillary might have demanded Abedin distance herself from Weiner if she wanted to keep her job.) Throughout the film, Weiner displays an arrogance as swollen as his briefs, responding to a random detractor in a bakery who calls him a "scumbag" that "it takes one to know one," then getting in a shouting match with the citizen. When his own polling expert tells him he has zero chance of victory and is bailing, Weiner refuses to listen to reason and muses about saving himself via a "Bulworth" moment of unhinged hard-left appeals. He is seen chuckling at video of his disastrous, out-of-control interview with MSNBC host Lawrence O'Donnell, while a disbelieving Abedin asks, "Why are you laughing?" After his concession speech, Weiner is photographed giving the finger to photographers.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Documentary takes long, hard look at Carlos Danger's collapse 'Weiner' flick is a coming attraction

summary: Twelve years after leading the Ravens to their first Super Bowl title and winning MVP honors as Baltimore hammered the Giants in Super Bowl XXXV, [Ray Lewis] returned to the big game. After missing the last 10 games of the regular season to with torn triceps, Lewis returned in time for the playoffs-had an NFL-best 51 postseason tackles-and helped the Ravens to a 34-31 win in Super Bowl XLVII. The Giants stunned the undefeated Patriots in Super Bowl XLII, harassing league MVP Tom Brady all evening, with [Michael Strahan] leading the charge. The Hall of Fame defensive lineman had two tackles and a sack in the Giants' 17-14 upset of the Patriots in Glendale, Ariz., and in June of that year, he called it quits following 15 NFL seasons, all with the Giants. author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: For the sake of pure fascination, wouldn't you love to gather Peyton Manning, John Elway, Gary Kubiak and Brock Osweiler together at the conference table upstairs in the Broncos' training facility and conduct a tell-all truth session? Would Manning want to walk away when he still thinks he's got it? Would the Broncos want him to retire, knowing they just won a Super Bowl while Manning had the worst regular season of his career? What about the players in the locker room? They're all now singing the praises of Manning - and justifiably so given where they are going next week. But what if Manning's postseason performance matched what he did in the regular season, when he threw just nine TD passes and had 17 INTs, and Denver flamed out of the playoffs early? author: STEVE SERBY
summary: Newton, 26, is an athletic marvel in his prime who loves to preen and dab. [Peyton Manning] is the broken-down warhorse with the plantar fascia left foot who rallied off his football death bed for this chance to ride off into the sunset the way John Elway did. Life doesn't begin at 40 for NFL quarterbacks, not even for Hall of Fame quarterbacks. Manning will be looking to redeem himself after the 43-8 beatdown the Seahawks administered in Super Bowl XLVIII in his little brother's stadium. It won't be easy against a Panthers defense that clawed Carson Palmer and takes no prisoners and refuses to stop playing the respect card. One last time, Manning will be facing a defense that will dare him to win the game. He'll have 13 days to pick Eli's brain about the Panthers. Eli threw four TDs with one interception in a 38-35 loss to Carolina last month. If Peyton's lucky, all the Odell Beckham Jr. questions certain to be lobbed at Josh Norman next week will serve as a distraction. Just as importantly, he'll have 13 days to allow his body to rest. author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: It's well to remember the NFL has long had a place in cities other than the major industrials that fancy themselves the game's rotating capitals, New York and Chicago, Pittsburgh and Dallas. Akron won the very first NFL title, in 1920. Canton won back-to-back, 1922 and '23. Instead, in a move that even Roger Goodell would've had trouble abiding, NFL Commissioner Joseph Carr suspended the Maroons late in the season, eliminating their title hopes. Thankfully the Internet wasn't invented yet, or it would have melted on the spot. Still, if Pottsville, Pa., could have once been home to an NFL power, why not Charlotte? Why not North Carolina? The state already has enjoyed one championship run, the unlikely dash to the 2006 Stanley Cup by Raleigh's Hurricanes. Charlotte is definitely ready for this. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Carolina's cue Charlotte ready to become home of NFL powerhouse

author: Brian Costello
summary: The Broncos will return to the Super Bowl against the Panthers in two weeks with a ferocious defense that was on display Sunday in the AFC Championship game against the Patriots. After finishing No. 1 in the NFL in total defense, pass defense and sacks this season, the Broncos defense showed it was for real against Tom Brady. Denver sacked Brady four times, 2.5 from Von Miller, and hit him 23 times, the most any quarterback has been hit in the NFL this season. [John Elway] found some other gems beyond the first round of the 2012 draft with defensive ends [Terrance Knighton DE Derek Wolfe] (second round) and Malik Jackson (fifth round) and linebacker Danny Trevathan (sixth round) . Trevathan was taken with a pick acquired by Elway from the Jets in the Tim Tebow trade. 'WAY TO GO: John Elway apparently knows defense, too. Since watching his team torched in Super Bowl XLVIII, he has brought in Derek Wolfe, [DeMarcus Ware] and Aqib Talib as he's overhauled the Broncos defense. "But I'm going to give [Joe Johnson] a chance to have the decision-making in his hands in regards to throwing the ball into [Brook] or some kind of pick-and-roll with Joe and Brook involved. Not to say these guys won't handle it, but [Johnson and [Lopez]] have been there before. Joe's got great experience and poise, so I just feel better about going through those guys late." author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: The Blueshirts' bedrock netminder turns 34 years old on March 2, and that is a fact not lost on him, not lost on general manager Jeff Gorton, and not lost on coach Alain Vigneault. Whether directly or indirectly, that fact is the source of urgency that now exists - the urgency that reared its ugly head when Vigneault had his stoic public persona begin to crack after Sunday's 3-0 loss to the Senators in Ottawa, now described by Vigneault as a "blowout" and "a stinker."  "I'm not looking for that," the coach said. "We're right against the [salary] cap. That's not my job. My job is, I've got players here, and my job is to make them perform up to their potential. Obviously, I can say right now that I haven't done that." "Before [Sunday], I would've said, Jeez, we're getting better," Vigneault said. "Then [Sunday] sort of buckled me a little bit there." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: An urgent matter Must find way to win with King in prime

author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: The Blueshirts' bedrock netminder turns 34 years old on March 2, and that is a fact not lost on him, not lost on general manager Jeff Gorton, and not lost on coach Alain Vigneault. Whether directly or indirectly, that fact is the source of urgency that now exists, and that reared its ugly head when Vigneault had his stoic public persona begin to crack after Sunday's 3-0 "blowout" loss, as he described it, to the Senators in Ottawa.  "I've got players here, and my job is to make them perform up to their potential," Vigneault said. "Obviously, I can say right now that I haven't done that. I need to make sure that I get this group here to play to their full potential. We have not done that."  "Before [Sunday], I would've said, 'Jeez, we're getting better,' " Vigneault said. "Then [Sunday] sort of buckled me a little bit there." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: Which is the one that really seems like a curious choice. Yes, Casey Stengel was the Mets' first franchise face, and he remained a popular team ambassador to the end of his life. But he also lost 404 of the 579 games he managed with the Mets. That's a winning percentage of .302. That's 122 points lower than Art Howe's. This has been a popular crusade for a lot of Mets fans of a certain age, because Keith Hernandez did in 1983 what [Mike Piazza] would do in 1998: He made the Mets credible again, after an endless stretch of irrelevance. And Hernandez helped bring a championship to the Mets, too, and there isn't a player on that 1986 team who would argue who the undisputed leader of that team was. This number should have been retired years ago. It's crazy that it's still been around for the likes of Kevin Appier, Dae-Sung Koo and David Newhan to have donned in the years since.more understandable than the others, given how he sabotaged his career here. But it really should be worth something to commemorate what Dwight Gooden was in those heady days of the late-'80s when the Mets weren't just baseball stars but rock stars, too. author: Marc Berman
summary: With sore-kneed Carmelo Anthony on the bench in a gray suit, the Knicks gave Oklahoma City a fiery battle, but [Kevin Durant] wouldn't let them lose. Durant, in leading the Thunder from an 11-point deficit in the final 10 minutes to force overtime, racked up 44 points, 14 rebounds and five assists as OKC survived the scare and beat the Knicks, 128-122. Durant blew past Porzingis for a hard jam with 3:00 left in regulation to put the Thunder up 106-104. At 106-106, Durant fired in a 3-pointer over [Lance Thomas], his former workout partner in Oklahoma City. The big basket came in the final minute of the period. [Derrick Williams] missed a short jumper, Grant fought for the offensive rebound and swung it to [Langston Galloway] on the left wing. The Knicks' clutch 3-point sniper drilled it. At the third-buzzer, Knicks backup center Kevin Seraphin blocked Durant on a running drive, sending the crowd into a frenzy. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. We've been an inconsistent team throughout the year. Tonight bothers me - we have to give that consistent effort so we can pull out wins. From this point forward, it's about giving that energy. We gave everything, Melo was out and that team is one of the better teams in the league. That lets me know we're capable of much more. "There's a point in every season we have to decide if you want to hover around .500," Afflalo said. "I feel we're better than that. I feel I'm better than what I am. Moving forward, it's time to show it." "[[Kevin Durant]] played well and they won," coach Derek Fisher said of his former Thunder teammate. "He's on the other team." author: Marc Berman
summary: "The season moves along so quickly," [Kevin Durant] said. "Every chance I get alone, I'm either on the plane [or] in the city thinking about the game the next day. I can't totally just say I haven't totally thought about it at all, but I haven't sat down and put a lot of time into what I'm looking for. I've been focusing on the season and teammates and how I can be better as a player and leader. Everything else comes after that and the season." "I haven't thought about that," Durant said. "I'm enjoying every moment, and told that to myself before the year. It's easy for me to stray off the path and think about the future. I pray when I get out of bed to stay in the moment and enjoy the moment. This stuff goes by quick. It's my ninth season, and I can remember my first game at Madison Square Garden like it was yesterday. "It's not different," Durant said. "So many games on TV nowadays. Social media gives the game and different players exposure where you are. It really doesn't matter. It's never been about that for me. "I think it's a great thing obviously," Johnson said. "When I've got the basketball, running pick-and-roll with Brook [Lopez], I just tell guys, 'Be ready to shoot. Just because I'm not looking at you doesn't mean I don't see you.' We've been getting great stuff out of it. Brook draws a lot of attention with him rolling, and it frees up guys like [Bojan Bogdanovic] and Wayne [Ellington] to knock down shots. "Joe's having fun playing this way," said Brown, who now has both a point-forward and potential trade asset on his hands. "The ball's in his hands, he's making decisions. author: Marc Berman
summary: "They link everybody with New York City," [Kevin Durant] said. "It's one of the greatest cities in the world. It's not a bad thing. It's a great city. Great place to visit, great place to live, I'm sure. But they link everybody, not just me. "The season moves along so quickly," Durant said. "Every chance I get alone, I'm either on the plane [or] in the city thinking about the game the next day. I can't totally just say I haven't totally thought about it at all, but I haven't sat down and put a lot of time into what I'm looking for. I've been focusing on the season and teammates and how I can be better as a player and leader. Everything else comes after that and the season." "I haven't thought about that," Durant said. "I'm enjoying every moment, and told that to myself before the year. It's easy for me to stray off the path and think about the future. I pray when I get out of bed to stay in the moment and enjoy the moment. This stuff goes by quick. It's my ninth season, and I can remember my first game at Madison Square Garden like it was yesterday. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Joel Sherman
summary: The commercial breaks in such games are 2:05. Last year, the clock was set at 2:25 at the end of a half-inning, with the idea the hitter would get in the box with 20 seconds remaining on the clock and the pitcher would deliver by zero. The clock was part of MLB's attempt to address pace-of game concerns, a focal point for Rob Manfred in his first year as commissioner. Rules also were implemented to keep managers in the dugout during replay challenges and to have hitters keep one foot in the batter's box during at-bats. But overall it's great to see a collection of that type of talent with a great attitude, good team guys. They came up together and that's powerful." author: Kevin Kernan
summary: "I'm going to try to do exactly what I did last year, see ball, hit ball," [Alex Rodriguez] said. "Keep it really simple. Enjoy it, have fun." If he can do that again this season, if Rodriguez can hit 27 homers (six fewer than he hit last season), he will tie Babe Ruth - the ultimate Yankee - at 714 home runs. Barry Bonds is first at 762, then Hank Aaron at 755, Ruth at 714 and Rodriguez, who owns 687 home runs. "That was very humbling," Rodriguez said. "It gave me a different view of the game." Viewers got to see Rodriguez's knowledge of baseball, and he suddenly was humanized and became more approachable. He noticed that a few days after the World Series when he was having dinner in the Meatpacking District and groups of baseball fans came up to him with questions and comments. "There were doubts," Rodriguez said. "I went over a year without playing baseball. At 39, not playing for a year, a year and a half, there were a lot of nights I was saying, 'This is going to be tough.' " The Yankees need everything to go right, including Rodriguez having another big year if they want to make the postseason again. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "What's the point?" he said a few days later. "It's not just that he won't spend a minute in college, he shouldn't. He's a physical freak. There's only one league for a guy like that, and it's not the Big East." LeBron James proved worthy of all the advance billing. You can haggle with some aspects of his game, still, 13 years later. You can argue with how he sometimes carries himself. But from the moment we became aware of him as a high school kid, this was never in dispute: Bill Parcells, from 2012: "That kid is a specimen, a physical freak." Jon Gruden, from 2011: "Jaw-dropping talent.A physical freak." Bruce Arians, Sunday night: "When he gets it going, there's nobody like him." Funny thing, too: Here's where sometimes being a general manager or coach - and having that built-in affinity for raw, unmistakable talent - comes in handy. Because even though Newton had burst into America's football consciousness in 2010 by becoming the first SEC player to throw for more than 2,000 yards and rush for more than 1,000, leading Auburn to a 14-0 record and the national title, there were some who believed his ridiculous physical skills might work against him. "You have to be talented to be an NFL quarterback, no doubt," Gruden said earlier this season. "But you have to have that something else. And when you have the most talent and that something else ... you have Cam Newton." Football is a fickle beast, of course, and so Newton's shelf life as a physical freak may be much shorter than [James]' - for all the pounding [LeBron] absorbs on flights to the basket,a month's worth of drives don't add up to three plunges into an NFL line. And quarterbacking can be hard to predict - remember when Colin Kaepernick was going to redefine the position? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: 'FREAK' SHOW Physical beast Cam is the NFL's LeBron

summary: A Charlotte Observer online poll conducted in September 2013 asked readers this question: "If you were Panthers owner [Jerry Richardson], would you fire [Ron Rivera] this week?" Whatever, the Panthers went 11-1 to finish that 2013 season and Rivera was named Coach of the Year. "Hey, he's come back a couple times," [Herman Edwards] said. "He was a coordinator being talked about as a head coach and all of a sudden he got let go [by the Bears in 1998] and had to start all over again. That's not easy to do." summary: The fact is, [Dan Boyle] - who sat out Monday's 6-3 victory over the Sabres - has not been on the ice for a power-play goal since Dec. 22. He has not been on for a five-on-four power-play goal since Dec. 20. He has not recorded an even-strength point since Dec. 30, and he has the fewest number of five-on-five points (two goals, two assists, four points) of the Blueshirts' six regular defensemen, just one more than [Dylan McIlrath] (two goals, one assist, three points) in nearly 400 more minutes of even-strength ice time. Look, this isn't meant to demean or run down Boyle, who has had an estimable career. But the 39-year-old is not getting it done at either end of the ice. Furthermore, he takes minutes away from both [Keith Yandle] and McIlrath whenever he dresses. author: Haley Goldberg
summary: Agave nectar: Found in bottled iced tea and granola bars, this sweetener is natural, but that doesn't mean it's healthy. It can have more fructose - which drives up blood sugar and can serve as a catalyst for weight gain and diabetes - than corn syrup, [Haylie Pomroy] says. Castoreum: This additive found in flavored yogurt, ice cream and candy is actually derived from beavers' anal glands - gross! - but it's a safe, natural flavoring, [Tanya Zuckerbrot] says. The compound's smell and flavor can range from vanilla to honey to strawberry. Xylitol: This natural sweetener - common in sugar-free gum - is dangerous for dogs, Pomroy says, but safe for humans. "The name sounds very chemical-y," she says, but xylitol derived from hardwood or beech - not corn - is generally healthy. Though it doesn't contain fructose, it's best to limit consumption as it can induce stomach problems like diarrhea if eaten in large amounts.Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Michael Goodwin
summary: It was less than two years ago when [Cuomo] stood bravely with the charter movement against Mayor de Blasio and the unions. On a winter day in Albany, as de Blasio pandered to his union allies in a warm meeting room, Cuomo mounted a stage outside the frigid capital to promise a rally of charter parents and students that he had their backs.  I called it Cuomo's finest hour, and he was just getting started. He delivered legislation requiring de Blasio to give charters space in city buildings or pay their rent, and called himself the "student lobbyist." The governor vowed rigorous teacher evaluations and praised charters as necessary competition.  "I believe these kinds of changes are probably the single best thing that I can do as governor," Cuomo said. He promised "to break what is in essence one of the only remaining public monopolies - and that's what this is, it's a public monopoly." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Michael Starr
summary: The British-born Miller, 43, took time out from his hectic shooting schedule to talk to The Post about "Elementary," why Sherlock and [Joan Watson] will (likely) never hook up, his love for New York City and his late grandfather - actor Bernard Lee ("The Third Man"), who played intelligence chief "M" in the first 11 "James Bond" movies (from 1962-79). I think we're all on the same page here as far as that goes. [Holmes] and Watson's relationship is sacred, and if you change that, then the show is not about Holmes and Watson anymore. There are some things you can play with and some you can't. The fact that one's a man and one's a woman is irrelevant; it's who they are as people that's important. The original Holmes and Watson were not romantically involved and, therefore, neither should we [be romantically involved]. It's good to have people's minds racing and thinking one thing or another, but we're in the Holmes and Watson business. That won't change unless someone else swoops in and takes over and turns the ship upside-down. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: IF YOU'LL allow me to channel Post teammate Mike Vaccaro for a moment, where does Yoenis Cespedes' re-signing with the Mets rank among historic, dramatic New York baseball free-agent signings? We're talking the free-agency sagas themselves, as opposed to merely the caliber of the players or the size of the contracts. "He doesn't view this as a short-term relationship, or a short-term contract," CAA Baseball's Brodie Van Wagenen, who led Cespedes' negotiations, said in a Wednesday telephone news conference of his client. "Yoenis sees this as an opportunity. He hopes that it'll be a bridge to a longer-term contract in the future. He has an eye toward what this relationship could become on the heels of the relationship that we've already shared." The Mets? They don't own a goal fundamentally opposed to that of Cespedes'. They're paying the 30-year-old $27.5 million for 2016, including a $10 million signing bonus that must be distributed within 30 days of the deal's finalization, and they want to get sufficient bang for their buck. Yet they would like development on other fronts, namely the good health of David Wright and blossoming of Michael Conforto and Travis d'Arnaud, to make them feel just as secure over holding a hard line with Cespedes as they just did successfully. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Amazin' saga has just begun

author: Mike Puma
summary: After assuring [Sandy Alderson] that [Cespedes] wanted to return, the agent had a question of his own for the general manager: "Are you in it to win it?" Alderson recalled Van Wagenen asking him. "We were very candid with Sandy that this situation would not come down to an apples to apples comparison of the player's choices and I think both sides remained committed to keeping an open mind on creative deal structures," Van Wagenen said. "Clearly the player had a desire to be here and had motivation to structure a deal that not only kept him here, but also accomplished his goals of having him properly valued and properly placed, in not only this market, but also his outfield peers across the game. "[Jeff Wilpon]'s willingness to push this deal to the finish line is a testament to the Wilpon family's commitment to giving Met fans a championship caliber team that they deserve," Van Wagenen said. "I think it was a group effort from the Mets organization from a lot of different folks involved." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Kevin Kernan
summary: "We're excited to walk out that first day of spring training," [Terry Collins] said. "We're not world champions, but we're [National League] champions. That's got a nice ring to it." In 2017, the goal is to walk out on that field in spring training as world champions. "We have to take a look at Kansas City and learn something," Collins said of the Royals, who lost to the Giants in seven games in 2014. "They made it a point, 'We're going to go back and we're going to get this done.' That was their mantra the entire year.We have to have a similar one." This is all so refreshing to hear in a world in which everyone gets a trophy for just showing up. It's not about getting to the tournament, it's about winning the tournament. "I learned my lesson, if it's the same situation," Collins said. "You can't burn yourself twice." Collins and pitching coach Dan Warthen already have drawn up a plan to let the pitchers get added rest in spring training, but also to get them ready. Collins said he asked John Smoltz about how the Braves approached the season. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: NO 'PAGNE NO GAIN Collins throws down challenge to win it all in 2016

author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: "Right now, I think [Cam Newton] is the best player in the league," [Darius Butler] said. "That's why I would pick Carolina in this one. The way Cam is playing right now, it seems like he's on a mission. Their whole team has been focused all year. You don't win 15 games in the regular season by accident. "They stick to their process. They're really tough to beat. They're pretty committed to running the ball, and Cam can tuck it and hurt you at any point." Butler, who was drafted by the Patriots in 2009 and played for the Panthers in 2011 (Newton's rookie year) before joining the Colts, called "trying to game-plan" for Newton "tough" because of his threat to run the ball. "During the week, when you're game-planning it's tougher to go against a quarterback like [Peyton Manning], who will know almost everything you're in, will be calling out your blitzes and coverages at the line of scrimmage," Butler said. "But, once you get to the game, Cam has more physical attributes for you to deal with than Peyton. So on game day, it's probably a little more intimidating going against Cam at this point." Can the Denver defense do to Newton what it did to New England's Tom Brady on Sunday, hitting him 23 times and sacking him four times? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Common foe: Newton will be difference

author: HOWIE KUSSOY
summary: "People think that you should be stoic when you play this game, and I think a lot of people disagree," [Ron Rivera] said. "You should be able to come out and have fun. This is a kid's game we're playing. I know there's a lot of money involved and everything, but at the end of the day, it's about entertainment and having fun."  "I've said it since Day 1, I'm an African-American quarterback that might scare some people, because they haven't seen anything they can compare me to," Newton said at a press conference Wednesday. "Oftentimes, it's funny, I get inspired, it makes me go out there and practice even harder because I remember when I was working out for the draft and I would see the Senior Bowl playing, I see these guys out there busting their tails, trying to get drafted, trying to have a job to provide for their family or themselves and it's like, here I am, I'm doing exactly what I want to do, how I want to do it." Super Bowl 50 marks the fourth straight title game featuring a black starting quarterback, though Newton is just the sixth black quarterback to start in the game. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: CAM: DEAL WITH IT! QB says race a factor with perceptions, but he's not about to change

author: Paul Schwartz
summary: "We're right in the middle of the process right now, so it's hard to make a lot of changes," [Jerry Reese] said. "We have guys who've watched these guys all year long and know them better than anybody. We always look at the process and see if we can do things differently or better. We'll continue to do that. Scouting is scouting." "You guys didn't like that when I said that, said I was trying to duck that, that's not true at all," Reese said. "Ever since I've been here with the Giants, everybody has been part of the process. We come to a consensus on who we like, and ultimately if we don't pick a guy that works out it's my fault, it's the general manager's fault. But everybody is part of the process, and I'm not going to back off that. It's the truth." "One of the favorite guys people like to throw at us is [Marvin Austin], a guy everybody says we spent a high pick on and we missed on him," Reese said. "There's plenty of Marvin Austins around the National Football League. I can give you an example of how we talked about him. Marvin Austin, we're kind of like, 'This guy's going to be a hit or this guy's going to be a miss.' We missed on him. We said, 'It's probably not going to be anything in between.' Take [Mario Manningham], we said, 'This guy is going to be a hit or a miss. Nothing in between.' We hit on him." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. title: It is on me Reese defends group-effort stance, but knows blame ultimately his

"One of the favorite guys people like to throw at us is [Marvin Austin], a guy everybody says we spent a high pick on and we missed on him," Reese said. "There's plenty of Marvin Austins around the National Football League. I can give you an example of how we talked about him. Marvin Austin, we're kind of like, 'This guy's going to be a hit or this guy's going to be a miss.' We missed on him. We said, 'It's probably not going to be anything in between.' Take [Mario Manningham], we said, 'This guy is going to be a hit or a miss. Nothing in between.' We hit on him." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brian Costello
summary: Olsen's lasting impact may be in the community, where he has helped numerous families. Olsen's mother, Susan, dealt with breast cancer when he was still in high school. In 2009, Olsen established "Receptions for Research," a foundation to raise money for breast cancer research. His foundation received another focus, though, in 2012 when his wife, Kara, gave birth to twins. One of the twins, T.J., was born with hypoplastic left heart syndrome [HLHS], a rare congenital birth defect that affects blood flow through the heart. T.J. had multiple surgeries and is OK now, but Olsen saw how difficult and expensive it was for families to go through it. He established "The Heartest Yard," and about two dozen families in the Carolinas have benefited from the program. It provides about $25,000 to $30,000 worth of nursing care to families dealing with HLHS during the first six months of a baby's life. [Greg Olsen] - the Panthers' NFL Man of the Year nominee - also meets with the families and tries to comfort them. "Everything under the sun that these babies tend to struggle in, we would provide some of expert in their field to be in your home to help you take care of it," Olsen told The Associated Press this fall. "We feel like this is the most tangible, direct thing to impact that percentage and changes these babies' lives forever." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: PRIDE & JOY An NJ champ with his dad, Panthers' Olsen keeps family first in title quest

I hope he can win, but [his] impact has already been made, and his legacy should not be affected by this one game." "I'm excited for him," Eli said. "I know this has been an interesting year for him - new coach, the new offense, and trying to learn that, deal with an injury, having to sit out for seven weeks, never gone through that before, coming back as a backup, never done that before. ... If we're consistent with that, I don't see why we can't be." "We all feel the same way. That's our goal for the season. We want to make it to the playoffs and we feel like we're able to do that," said rookie Kristaps Porzingis, who was named to the World Team for the NBA's Rising Stars Challenge at All-Star weekend. I don't think he was involved in any of the conversations that goes on with the personnel of the team or the coaching staff or anything. But it's easy to say that at this point." "But you can't worry about it too much," James said. author: Zach Braziller
summary: Of Seton Hall's first seven Big East games, four have been on the road, three against top 10 opponents Providence, Villanova and Xavier. Coach Kevin Willard's team also has faced Providence at home, as well as surprising Creighton. And aside from the loss to the Bluejays, the other three setbacks have been by a combined 18 points, highlighted by last Wednesday's heartbreaking 72-71 defeat to Villanova. Last year's group, through seven Big East contests, had played just two ranked teams, both at home, and suffered a pair of double digit losses on the road. The dynamic sophomore missed the first eight Big East games last year with a stress fracture in his foot, and never quite found himself upon his return, battling inconsistency issues. While still up and down, the 6-foot-4 [Isaiah Whitehead] has performed well in the league as the Pirates' point guard, finding the balance between looking for his shot and setting up teammates. He's leading the team in scoring (15.5 points) and distributing (4.5 assists), and nearly led Seton Hall to the upset of Villanova by himself, scoring 19 points in the second half. Last year might have ended differently with that kind of production from Whitehead.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: Clippers forward Blake Griffin watched his teammates win Tuesday night, then apologized for why he wasn't there to help. He is expected to miss 4-6 weeks. "A situation among friends escalated and I regret the way I handled myself towards someone I care about," Griffin tweeted. The Spurs' Gregg Popovich will coach the NBA's West All-Stars, though the Warriors have the conference's best record. summary: Overlooked in the mother/ daughter drama surrounding the $100 million estate left by philanthropist and socialite Carroll Petrie, who died last year, is this teeny yet elegant guest studio on east 63rd Street. author: Zachary Kussin
summary: [Jeff Greene]'s piggyback development technique is certainly neat, but it's hardly alone. Greene couldn't be reached for comment, but industry experts agree that as vacant parcels become harder to find, developers are getting creative and placing new residential builds on top of other properties. The key to their success lies in maximizing zoning and securing air rights to maximize the projects' benefits. "We're the lowest building in our area, and [we] wanted to do something to generate income," says Jeffrey Charles-Pierre, board president of Neighborhood Housing Services of Bedford-Stuyvesant - a Brooklyn nonprofit that develops affordable housing. Thus birthed the organization's plan to grow its two-story office building at 1012 Gates Ave. in Bed-Stuy into an affordable rental, which calls for five modern-design floors to be built right on top. Charles-Pierre says they're currently working to secure financing for this project, and estimates a 2020 completion. "It's unusual to dig a foundation and not have some kind of surprise you'll have to deal with - that's just time and money," [Howard Glatzer] says, adding that above-ground construction costs are still comparable to ground-up construction. "You're already ahead of the 8 ball," adds Charles-Pierre. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: TOP HEAVY Short on space and long on ambition, canny developers are now building on top of buildings THE NEXT LEVEL

author: Kyle Smith
summary: [Nate Parker]'s "Nation" is much more structured, veering away from the indie intensity of "12 Years" into more conventional Hollywood territory. A proud, stirring, emotional appeal, it leans toward the style of "Glory," the 1989 Civil War epic about black troops fighting under the command of a white officer. Painstakingly establishing who [Nat Turner] was and why he decided to fight the system of which he was part, Parker uses arresting images such as a glimpse of two black girls at play, one with a lasso around the other's neck - to map the anguished landscape of Turner's soul. As an actor, Parker is superb, and the script is first-rate as well. When Turner announces his plan to a disbelieving house slave, the latter says something like "You have killed us all." Turner says no: He is choosing for the first time to really live. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Trending Rebels are gunning for Oscar A biopic of Nat Turner, who led a slave uprising, will be a top contender at next year's Oscars

A child actress who made her film debut in 1995's "Friday," she found herself rebelling. "I was always being told what to do. If I felt bad about something, I would drink. That is how I got started with smoking too." "There were moments where we would be alone and I thought, 'Man, I could really [have sex] right now,'" Good recalls. "The study suggests that Zika virus could eventually reach regions of the United States in which 60 percent of our population lives," including the East Coast, the South and West Coast, he wrote. author: Andrea Morabito
summary: "If it's raining we're going to see rain; if it's sunny we'll see sun," production designer David Korins (who also worked on "Hamilton") tells The Post. "So much of TV and film is about control. In doing it this way, we give up control. We accentuate the now of it." "Grease: Live" aims to use the best elements of stage (rotating sets, sliding walls) and film (camera tricks to recreate the Thunder Road car race) in its three-hour TV production. Two songs from the original Broadway production not in the classic 1978 movie are included: "Freddy, My Love," and "Those Magic Changes." Choreography (by "Glee's" Zach Woodlee) has been updated, like the T-Birds' classic arm movements in "Greased Lightning." But, for the most part, "Grease" still lives in the innocent 1950s. Julianne Hough ("Dancing With the Stars"), who plays the virginal Sandy to bad boy [Danny Zuko], says the chemistry was immediate with [Aaron Tveit], a Broadway veteran best known for "Graceland" and the movie version of "Les Miserables." Porzingis showed Canada something in the Knicks' visit to Toronto in November, soaring over three Raptors for one of the first of his many highlight-reel putbacks. Since then, teams have become more aware of his trademark play and generally are more physical against the lanky Latvian. "He's going to be a handful, whether physical with him or not," the Raptors coach said. "He's a tough kid, not soft. You have to work for his position - if that's physical, so be it. Walk-off hero - Most agree Supe V (Colts-Cowboys) was the sloppiest, worst played, most egregious Super Bowl ever played But the game's final error - Craig Morton's pass tipping off Dan Reeves' hand, into Colts LB Mike Curtis' arms - set up Jim O'Brien for the first-ever Super Bowl-winning field goal. 1. Joe Namath's guarantee - Three days before he would earn MVP in Super Bowl III, which only gave lasting legitimacy to the Big Game, Namath answered a heckler at a Miami Touchdown Club dinner thusly: "We're gonna win the game! And then you look up, and the ball's out of bounds and you were like, 'Oh no!' But, to be quite honest, your mindset is, 'All right, we're gonna stop 'em, go to overtime.' ... And then when [Adam Vinatieri] lined up for the kick, my next thought was, 'OK, we're blocking this.' That was just kinda the mindset of that whole football team, it was by any means necessary, and we were gonna win. It didn't matter." Except Vinatieri booted the 41-yard field goal with four seconds left. "The rope comes up, and literally, you're roped off and you go into the locker room," Delhomme said. "Just kinda looking and saying, 'We're gonna get back. We're gonna get back here to win it.' " It is the best available defense mechanism for the heartbreak and heartache that devastated the Panthers in their locker room while confetti rained on the Patriots. author: Paul Schwartz
summary: In many ways, [Bronson Kaufusi] is the polar opposite of a pass-rush prospect, Damontre Moore, who went bust for the Giants. Where Moore was young, Kaufusi is older than most seniors, having spent two years on a Mormon mission in Auckland, New Zealand. Where Moore was immature, Kaufusi is grounded - his father, Steve, was his defensive-line coach at BYU, and Bronson is married, to a former BYU soccer player. Where Moore was skinny and needed to add bulk and strength, Kaufusi is already NFL-sized. Kaufusi is well aware of the Giants. His former college teammate of two years, linebacker Uani 'Unga, was an undrafted free agent last summer and made the Giants' roster, even starting several games. Kaufusi also knows about what not long ago was a Giants tradition of pass-rushing defensive ends. "Oh, yeah, they've had terrific pass rushers," Kaufusi said. "I know 'em. [Justin] Tuck. JPP's there. They're all about getting off the ball and getting in the backfield. I feel like it's definitely my strength." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Larry Brooks
summary: "You've got to play your lineup," said [Alain Vigneault], who has had Boyle in the lineup for 42 of the club's 49 games. "You've got to play your best players, and your best players have to be your best." Let's stipulate this: The Boyle-McIlrath matter, while a flashpoint because it is the most significant lineup decision confronting the coach and because it has trade-deadline ramifications applying to Keith Yandle, isn't the most critical issue the somehow-seventh-overall Blueshirts must overcome if they're going to be more than a second-half paper tiger. Trusting veterans is Vigneault's way. He has implicit faith in guys who have been there and done that. Maybe the best equivalent to Boyle this year is the way the coach continued to deploy Marty St. Louis, Boyle's 2004 Cup-winning teammate at Tampa Bay, in critical spots in the playoffs a year ago, even though the future Hall of Fame winger's game was in steep decline. author: Sara Stewart
summary: The wildest of the bunch, and the one that's stayed with me the most, is Don Hertzfeldt's 16-minute "World of Tomorrow" (also streaming on Netflix). A little girl named Emily is visited by an adult, third-generation clone of herself, who takes "Emily Prime" on a trip to the "outernet" of the future. Hertzfeldt's deceptively simple stick figures and drifting geometric shapes contrast smartly with a dark dystopian vision. Also included are a handful of "highly commended" shorts that didn't make Oscar's cut. "The Short Story of a Fox and a Mouse" is a gently beautiful nature fable, while a pack of meerkats in "Catch It" recalls the more antic animals of the "Ice Age" films. summary: In the movie, churchgoers are angry because a community center they want has been held up. They think it's because city workers are lazy or don't care. [Barack Obama] gently suggests they stop casting aspersions on others' motives and urges them to change their point of view: The city just doesn't think the project is feasible in a depressed area. He tells them they can make it work by enticing private developers to create shops near the community center. Everybody wins. "You gotta put yourself in their shoes," Obama tells them. He notes that they should think that way of even their opponents because "most people are basically at their core good people." author: Lou Lumenick
summary: The true story behind a Coast Guard rescue depicted in Disney's "The Finest Hours" is amazing enough that it didn't require corny romantic embellishments that threaten to capsize everything. In the film's most preposterous scene, [Bernie Webber]'s fiance Miriam marches into the Coast Guard station and demands that the commander (Eric Bana in a thankless role) call her Bernie back so they can get married. When the commander declines, Miriam leaves in a huff, walks out in a freezing storm without her coat, and crashes her car into a snowbank. (In real life, Miriam was at home with the flu.) The filmmakers couldn't resist manufacturing a shamelessly hokey finish centering on, you guessed it, Miriam. Despite some impressive special effects, "The Finest Hours" is no "Perfect Storm," but thankfully, it's no "In the Heart of the Sea" either. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Robert Rorke
summary: "If I didn't get the script, I was going to call them and say, 'What's the matter with your mail?' I am the logical person to play the role," says [Richard Dreyfuss], 68. "I am clearly a New Yorker. I have made a career out of playing college-educated, Upper West Side Jewish men. That's the way I see myself. And that's why they would be silly to go Joe Yutz." Playing Madoff marks a return to acting for Dreyfuss after a lengthy hiatus. And it couldn't have come along at a better time. He cut down on acting in 2004 after getting fired from the London production of "The Producers" - "I had a bad weekend," he quips - and spent the next four years at St Antony's College at the University of Oxford as a Senior Research Advisory Member. "In my house, my father said he had this company, Eldon, and he came home every night exhausted and you would no more question what he did for a living than you would jump off the Brooklyn Bridge," Dreyfuss says. "One didn't challenge your father, especially about the fundamentals ... When people say, 'They must have known,' I say, 'Oh, really? You tell me how they found out.' They ain't gonna get it from him 'cause they ain't gonna ask him."Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

The finale "Close to You" sees Rihanna ditching the sex and drugs haze in favor of a tender piano ballad that is one sickly-sweet couplet away from being in Adele territory. The movie is told from Kasabian's point of view as one of "Charlie's Girls" who drove the getaway car at both crime scenes and later received immunity for turning state's evidence against Manson and his minions at their murder trials. (She now lives under an assumed name.) My favorite character in literature is Iago in "Othello," and I brought a lot of Iago to Charlie - and Travis Bickle ("Taxi Driver") and Heath Ledger in "The Dark Knight." I hope a lot of people look at this movie and go, "I get it. I see how these people started to begin to be enticed by this guy." He wasn't just walking around saying he was going to kill everyone - it was so much more complicated than that. I hope people think twice about [Leslie Van Houten], Linda, Patricia, Tex etc. ... they were starved, beaten, drugged and brainwashed by a person who was a once-in-a-generation expert at it. I don't have sympathy for Charlie but I do have sympathy for those people. They spent the rest of their lives in prison. Charlie stole their lives - he killed them, too. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: PORTRAIT OF EVIL 'Manson' star:'I felt possessed by Charlie'

author: Marc Berman
summary: "It would be a dream come true for Latvia to make the Olympics," [Kristaps Porzingis] told The Post. "I have to make a decision. If I want to work on my game individually or play for the team. It's different ways [of developing]." "They're good and getting better," Porzingis said. "I thought they did good in the European Cup. I think we'd have chance with or without me. But I have to make a decision." Latvia's highest-drafted NBA player before Porzingis was 7-foot center Andris Biedrins, who played for Golden State and Utah from 2004-14. Biedrins is no longer part of the Latvian program. Their other two standouts are point guard Janis Streinieks and shooting guard Davis Bertans. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: "I see coaches report players and pull them out of the game. I see players report themselves. I see players report each other," [Richard Ellenbogen] said. "Clearly, we've lowered the threshold for diagnosing concussion, for pulling players out and evaluating them.""We know there is always natural variability in the occurrence of illness and injuries, and last year could have been an unusually low year [for concussions]," NFL VP of health and safety policy Jeff Miller said Friday on a conference call. "Is this a real increase? Or, could it be caused by something else? Like more extensive screening, or more sensitive diagnostic testing or more self-reporting." author: Bart Hubbuch
summary: "It was just a gutty performance across the board," Falcons quarterback Matt Ryan told reporters after rolling up 306 passing yards without an interception that day against the Panthers' vaunted secondary. Crucial to counteracting Newton and the Panthers' potent offense is controlling the ball, and the Falcons certainly did that in Week 16. They stuck with the run game, and even though Atlanta rushed for just 77 yards, 30 carries helped the Falcons dominate time of possession (35:38 to just 24:22) and keep Newton off the field. Atlanta limited Newton to just 113 passing yards - his second-lowest output of the season - and sacked him twice. The Falcons' strategy of bringing pressure from the outside and keeping Newton in the pocket or forcing him to run up the middle worked well, and it's not difficult to see the Broncos' No. 1-ranked defense duplicating that strategy. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Unlikely source for winning blueprint

author: Steve Serby
summary: "Cam is dangerous," [Von Miller] said. "He's 6-6, 250 pounds. If he played defensive end, he probably would have had a $220 million deal. He can do whatever. He can pass, he can run, he's running over guys. I'm positive that he can play defense. There's not much that he can't do." "He's working well with Cam. It's probably the best offensive line that we've played in the playoffs," Miller said. "It's gonna be a tough challenge." "I feel like I've been here before," Miller said. "I didn't play in the first [Super Bowl] game before but I was there and I got to see it and I got to witness everything. It's my first Super Bowl, but it doesn't feel like I haven't been there before." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Drew Loftis
summary: Panthers fans do. Our team wears a Harry Potter cloak - mostly unseen for the bulk of the Panthers' existence, often confused with our expansion brethren, the Jacksonville Jaguars. Ours is a Carolina team whose hometown cannot be identified easily by the many who don't care to know. There's pride: I'm not accustomed to rooting for the best team in the league. There's embarrassment: How do I stay humble while rooting for the best team? There's fear: What if the best team doesn't win the Super Bowl? There's superstition: I will take the Broncos in the Bettor's Guide because I've picked against the Panthers routinely this season, and they keep on winning. Blame it on Newton's dabbing, [Josh Norman]'s trash-talking, [Luke Kuechly]'s unworldly linebackering, but now they are in the Super Bowl. Now you know who they are.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Carolina in our mind Panthers fan revels in relevance

author: Mark Cannizzaro
summary: Do the Broncos have star players on their roster? Sure they do. Quarterback Peyton Manning is one of the league's biggest stars. Linebackers Von Miller and DeMarcus Ware are stars. Statistics aside, the Broncos have been riding a synergy through this postseason that has been about winning a championship for the elder statesmen on the team - specifically Manning, who's probably playing for the last time, and Ware, who's in the Super Bowl for the first time in his otherwise-decorated 11-year career. "Getting Peyton another Super Bowl ring and DeMarcus his first is huge," running back C.J. Anderson said. "At the end of the day, that's who you play for. You play for your teammates." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Cam vs. machine Super showdown will pit balanced Broncos against Panthers phenoms

author: Brian Costello
summary: "I think those things stay for a long time," [Woody Johnson] said Friday at the "Jets House" in Manhattan. "They're kind of indelible ink. You've got to move on, move forward and learn from what happened in that game. Twice when we played Buffalo, the same thing. We've got to be better, that's all." "When you lose a game in football, it's never pleasant. It's a hard thing to live through," Johnson said. "I wish we had completed a few more passes and we could have won that easily. I don't think there was any game that we played that we weren't in it. We were in every single game. ... That's a sign of something good happening." "I don't think as an owner you can ever be satisfied until you do win the Super Bowl," Johnson said. "There's a Super Bowl [trophy] right out there and it's lonely. We haven't won [a Super Bowl] since ... this is Super Bowl 50 and that was Super Bowl III, so it's been a while." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Brett Cyrgalis
summary: "We have games like in Arizona where [Cory Schneider] stood on his head," [Ray Shero] said of the road game on Jan. 16, when Schneider had a 38-save shutout in a 2-0 Devils win. "Well, 'Thank God we have Cory Schneider.' Well, what the [heck]? We're paying him $6 million. If I'm paying $6 million to a left winger, he better score 40. Like, really? You expect him to do it. Cory is doing his job. "I think I'm not really out for recognition," Schneider said. "I don't necessarily care if people hear or know about it, or think of me a certain way. I think, whoever picks [the All-Star team], the league staff, it's nice that they think of you as one of the best players in the league and feel you deserve this opportunity. I think it's through hard work. I think that's what is rewarding about it is you've worked this hard and gotten to the point where that's where you're considered." "The people around me, my family, my friends, people that followed me my whole career - it's a pretty big deal," Schneider said. "I know with the fans or the media [it] might be a nuisance, but for the players, I'm going to go and enjoy it, soak everything up and enjoy the experience. Because you never know if you're going to go back." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Guts & Cory All-Star nod culmination of Schneider's long road

author: Brian Lewis
summary: "It's just been a good situation for me," [Deron Williams] said. "Top to bottom, the organization's been really great. The coaching staff and players, it's been a situation where I feel like I've come in and fit really nicely. It's everything." "It's definitely tough. Every year you're learning a new system, a new philosophy on offense, on defense. Players are being cycled in and out on top of that," Williams said before the game of the Nets' coaching turnover from Lionel Hollins to [Tony Brown], ironic considering his culpability in said instability. "It makes chemistry tough. It makes consistency tough. When there's that much change going on, it definitely affects you. "I figured they'd be a lot better. But I know they've struggled with injuries and things that've definitely hurt them and the coaching change and Billy getting let go. So there's a lot of things going on over there right now. I was a little surprised because Lionel's only been there a year and a half. I thought he'd get a little bit more of a chance. But that's the nature of this business." The system, it definitely fits my style, it's more free-flowing, more movement on offense, and they put me in a lot of great positions on the court offensively." "I figured they'd be a lot better," he said. "But I know they've struggled with injuries and things that've definitely hurt them, and the coaching change and Billy getting let go. author: Howie Kussoyl,Courting the Area
summary: "I told him to do what you got to do and we all understand, but he wanted to play," [Steve Pikiell] said. "There's no manual on how to handle those things. He played maybe the best game of his career, and then he went home and went to the funeral, but he didn't miss a game. That was all on him. He could do whatever he needed to do, but he was like, 'This is my family, too, and they need me here.' " "He's a guy that sacrifices, he does a lot of things for us and he's just gotten better and better," Pikiell said. "He was quiet for a little while. He's the most verbal guy on our team and he wasn't that Ray, but you give him a little space and a little time and he's back to Ray. He's been Ray for a while now. It's great to see." "I told him everything I wish I had heard when I was going through it," said [Peter Hooley], whose mother, Sue, died one year ago Saturday, from colon cancer. "It's tough because there's only so much you can say that can really help him get through it because you've been through it. I told him it's not ever gonna go away and you have to deal with it. I told him he doesn't always have to be strong and it's OK to have your time where you break down. He'll always have people around him. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. author: Zach Braziller
summary: [Angel Delgado]'s play is worth monitoring. The 6-foot-9 sophomore, coming off season-highs of 15 points and 17 rebounds against St. John's, was a non-factor against Creighton, overwhelmed by the Bluejays' 7-foot senior Geoffrey Groselle, who is third in the country in field-goal percentage (71 percent). In Seton Hall's six losses, Delgado is averaging just 7.1 points, 6.3 rebounds and 6.1 shot attempts, while in the team's 14 victories, he is averaging 9.1 points, 11.2 rebounds and 7.6 shot attempts. "In order for us to go far or go where we want to go, we need him on board," sophomore guard Khadeen Carrington said. summary: Sure, it's called Italian fast-casual, but when it's helmed by Mario Batali and [Mary Giuliani] you'll want to try something special, like the white bean, escarole and rosemary soup ($5.50 for 12 ounces), the spicy Sicilian tuna with crispy kale, basil pesto and sliced egg ( $13), or to-die-for Venetian rainbow cake ($4). It's chef Franklin Becker's third NYC location, and the buzz for the farm-to-table, gluten-free outfit is justified. The "Beet Box" Veggie Pattie with lentils, quinoa and chickpeas ($11.94) hits the spot for filling and healthy fare. Don't wait till summer to enjoy fresh lobster - try celeb chef Marc Forgione's Press Box ($21), which includes a pressed lobster sandwich, pickled veggies and kettle chips, and will satisfy any crustacean craving. Wash it down with a Maine Root drink ($4). Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
