summary: Based on the Jeffrey Toobin book "The Run of His Life," the show re-creates the nation-captivating story: the discovery of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman's bodies on June 13, 1994; [O.J. SIMPSON]'s attempted escape from the LAPD in a white Ford Bronco; wild courtroom moments ("If it doesn't fit, you must acquit"); and the shocking "not guilty" verdict. Understanding [Kris Jenner]' friendships was key to playing her. "She really was Nicole's best friend. For Kris, it was a horrifying, sad and unexpected time. She said, 'At the funeral, we didn't know what to think,' " [Blair] explains. "It was really painful that the alleged killer was going to be represented by their children's father in court . . . She talked about going to Nicole's house after [the murder], to get things for [Brown Simpson's] kids to have because they were staying with their grandparents. "Toobin didn't think [Christopher Darden] was a very good lawyer," Brown says. "What I learned [from Darden's book "In Contempt"] was . . . how naive Darden and [Marcia Clark] were. They thought the jury [would be] able to come to a logical conclusion that O.J. was guilty. They didn't understand the [racial] unrest. The verdict should have been about the murder of two innocent people, but it was an indictment of the LAPD."Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: In his latest film, "Dirty Grandpa," Robert De Niro gets friendly with himself while watching porn, performs a bad karaoke version of Ice Cube's "It Was a Good Day" and sexes up a college girl by dropping onto the bed and saying he's "fallen and can't get up." Could he have concentrated solely on "quality stuff"? It's not like Hollywood is overflowing with roles for a 72-year-old, and to De Niro's credit, he did appear in three prestige pics - David O. Russell's "Joy," "Silver Linings Playbook" and "American Hustle" - over the last few years, but likely didn't bank much. Critics point to 1999's "Analyze This" as the moment when De Niro's career began to tip. It marked his first foray into broad comedy and also found him sending up the weighty on-screen persona that earned him Oscars in films including "The Godfather Part II." The years that followed saw an increasing number of (often repellant) comedies on his rsum, such as 2002's "Showtime." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Make him an offer. De Niro can't refuse

summary: Newton's character was the biggest question. After an arrest at the University of Florida for a stolen laptop, questions about his recruitment to Auburn from a junior college and a view that he had attitude issues, many draft "experts" knocked Newton before the draft. The Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel polled 24 front office executives. Of the 24, 11 said they would not take Newton in the first round, and one said he would not take the Heisman Trophy winner at all. Blaine Gabbert and Jake Locker were viewed as better prospects by some. Thirteen of the 24 executives said Newton would either be a bust or never turn into an effective quarterback. "I knew Cam's ability and what he stood for. I knew [Von] very well because he was right down the street from us," Broncos coach Gary Kubiak, who was the Texans coach in 2011, said this week. "When you look back on it now and who's lining up and playing here in a couple of weeks, that tells you it was a pretty darn good draft for both teams." "At 11, I don't think we would have picked him if we had that pick," said [Joe Banner], whose Eagles took Danny Watkins with the 23rd pick. "I would say we missed on him. I guess it was just a misevaluation. I don't remember any specific testing or character. I just think we watched the film and didn't fully realize the potential of what he's become." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: HEAD OF THE CLASS Newton, Miller in Super clash of remarkable 2011 draft

summary: "Pete Carroll ran kids off. Nick Saban and Jimbo Fisher [did too]," [Mike Farrell] said. "Every great coach has had to back off a commitment - whether for academic reasons, character reasons, injury reasons, they weren't developing properly. I've seen 50 percent of classes wind up elsewhere. It's all coming at the end of the cycle, which is leading to criticism. It's the timing. "To me, he's setting the bar for people," [Brian Dohn] said. "He's creative. These are kids who are impressionable. Kids are thinking, 'This is how much this guy wants me to play at his school.' Everybody looks at it as going to class or sleeping over. It's building a relationship. He's doing it in a way people haven't done it before." "They're like bulldogs," DePaul Catholic associate head coach Brian Murray said. "They want a guy, they're coming after him. If you're working 20 hours a week, they're working 24." summary: Vanessa Hudgens grew up doing acting in musical theater before becoming a household name in Disney Channel's "High School Musical." After moving on to Broadway ("Gigi") and movies ("Spring Breakers"), she's now portraying the feisty Rizzo in Fox's live production of "Grease." On a break during tech rehearsals last week, the 27-year-old actress talked to The Post about taking on the iconic role. I had a big flip. I never saw myself as Rizzo, because as a kid watching the movie, Rizzo's mean. The older you get the more you appreciate her fierceness. I'm very bubbly most of the time and really nice, but I'm honest and I'm frank and that's what Rizzo is. It's such a fun character to play. [Manson] is big again. Last year we had the series "Aquarius." Now we have "Manson's Lost Girls," the story of the women he taught to steal and kill. They are: Susan Atkins (Eden Brolin), Squeaky Fromme (Grace Victoria Cox), Linda Kasabian (Mackenzie Mauzy), Patricia Krenwinkel (Isabel Shill) and Leslie Van Houten (Greer Grammer). The story kicks off with Linda's arrival at the Spahn Ranch hippie commune. Taken with Manson, she is soon drawn into a life of crime, notably theft, in what they called "creepy crawls." Linda reluctantly becomes an accomplice in Manson's "Helter Skelter" murder spree that claimed the life of actress Sharon Tate. She ultimately breaks away and turns herself in as a witness for the prosecution and helps to convict Manson.Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: TV 8 THINGS TO WATCH THIS WEEK

summary: "He was undefeated with us on free-agent signings," [Ernie Accorsi] said. "Whether it was a star like Plaxico [Burress] or Antonio [Pierce] or whether it was Shaun O'Hara and people like that. When we signed Antonio Pierce, he was playing the outside. We signed him as a middle linebacker, [Dave Gettleman] was convinced he could play middle linebacker." "And I felt sorry for Dave on the thing, I don't think it was an easy decision for [John Mara] or the Tisches," Accorsi said. "When Jerry got it, I could tell Dave was down. I said to him, 'Look, I have no idea if I'm ever going to be able to deliver on this, but if I possibly can take care of you, I will.' " Lo and behold, Accorsi found a second career as a consultant, helping NFL teams find and hire head-coach and front-office candidates. The Browns needed a GM in 2009, and then-owner Randy Lerner sought Accorsi's advice. Accorsi recommended Gettleman, but George Kokinis got the job - and lasted just six months. Gettleman interviewed with the Chiefs, but the GM position went to Scott Pioli. In 2010, Accorsi again pushed Gettleman on the Browns and thought this time would be the charm. Instead, they hired Mike Holmgren. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: GETTLE'S METTLE Took long time for former Giants exec to land dream job as GM

summary: In his latest film, "Dirty Grandpa," Robert De Niro gets friendly with himself while watching porn, performs a bad karaoke version of Ice Cube's "It Was a Good Day" and sexes up a college girl by dropping onto the bed and saying he's "fallen and can't get up." Could he have concentrated solely on "quality stuff"? It's not like Hollywood is overflowing with roles for a 72-year-old, and to De Niro's credit, he did appear in three prestige pics - David O. Russell's "Joy," "Silver Linings Playbook" and "American Hustle" - over the last few years, but likely didn't bank much. Critics point to 1999's "Analyze This" as the moment when De Niro's career began to tip. It marked his first foray into broad comedy and also found him sending up the weighty on-screen persona that earned him Oscars in films including "The Godfather Part II." The years that followed saw an increasing number of (often repellant) comedies on his rsum, such as 2002's "Showtime." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Make him an offer. De Niro can't refuse

summary: Though Louis B. Mayer's name was on the MGM logo, [Eddie Mannix] (as general manager and later a vice-president) ran the studio from the 1930s through the '50s, according to E.J. Fleming, author of "The Fixers: Eddie Mannix, Howard Strickling and the MGM Publicity Machine." Mannix probably would have ended up a low-level mobster buried in the Meadowlands had he not gone to work for Nick Schenck in 1919. Schenck owned amusement parks and movie houses. Mannix became his right-hand man. When Schenck acquired MGM in a deal, he dispatched Mannix to Los Angeles to keep tabs on the studio, and Mayer in particular. The legendary movie producer may not have known it at the time, but a copy of every telegram he wrote wound up on Mannix's desk. Things got ugly when [George Reeves] fell in love with a socialite and broke [Toni]'s heart. There was a party at Reeves' house one night. By morning, he was dead - shot in the head. It was ruled a suicide, though many books (including Fleming's) posit it was almost certainly a murder. Some have fingered Mannix. Fleming argues that it was the socialite. In any case, Mannix didn't want Toni mixed up with a murder. So he painted another suicide. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: H'wood's Mr. Fix It Erased scandal - and maybe Superman, too

author: Mike Vaccaro
summary: "Our game is to get as many open shots as we can, and when we're open we're supposed to take them," Curry said after dropping 30 on the Terps, thrilling the Buffalo crowd by shooting 14 3-pointers and making half of them, and that seemed so ... what? Cute? Adorable? Fascinating? That was the day so many people learned that Dell Curry - who never met a long-distance shot he didn't think he could make in 16 years as an NBA player - had a son. "He's not a legacy player," [Davidson] coach Bob McKillop warned us after his team finally had succumbed to Maryland, 82-70. "Just wait and see how good he's going to be. Soon enough he won't be Dell's kid. Dell will be Steph's dad." "This kid," he said at halftime, "makes me wish I could be 25 years old again, squeeze into my uniform, and play. I'd love to play with him. Look at him!" Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: He is not there yet. But [Peyton Manning] is. Manning might never have drawn out the kind of passionate dislike some of his elite status can (again, refer to [Tom Brady], Thomas) but it always has been easy to grow tired of Manning since not only have all his games seemingly been on national TV, but he has filled the commercial time between timeouts seemingly by himself, too. (Sung to the "Nationwide" tune: "Pey-ton Manning's/Ev'ry-where")That's where Peyton is now. The arm that broke hundreds of hearts and the face that nearly broke millions of TV tubes? Even if you aren't rooting for the Broncos, you probably are rooting for Peyton. It's the circle of life. Especially for an athlete. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. summary: "Every year is a new team and you try to get everybody on the same page and playing up to par as fast as you can," [Ryan McDonagh] said. We went in a little slump there, but it taught us a good lesson in what it takes every night to win games. We've really been competing hard, battling hard, coming up with loose pucks on the wall, winning those battles, and that helps everybody. "I'm really excited," McDonagh said. "It's going to be a lot more enjoyable coming off [the win over the Sabres], knowing the fact that our team is starting to play a little more consistent here, and understanding what our strengths are. Certainly, that's my main goal is what's going on with the Rangers. "I know and I hope that the guys understand that I'm a big, impact player here," McDonagh said. "I know that. I play in a lot of situations, and I need to step up in a lot of different roles. And it feels good to have that recognition. summary: "It's always easier to get better after you lose," Villanova coach Jay Wright said. "It's a challenge to win and keep getting better. This will help us get better." "I think being young players going through this for the first time helps, but I think more important is not really being a salesman and just being honest and up-front and calling it like it is," coach Chris Mullin said. "From Day 1, I told them if you work hard and give good effort, we'll live with the results. When we look at the film and when we talk about performance, we're very honest about it. I don't try and sell my game plan or philosophy; I really just try to teach them the right way to play. Individually, guys have to deal with losing and frustration and all that, but I think on a daily basis it's much easier if you're up-front and you call it like it is. author: Ken Davidoff
summary: The Royals' average age of their Opening Day roster, according to data compiled by Major League Baseball, was 30.13, second-oldest in the American League behind the Yankees (30.19) - who also qualified for the playoffs by going 87-75. The Mets' Opening Day roster stood at 29.14, 10th-oldest (sixth-youngest, for those scoring at home) in the National League. "It's pretty much common sense that when you're younger, your body works a little better," Royals general manager Dayton Moore said in a telephone interview this past week. "But superior athletes are genetically gifted and are able to maintain it longer." "This year, I feel if we stay healthy, we'll benefit greatly from our experience," said Ross Atkins, who became the Blue Jays' general manager last month. "If we don't, it could have something to do with our age. That's the balance of youth versus experience in my view." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. I need confidence to go down there and bring in a few guys to continue what we've been doing, and I didn't see that [Friday]. Not putting any pressure on them, but I need to find a group of guys that's going to get some chemistry out there and keep us in ballgames." author: JOHN CRUDELE
summary: Bookstores and textbook publishers now want to sell bundles. That means when a first-year math student buys a textbook, he or she is also required to buy the study guide and a solutions manual for the math problems that are included in the textbook.When the study guide and solutions manual are digital and the student pays $300 for the bundle, he only has access to the digital study guide/solutions manual for a limited number of months. At the beginning of the next year, the book publisher changes the codes for the study guide/solution manual. summary: Wall Street's most vocal soothsayer on digital media is BTIG's Rich Greenfield, and he's been hammering Disney's ESPN over the size of its customer base. To that, Greenfield responded: "If this is an important issue for ESPN, they should start releasing actual subscriber numbers rather than relying on third parties [Nielsen]. If they are upset with the confusion, let's see the actual number of paying subscribers in the US over five years." He added that Nielsen's flip-flop on the inclusion of broadband-only homes has created a "multiyear mess." Can't argue with that.  "They put people on firing lists who they didn't mean to - people who were lower on the performance scale but who weren't meant to get fired," an insider explained. author: Kyle Smith
summary: On page one, we're informed that "in the 1950s, it was a man's world" and that girls "weren't supposed to act smart, tough or ambitious." Little [Hillary Rodham Clinton], looking spunky in a bright-red dress, is set off against a gray and brown array of celebrated men of the time, including Nat King Cole and Jackie Robinson. "Only boys had no ceilings on their dreams," go the harrumphing words.  After "upstaging boys in class" - not just succeeding but "upstaging boys," because it's important that your little girl learn to see life as an us-against-them situation - the teen Hillary "met with poor black and Latino teenagers in the inner city." Brave Hillary! Later, in law school, we learn that Hillary "walked up and down dangerous blocks in Texas, registering voters for the presidential election." "Dangerous" apparently means "populated by Latinos," because below these words is a picture of Hillary talking to brown-skinned people on a sidewalk.  Any girls out there who feel they're "born to lead" should learn early how to dismiss such contradictions, and how to frame any criticism as unfair. During her husband's 1992 presidential campaign, we're told that Hillary "couldn't believe how people criticized her - in ways they'd never criticize a man." If any first-graders being read this book raise their hands and say, "Don't people make fun of how Donald Trump and Chris Christie look?" pay no attention. They're probably related to the Koch Brothers.  Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Think of the children! A new Hillary Clinton kid's book aims to indoctrinate young minds

author: Billy Heller
summary: Her reign ended in nine days. Now [Suzannah Dunn] ("The May Bride,") imagines what happened next to Lady Jane Grey after "Bloody" Queen Mary kicked the not-so-sweet-16-year-old usurper off the English throne. Narrated by lady-in-waiting and fellow teen Elizabeth Tinley, the novel describes Jane's time in the Tower of London. Having very little in common, two girls bond over their mutual dislike of Jane's arranged-marriage husband, fellow teen prisoner Guildford Dudley. But in this story of three young people coming of age, only Elizabeth will walk away.Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Required Reading

summary: I was appalled by Seth Lipsky's shameless defense of those at the Center for Medical Progress, whose doctored videos of Planned Parenthood make it appear as though it sells parts of aborted fetuses for profit, which it doesn't do and has never done ("Jail the Journalists?" PostOpinion, Jan. 28). Given the alarming rates of obesity and Type 2 diabetes in children, providing calorie-appropriate meals, according to McDonald's, is simply not good enough. It's a parent's right to raise their kids the way they choose, but you'll be hard-pressed to find one who wants to feed their kids junk. It's surprising to me that some teachers are upset by my book about my rookie year teaching, "The Battle for Room 314" ("Teacher blasts expos on abuse in NYC schools," Jan. 24). summary: HHS spokesman Mark Weber told The Post his agency bypassed procedures only in "very few" cases - numbering "in the hundreds" - and that officials with "years of experience" felt confident the steps weren't needed. The AP found "more than two dozen children" released to adults who subjected them to "labor trafficking or severe abuse or neglect." Some kids were raped by their sponsors' associates. "We were concerned it could have been a front to have those kids released so that traffickers could get them into the workforce," AP was told by Hilary Chester - a higher-up at the US Council of Catholic Bishops, which does much of this social work under government contract. Today, Chester notes, "No one knows where the kids are." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.
title: Federal Child-Traffickers EDITORIAL

summary: The key flaw is what we'd call a lack of tough love - the need to marry the "right to shelter" with a "mandate of services." That is, to push "clients" to make the necessary personal progress - by providing both the resources and the pressure to overcome the problems that left them homeless. "The focus should be getting out of the shelter system," says Doe Fund President George McDonald. "If you're able to go to work, you should work, because it will get you up and out of the system sooner." We doubt the de Blasio review will admit this obvious truth - because it's being led by Human Resources chief Steven Banks, who's spent much of his career fighting for unconditional homeless "rights." Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission.

summary: Frustrated staffers call the OACE's performance "embarrassing" and "totally unacceptable." Many blame Superintendent Rose-Marie Mills, who has led OACE for three years. "There's no feedback, no support, no curriculum. We're left to our own devices," said a veteran teacher. Influential lobbyist Jennifer Cunningham is the point person in six of the seven Knickerbocker contracts with Puerto Rico, records show. Cunningham, pal to Gov. Cuomo and former wife of Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, is a former honcho with SEIU Local 1199, the giant health-care-workers union based in Manhattan. author: Michael Goodwin
summary: [William Safire] took a lot of heat, with critics disputing not so much his conclusion about a raft of incidents but the bare-knuckled way he expressed it. [Bill Clinton]'s press secretary supplied obligatory chivalry by saying, "The president, if he were not the president, would have delivered a more forceful response on the bridge of Mr. Safire's nose." Safire used a later column to defend his language with a dissection of both "congenital" and "liar." He cited Winston Churchill, who had once chided a colleague for "terminological inexactitude," before quoting Churchill's advice that "short words are best, and the old words when short are best of all." Nobody "watches" anything anymore, they "monitor" it. No action is taken until all "stakeholders" are consulted. We say "price point" when we mean "price." And is there no other way to express sympathy besides pledging "thoughts and prayers"? Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner.
